Like Fire in Our Bones

by acuteneurosis

Summary

With all of the most important things in the galaxy literally exploding around her, Leia is given the chance to go back and help keep a promise she never personally made.

But then, for Skywalkers, saving the galaxy was always a family matter.

Notes

Delving into a new fandom here. Hope you enjoy.

Desert Born

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The first thing she noticed as she woke was the pain. She wasnâ€™t expecting it and was more than a little surprised to realize it felt like her skin had shrunk over her muscles and that her joints all ached as if they had been wrenched almost apart.

Normally, the pain only came after she was awake enough to realize that Luke was still gone.

The ache in her heart pulsed, and Leia made herself breathe slowly as the last thought crossed her mind twice more, checking itself against reality. Yes, that faint light that had been ever-present in her mind was still dark and cold. Yes, she could not find her brother. Yes, Luke really was still gone.

Riding the waves of anguish that the unavoidable next thoughts brought (yes, that meant Han and Chewie were gone too) Leia forced herself to open her eyes and suffered another shock.

This was not her room.

Not Coruscant. Not planetside on any of the places that she had visited in the past weeks. Not her quarters on the ship that had almost started to feel like home until the moment when she had realized she might never find home ever again.

Not her room.

Pale walls, sparse furnishings, a musty smell like it was rarely used. No windows, but an open door, and the light seeping from that portal brought more brightness than she would have expected. Looking down at herself, but hesitating to move, Leia noted thin, white sheets, soft and well worn, slightly greyed from use.

â€œYouâ€™re awake,â€ a gentle, low voice murmured, and Leia turned to face the woman who slowly entered the room. Dark hair just barely touched with grey, a concerned, motherly look (which touched another pain, older but more painful again for the new pains stacked atop it), and cheap if serviceable clothes. Desert style and well worn, like the face of the woman. Like the sheets.

Shmi.

â€œOh hell,â€ Leia groaned, squeezing her eyes shut and trying desperately not to remember. To her surprise, that earned a soft chuckle.

â€œNot quite, but close enough,â€ Shmiâ€™s voice was smiling, Leia knew. Not at all offended, but maybe a little curious. â€œAnd you seem to have caught the worst of it.â€

The tentative, â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ died in the back of Leiaâ€™s throat. Sheâ€™d done enough apologizing these past months. So much it had almost crushed her even before all of this. â€œThank you,â€ she managed instead. â€œYou definitely saved me.â€

There was a gentle shush of fabric moving and the bed dipped slightly. â€œIt isnâ€™t wise to be caught in the desert during a storm. Weâ€™ve been wondering how you got here.â€

Hazy figures tugged at Leiaâ€™s memory, but she couldnâ€™t remember them distinctly. Everything after she had landed was still mostly a blur. Except that brief introduction.

â€œIâ€™m Shmi Skywalker. Youâ€™re safe.â€

â€œTo be honest,â€ Leia said, struggling to sit up without wincing, â€œI donâ€™t think I could explain it. Iâ€™m not really sure how it all happened.â€

That was a lie. Or at least a violent exaggeration of the truth. But there was no way she was going to try and explain it. Not to this woman and not now. Maybe somedayâ€¦

â€œCliegg is worried,â€ Shmi started, and seeing Leiaâ€™s confusion added, â€œMy husband. We donâ€™t get many visitors out here, and almost everyone from the planet knows how to not get caught in a storm. You arenâ€™t from here,â€ she said, giving Leia a brief look over, â€œand heâ€™s worried what it could mean.â€

â€œWhy? Iâ€™m not dangerous.â€ Also a lie, but a much less obvious one.

Shmi hesitated. â€œThe last time I let strangers into my home who were from off world to protect them from a storm, one was a Jedi. And he took my son. It isâ€¦ difficult to not see the similarities.â€

â€œIâ€™m sending you to someone safe. Probably the only one who can help you actually fix everything. Do whatever is necessary. And donâ€™t look back.â€

The words were a cold impression on Leiaâ€™s mind, and she swallowed slowly. â€œIâ€™m not a Jedi,â€ she said carefully. â€œI never could be.â€

â€œMost of us canâ€™t,â€ Shmi said, a cautious look on her face. â€œThat is aâ€¦ unique way to put it.â€

It took two more swallows and a deep breath before Leia managed in a tight voice, â€œMy brotherâ€¦ was. Wasâ€¦ a Jedi.â€

It was all she could manage. There was probably more she ought to add, to explain. Luke hadnâ€™t really been a Jedi in the way that Shmi would be familiar with, if she had met a "real" Jedi. Temple trained Jedi. Child stealing Jedi (and Luke had never really gotten over that when he had realized how it had to have been, and what had happened to hisâ€”their faâ€” to Vader).

A warm hand covered hers, and Leia looked into eyes filled with deep sympathy and compassion. â€œIâ€™m sorry. So sorry that you lost someone you loved.â€

â€œEveryone,â€ Leia croaked, the grief lodged in her throat. â€œIt was everyone, over and overâ€”â€œ

Alderaan and the rebels and planet after planet that they couldnâ€™t bring into the new Republic and Luke and Han and Chewie and Artoo andâ€”

â€œAnd donâ€™t look back.â€

She couldnâ€™t. Couldnâ€™t stop. Her eyes firmly fixed on the past, Leia cried and cried. Cried like she hadnâ€™t allowed herself for years. Not since her mother and father had buried their friends as traitors and refused themselves even a single tear, just to protect her. She cried with grief and rage and hopelessness, sobbing in Shmi's arms, words and whispers of comfort washing over her in gentle, unintelligible waves. And Leia knew, no matter how much it hurt, she could never go back.

But she wasnâ€™t strong enough not to look. Not yet.

Maybe never.

The Lars homestead was exactly as Luke had once described it and also nothing like his description at all. The basic framework was all there. Buildings mostly below ground level, different sections to spare power when it was scarce and confuse possible raiders, desert colors, few doors, and sand. Sand everywhere, no matter what you did. Always, all the sand. But that was just a feature of Tatooine, heâ€™d said. All the sand in the worlds.

It was also a home. The ceilings were painted with dark designs in contrast to the pale walls. There were some tapestries and it had a very well used kitchen that smelled of earth and something Leia couldnâ€™t quite place. For a place where nothing was supposed to grow, there was still the occasional splash of pale green and all the Larses were adamant that they were on a farm.

Leia hoped it was true, though it was a bit difficult to believe them.

Shmi was also mostly what Leia had expected, and nothing like. Luke's mentions of a grandmother that had died before he was even born had spoken of her kindness and gentleness, conveyed to him by stories from his aunt and uncle.

He hadn't mentioned that Shmi was strong. And brave (it took a lot to comfort a close friend, much less a complete stranger).

Leia let her fingers skim across the wall as she was led out of her room and down the hall. The tightness of her skin made it agitating, but there was something grounding in the action so she didnâ€™t stop. Just took slow, careful steps as her bones creaked and her muscles stretched and eventually relaxed. Taking the few steps up to the open courtyard Shmi was leading Leia to was a little more painful, but she managed.

â€œSo what brought you to our crack in the galaxy?â€ Cliegg had asked the moment she had reached out to shake his hand, carefully not wincing at the firm pressure.

Sensing his distrust (and was that just her experience talking, or was she feeling the Force at all, why hadnâ€™t Luke ever explained the difference?) Leia hesitated before she answered. â€œIâ€™m looking for something. Aâ€”A new start, I think. Or maybe just something better than where I was.â€

â€œSo you came here?â€ was the patently skeptical answer. â€œWhoever sold you that story was full ofâ€”â€œ

â€œCliegg,â€ Shmi cut him off firmly. â€œYou didnâ€™t let her finish.â€

â€œItâ€™s alright,â€ Leia said, shrugging. â€œI know Iâ€™m out of place here. I understand his disbelief.â€

â€œDo you?â€ he pressed, looking her up and down, taking in her fine, dark clothes (she wouldnâ€™t think about mourning, not under his scrutiny) and carefully styled if now mussy hair. She knew her skin was still mostly soft, even after all her adventures. There might be a few new stress lines on her forehead and around her eyes, but there was nothing about her that said she had ever been exposed to the idea of manual labor, much less put thought into practice.

Four years with her home gone and even a complete stranger still saw her as a delicate little princess.

â€œNo need to look so surprised,â€ she managed to say with enough of an edge that Clieggâ€™s eyebrows shot up. â€œI wasnâ€™t planning on being here earlier today, but now I am and thatâ€™s just how it is. I can handle it.â€

That earned her a snort. â€œSays the girl who landed in the middle of a sandstorm,â€ he shot back. â€œWhereâ€™s your ship?â€

And of course he had to start with that awkward question. â€œI losâ€” I exchanged it. To get here.â€

Technically true. Completely false.

â€œI donâ€™t care what pile of scrap you were piloting,â€ Cliegg was, if possible, even more dismissive now, â€œif you traded it to stay here, you were cheated. And you deserve it.â€

Leia managed not to mutter a bitter agreement and forced herself to keep his gaze until he was the one that looked away. But it was a dirty trick. He wasnâ€™t wrong. Not about anything important.

â€œWhy donâ€™t we have lunch?â€ Shmi intervened gently, placing a hand on each of their shoulders. â€œI think everyone will feel better after weâ€™ve eaten.â€

There was a grunt of reluctant assent from her husband and Shmi used it as an excuse to immediately shoo Leia to the kitchen to help with the meal. Since at this point that mostly meant helping to carry the dishes that a girl introduced as Beru seemed to have been preparing (that was Lukeâ€™s aunt, wasnâ€™t it, why hadnâ€™t he talked about this place more?) Leia was able to be unembarrassed and helpful.

Who knew how long that would last.

Oh, this really is hell.

It was a brief thought that flared for a bright and sharp moment, hot and dry as the surrounding landscape, as the protocol droid in front of her turned and with an all too familiar stunted gesture in an all too familiar helpful tone announced, â€œHello, I am C-3PO, human cyborg relations. And who might you be?â€

â€œLeia,â€ she managed with what she felt was remarkable clarity as she stared at the grey metal coverings so unlike the gold she remembered and tried to reconcile the two images. â€œIâ€™m Leia.â€

â€œA pleasure to meet you, Mistress Leia. I hope I may be of service during your stay here. Iâ€”â€œ

â€œThank you,â€ she cut him off with what she hoped was not too forced of a smile. â€œIâ€™ll let you know if I need anything.â€

â€œOf course! Only say the word and I...â€œ

It was a relief to hear Shmi chuckle next to Leia, and made the younger woman relax as the all too familiar droid took several more seconds to pledge his service.

â€œHeâ€™s a bitâ€¦ excitable,â€ Shmi admitted when they finally moved away from the vaporators and back towards the house (and it turned out this pile of rocks and machinery really was a farm, of sorts). â€œBut I canâ€™t help but love him in spite of it. Anakin begged me to keep him when he left.â€

Heart stuttering slightly, Leia hesitantly asked, â€œAnakin?â€

â€œMy son,â€ Shmi answered quickly, her eyes gazing determinedly out across the desert. â€œThe one who was taâ€”who left. With the Jedi. I expect he is still training with them, since they didnâ€™t bring him back.â€

The forced humor in her tone resonated with a tight feeling that prickled over Leiaâ€™s skin and she hoped (if only Luke had ever properly explained) that it was a Force driven sense of what Shmi was clearly feeling. Grief and loss. Maybe even regret?

It resonated even more as Leia thought about it, so that was probably right. If there were any feelings Leia would be able to pick up on right now, those would be it.

â€œAre you sorry?â€ The words had escaped before she could think them through, and Leia winced a bit as Shmiâ€™s gaze snapped back to her guest.

There was a moment of hesitation before she answered. â€œI donâ€™t regret freeing him. He deserved to be free. Everyone does. I couldnâ€™t make him stay here either. Not after having been raised a slave. He would have tried to stay with me, tried to work for Watto to make him let me go. And that wouldnâ€™t have worked. No better than before at least. He isâ€”was such a sweet child. Always wanting to help everyone. I couldnâ€™t hold him back. Not here. Not like this.â€

It was difficult, impossible even for Leia to imagine what Shmi was saying. The only image in her head of Anakin Skywalker was a grown man, firm in his position in the Empire. Commander, tormentor, Sith.

How had he gone from being the sweet boy that Shmi remembered to beingâ€¦ that?

â€œIt must be hard,â€ Leia said at last, tripping a little over the words. They were so inadequate.

Shmi sighed. â€œWe do anything for the people that we love. No matter what it costs us. Itâ€™s the joy and pain of being a parent.â€

â€œI owe you. Possibly more than anyone else. Will you let me do this?â€

With a shudder Leia dragged herself back to the present, away from that ghostly place in her mind, cold blues and blacks, the saddest eyes (but she would never, ever forgive him), words that echoed pain across the empty silence in her heart (she couldnâ€™t feel Lukeâ€™s heartbeat, not anymore). Grinding her steps into the sandy ground, Leia let the irritation and pain of each movement grate through her mind in place of the memories that wanted to linger there.

â€œIs it worth it?â€ She hadnâ€™t meant to ask that question either, but something in Shmiâ€™s face told Leia the woman had not been asked this question often enough.

â€œI hope so,â€ was the whispered response. â€œI hope it was worth it.â€

Descending the stone steps back into the house, Leia turned that thought over and over in her mind, lingering on it.

There was a pressure to it. Not quite like the tight prickling of grief, but with the same ethereal tone it swirled about in Leiaâ€™s mind. Ephemeral and delicate, as if it could change from one heartbeat to the next.

Hope.

The thought lingered as Leia helped with dishes and then allowed Beru to guide her through some basic attempts at helping with the cooking. It danced around, back and forth as Owen and Cliegg returned and the family sat down to dinner. It swelled as Leia found herself staring at C-3PO later that evening while helping the family shut down the homestead for the night.Â  It burned as she changed into the clothes she had borrowed, letting her hair out and combing through the strands more meditatively than productively. The thought twisted and writhed as she tried to connect Shmiâ€™s longing to the masked face of Darth Vader and failed time and again to feel anything beyond the pain of the past.

â€œWhy did you send me here?â€ she asked the darkness in hushed tones, knowing there would be no answer. That there couldnâ€™t be, not anymore.

That had been the price.

â€œDo whatever is necessary.â€

Could she? Leia didnâ€™t even know what was necessary. Had virtually no training to reach into the Force and try and figure it out. She had only her gut instincts. And longing. Longing so deep and painful it almost stole her breath as she allowed it to come forward and gave it the attention she had been denying it all day.

It didnâ€™t hurt as much now, she noticed. Now that she had cried some of it out.

She had a feeling though, that it would be back. In force.

Something clicked then, a dangerous thought.

What would Shmi give, to have a second chance?

The pressure around her swelled and for a split second Leia knew, knew that if she offered Shmi the chance to see Anakin again Shmi would take it. No questions asked. Knew it as well as she had known the feeling of her brotherâ€™s life, shining near or far in the galaxy. As well as she knew her own name.

â€œI canâ€™t,â€ she said out loud, thinking of Cliegg and Owen and Beru. Of responsibilities here and now. Of a lack of ship, or destination. Leia didnâ€™t even know where Anakin Skywalker was right now. Or what year it was. Or anything.

â€œDo whatever is necessary.â€

Luke had told her she was brave. Braver than he was (as brave as Shmi was?).

She hoped that was true.

â€œAnd donâ€™t look back.â€

Chapter End Notes

I won't make any hard promises now about how much Extended Universe content will or will not appear in this story, but odds are higher than not that I will not be especially EU compliant, long or short term.
You have been warned.

I'll be adding more tags as they come up.

Reckless Abandoned

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The cold of the morning surprised her a little and Leia moved hurriedly from her room, across the courtyard, and into the kitchen where Beru, bless her, was already busy preparing breakfast.

â€œIs there anything I can do to help?â€ Leia asked, swallowing pride and preparing to admit that whatever came out of Beruâ€™s mouth would probably be outside the limit of the once princessâ€™ cooking knowledge.

Luckily, Beru was either the kindest secondary hostess alive, or had read Leia perfectly well the day before. â€œThe powerâ€™s still off in the droid garage. Could you go and turn it on? That way the droids can warm up before Cliegg and Owen need them.â€

â€œOf course.â€ Because naturally Leia was more at home among wires and oil baths than kitchen implements and home cooked meals. Sheâ€™d been in the rebellion far too long if this was what it had done to her.

What would her mother have said?

Not much, Leia had to admit as she bounded up one set of stone steps and then down another. Breha had never been one to fight her daughterâ€™s nature, and Leia had been bound for adventure and rebellion as long as she had known the difference between the words Empire and Republic. The Alderaanian woman probably would have laughed and recommended Leia hire good help for the kitchen.

Smile tugging at her lips, Leia was able to face C-3POâ€™s morning greetings with more composure than she had anticipated.

â€œWell, if it isnâ€™t Mistress Leia. So good to see you again. I trust you have been enjoying your stay here.â€

Biting back the truth (there was nothing enjoyable in anything about this place) she managed, â€œIâ€™m very grateful. The Larses have been very kind, letting me stay here like this. Iâ€”I donâ€™t have any way to repay them.â€

â€œOh, Iâ€™m sure they donâ€™t mind that,â€ Threepio said cheerfully. â€œThey are, as you said, most kind and most generous. Only think, Mistress Shmi insisted I be kept on all these years, and even convinced Master Cliegg that I needed new coverings. He said I wouldnâ€™t be very useful, and indeed sometime I wonder if Iâ€™m best suited for this job. My primary programming is etiquette, you know, and...â€œ

Nodding and making humming noises in all the right places, Leia checked the room to make sure the power was reaching everything properly, and that the droids were powering up as they should. C-3PO trailed along directly behind her, offering increasingly useless help and complimenting almost every choice she made in the few minutes it took her to make a full circuit of the room.

Who would have thought sheâ€™d be so sick of a familiar face already?

â€œThreepio,â€ she said, placing a hand over his mouth as she turned, ready to head back inside, â€œI need to go and see if Beru needs anything else. Iâ€™ll see you later today?â€

â€œWhy of course. Iâ€™ll just be out at the vaporators again. You must let me know if there is anything I can do for you. Anything at all."

"Thank you," Leia managed another smile, still tight but almost equal parts amused, and escaped back to the house before the protocol droid could start up again. She found Beru alone in the kitchen still. "Anything else I can do?"

Halfway through whatever would probably end up being the main part of their breakfast, Beru paused to think about the question. "No, I'm probably all good in here for now. Everyone else should be up soon." Then, conscientiously, "Did you sleep alright?"

The truth was probably close to, "As well as could be expected," but keeping in mind who she was talking to (and realizing she hadn't dreamed of her and Han's potential child again, so there weren't any tiny figures with dark eyes and soft, dark curls haunting her today) Leia managed instead, "Very well, thank you."

This was probably a good chance to also explain why she was up before sunrise, especially since no one had asked her to be available this morning, but Leia struggled to find those words and frame them in any way that came across naturally. She couldn't decide whether to be grateful or embarrassed when Beru's solution to the silence was to quietly turn back to breakfast and not push or even say anything.

â€œYouâ€™re up early.â€

And of course it would be Cliegg who would notice. And say something. Leia set the tray of drinks on the table and smiled calmly, drawing on her senatorial experience almost as naturally as breathing. â€œI do that sometimes.â€

A gentle nudge from Shmi prevented any further comments from her husband and they managed to sit down to a quiet breakfast. Owen and his father made plans for the day and Shmi explained to Leia that she wouldnâ€™t be expected to help with any of the chores.

â€œIâ€™d be happy to help,â€ Leia immediately offered, pointedly ignoring Clieggâ€™s skeptical look. â€œIâ€™m pretty quick at picking things up.â€

Shmi hesitated, looking between her guest and her husband. â€œWeâ€™ll be going over the building systems today, making sure the climate control is working properly. And maybe gathering the mushrooms from around the vaporators. It helps keep the animals away so they get less damaged.â€

â€œIâ€™ve worked a little on climate control before,â€ Leia offered. Multiple times, in completely different environments with a plucky multi-purpose astromech droid to help her, but who was really counting? â€œAnd I can always carry things.â€

It was a winning idea as far as not feeling guilty while everyone worked that day. It was less successful in that Shmi and Beru had a work method that required minimal verbal communication, and frequently required very little from Leia as well. Which meant a day of very light physical labor and plenty of time to linger in her own thoughts.

Leia spent a lot of time practicing thinking about nothing (except a vicious loop of Lukeâ€™s voice telling her to clear her mind), but she wasnâ€™t really sure about how well it worked.

â€œYouâ€™re tired,â€ Shmi said that evening as Leia returned from helping with the nightly shut down again. And there was an invitation in the words that suggested they meant more than just physical exhaustion.

It took two long breaths and swallowing twice as many lies before Leia could answer, â€œItâ€™s been a long day.â€

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ Shmi put an arm around Leiaâ€™s shoulders, her voice understanding and gentle. â€œIt isnâ€™t always easy to be alone with the memories.â€

â€œDoes it feel like heâ€™s dead then?â€ Leia asked before she could think better of it. She barely repressed a flinch at her own words.

Shmi hesitated before answering in an almost inaudible whisper, â€œSometimes. Yes, sometimes it does.â€

Leia remembered that.

She thought about it over and over in the following weeks as she learned more than she had ever planned to about vaporators and the shockingly small amount of water that seemed to exist on Tatooine. She thought about it between thoughts of her brother, and of Han, and Chewbacca, and every time Threepio asked her if there was anything that he could do to be of service. She thought about it as Clieggâ€™s gruff demeanor gradually improved and she earned what she thought was the beginnings of respect. She thought about it as she watched Owen and Beru, smiling and laughing together and having whispered conversations about their future when the family gathered underground for the evening.

Leia thought about it the day she saw raiders in the distance and urged Shmi back into the house with a level of panic that thoroughly surprised the princess and nearly brought her to her knees.

â€œItâ€™s alright,â€ Shmi had said once they were inside, Leia braced against the wall and breathing slowly. â€œThey wonâ€™t come after us. Cliegg has agreements with the other farmers. They keep us safe.â€

And Leia was grateful that Shmi hadnâ€™t asked questions and had waited until they were inside to say that.

And she thought about Anakin Skywalker, and how to Shmi, sometimes he was dead.

And she dreamed.

â€œDo you want children?â€ Beru asked one evening, when they were cooking together. â€œYour own family?â€

â€œSomeday,â€ Leia hedged, not really sure she wanted to talk about this, images of a now impossible future stuttering through her mind.

â€œAre you worried about it? That you wonâ€™t find someone to have a family with?â€

It was a natural thought, given how things were going with Owen and Leia could understand how Beru wanted the reassurance and also to share her happiness. All of the Larses had a tendency to want to share everything they had, no matter how small.

Leia was careful when she answered, â€œIâ€™m not really in a place to think about wanting children. They wouldnâ€™t have a very safe life, even if they were an option. But I donâ€™t worry about it. My parents adopted me when they realized they couldnâ€™t have children. I can have a family when the time is right.â€

If that family had been more real just a few short months ago, had taken on specific colors and features for a short time, she didnâ€™t have to think about that right now.

Didnâ€™t have to think that some of those features would once have belonged to Anakin Skywalker. Who Shmi sometimes remembered as one who was dead (and the smoke and the fire and the dark form on the pyre were just a dream, but one she had shared with Luke, so she knew that once it had been real and he had seen it and always remembered).

Leia remembered, and swallowed tears of rage over what had been stolen.

(Every day when she woke up, she still couldnâ€™t feel his heartbeat or that warm ethereal glow.)

The warmth of a home surrounded her and Leia couldnâ€™t accept it. The peace of the desert enveloped her, day after day as she moved from working in the house on menial tasks the Larses thought she could handle to more complicated ones as they realized that yes, in fact, she really was a quick learner.

Nothingness for miles and miles around nothing. Nothing but sun and sand and sun and hot wind for the day and chill gusts in the night. Nothing but occasional tuskens, infrequent jawas, and dozens of bizarre forms of resilient desert life. Whomp rats and banthas andâ€”

One day, as they had been moving along between the vaporators, a cry had echoed faintly across the desert. And when Leia had searched across the desert and found nothing, Owen had whispered, with something between awe and fear, â€œKrayt dragon. Must be hunting.â€

Leia remembered that cry. It was a song in her heart that she just kept singing, over and over, as the days passed by.

â€œThank you for helping us like this,â€ Shmi said one day as they were out gathering mushrooms before the suns got too high. â€œIt would have been natural if you had just left. Not many people want to work out on the farms. Especiallyâ€¦ for as little as weâ€™ve been offering.â€

Just room and board and no questions asked that she couldnâ€™t refuse to answer if the grief was too much (at least that was the excuse, because more than grief it was often that there just wasnâ€™t a safe answer).

â€œI needed space,â€ Leia answered. â€œTo think about where Iâ€™m going next. This was as good a place to start as any. Youâ€™ve been very gracious, letting me stay this long. Iâ€¦ I want to pay you back.â€

That earned a soft smile. â€œYou have.â€

â€œI think Iâ€™ve paid Cliegg. But not you.â€

And for a moment, Shmiâ€™s expression sharpened. She breathed deeply, once, twice. Leia didnâ€™t move, didnâ€™t blink. Willed the woman who would have been her grandmother to understand without any words between them at all.

Shmi looked away, shaking. â€œI donâ€™t need anything. Iâ€™ve been very blessed. My child is safe, my family is free, and I am not a slave. I have everything I wanted.â€

â€œExcept your son,â€ Leia said softly. â€œExcept Anakin.â€

â€œI love Owen,â€ Shmi answered, meeting Leiaâ€™s eyes again. â€œAnd dear Beru. They are my children.â€

â€œSo is Anakin.â€

The conversation stopped, but it hadnâ€™t ended.

â€œIâ€™m thinking it will be time for me to leave soon,â€ Leia announced at dinner a few days later. Beru looked the most disappointed, but Owen seemed sorry to hear it and Clieggâ€™s face took on the gruff edge that said he didnâ€™t like what heâ€™d just heard.

â€œWhat, before the harvest?â€ he demanded.

Leia hesitated, then nodded. â€œYes. It needs to be soon. Iâ€™ve got an idea now of where Iâ€™m going, and Iâ€™ll need to get there quickly, before I miss any more opportunities.â€

â€œWhere are you going?â€ Shmi asked, and Leia hoped no one noticed that the older woman had hesitated.

â€œOff planet. Thereâ€™s someâ€¦ government work that Iâ€™d like to do, but Iâ€™ll need to be closer to the core worlds. The news thatâ€™s trickling out here says civil war is a possibility, and Iâ€™d like to help try and prevent that.â€

It had been a little while since sheâ€™d seen Cliegg so patently skeptical, but it was nice to know the expression hadnâ€™t changed much. And in the stillness of the moment, Leia thought she might be able to feel a bit of the concerned disappointment as well. â€œGovernment affairs? No use getting involved in that business. You need money, and lots of it, to have a voice if you donâ€™t have the connections born into your planet and family name. Foolâ€™s errand, for someone who was making a new start and had to pick this planet.â€

â€œIâ€™d still like to try,â€ Leia countered, biting back the desire to list off her years of experience and knowledge that would give her no small edge as she creeped back into that world.

And it was time. What little news she had been able to glean from the Larsâ€™s small network and her rough memory of pre-empire dates, the Clone Wars were fast approaching. Which meant it was high time to find Anakin and see if she could right his wrongs. Before they had even happened.

Please, before any of them had really happened. She had no idea all the things that Darth Vader may have ever done. As a Jedi or Sith.

â€œWhat exactly do you plan to try?â€ Cliegg pressed, and Leia knew she didnâ€™t really want to get into this conversation.

â€œThere are more than a few planets that are probably working on negotiations. Iâ€™m sure thereâ€™s something that I can help with.â€

She tried to say it with the confidence of a seasoned negotiator and politician, but uncertainty crept in and lingered. Leia did have plenty of experience, for all the good it had done her the past few years, putting out fires across that galaxy and dragging planets back into the New Republic, only to watch other conflicts arise and old allies turn away, shaking their heads and saying maybe later. When things were more settled. When they had everything in line.

Looking back, Leia couldnâ€™t remember not hating every single minute of it from the moment she stepped off of Endor and into that new, fledgling world.

Even before it had taken her family away from her.

â€œDo you know where youâ€™ll be heading first?â€ Beru asked, breaking a slightly awkward silence.

Leia smiled. â€œMos Eisley first, I think,â€ she answered, ignoring Owen as he choked on his food. â€œIâ€™ll need passage and itâ€™s the closest spaceport.â€

â€œAnd the most dangerous,â€ Cliegg growled.

Which was not technically true. Leia had seen plenty of spaceports in her time, and while Mos Eisley was certainly one of the dirty, smuggling heavy ones, it was far from being the most dangerous. Smugglers could be bought. The Emperorâ€™s Imperial troops had had a tendency to love pain more than money. Or to take cash without really being bought.

â€œI can handle myself,â€ Leia retorted with more confidence in that statement than she had managed for her political skills. â€œIâ€™m used to that sort. I know how they do business, and I know how to deal with it.â€

Her hand had found her blaster at her hip, the last remnant of her old life besides the clothes she had come in that she still had. Han had given it to her, had picked it out specially to fit her hand, had practiced with her until sheâ€™d been able draw while firing as he so often had.

It made her burn to even think about it, but she could use it.

She already had.

â€œYou wonâ€™t earn any favors by causing trouble,â€ Cliegg seemed even more determined than before. â€œStay here the rest of the year, finish the harvest with us. Weâ€™ll take you in with us and you can book passage when you have real money to barter with.â€

It was tempting. Leia had no material wealth to her name, and she couldnâ€™t afford to sell her blaster (not in the least because she was pretty sure this model couldnâ€™t possibly exist yet), not if it was going to be her leverage in a port of smugglers and bounty hunters.

But a sense of urgency had been growing day by day, swelling in Leiaâ€™s chest. It almost didnâ€™t leave room for the pain her grief brought, it was so consuming. She didnâ€™t have time to wait anymore. This would be her last night. She was sure of it.

Shaking her head, Leia managed, â€œI appreciate it, but itâ€™s time. Iâ€¦ donâ€™t know how to explain it, but if I donâ€™t leave now I know Iâ€™ll lose the chance to do what I need to the most. Iâ€™ve got my feet under me now, and I know I have all of you to thank for it.â€

Cliegg held her gaze as Leia said the words, and a little of the gruffness left him. â€œWeâ€™d be happy to keep you. You do good work.â€

â€œI hope so,â€ was her immediate response. â€œAnd I hope the Republic thinks so too.â€

All that earned was a humph, but Leia accepted it with a smile. Maybe she could still negotiate with stubborn, irascible people.

But now would be the really tricky part.

Summoning all her courage (and drawing on the pressure in her chest that suddenly was almost threatening to explode), Leia turned to Shmi and asked, â€œI was wondering if you'd like to come with me.â€

Dead silence. Everything frozen in place, completely still. In that silence Leia was almost certain she heard Shmiâ€™s heart stop, as Beruâ€™s and Owenâ€™s started racing. Leia knew her own heart was pounding in her chest, not fast but heavy and deliberate. She felt the blood moving through her veins, felt something tightening over her skin, felt the world slowly slipping a little away, as if she was almost watching herself and the others at the table with outside eyes.

Shmiâ€™s heart stuttering into a beat again.

Clieggâ€™s breathing going in and out in two quick, sharp hisses.

Her own eyes blinking once, twice, while her gaze was unflinching.

â€œIâ€™ll probably end up going to Coruscant,â€ she felt her mouth say, almost as if it was someone else speaking the words. Or as if she was parroting what someone had whispered in her ears. â€œThe Jedi temple is there. You might see Anakin.â€

It was cheating. Leia knew it. But she wasn't fighting fair. Hadn't since her first act of espionage. Since that blast of green energy and the death of Alderaan. Since Luke and Han and Chewie and Artoo had disappeared in a wave of heat and pressure, obliterated beyond recognition, beyond existence. Since that bright and shining light had been ripped out of her heart.

â€œDo whatever is necessary. And donâ€™t look back.â€

Since sheâ€™d looked into the darkness and seen her own pain reflected in a strangerâ€™s eyes. We failed them. All of them. And there is no going back. It canâ€™t be undone.

Not without a price.

He had paid it. She had accepted it. Now was the time to act on it.

â€œShmi?â€

There was no need to press the point, Leia knew. From the moment she said the words, she knew her once grandmother had lost the will to fight. All that was left was the longing. Taking a deep breath, Shmi barely managed, â€œI donâ€™t think itâ€™s fair that I leave before the harvest. Perhaps another time, if you ever come backâ€”â€œ

â€œDonâ€™t be ridiculous.â€ Clieggâ€™s words were sharp and his tone was frighteningly flat. But Leia turned to him, ready to face anything he threw at them. Except for what he actually said. â€œTake the protocol droid with you. Maybe Anakin can fix him so heâ€™s less obnoxious.â€

There was another silence, just as deep but less distant than the last. Leia blinked twice more, felt everyone at the table make a sharp intake of breath.

â€œWhat?â€ Shmi managed to speak first. â€œClieggâ€”â€œ

â€œDonâ€™t argue,â€ he growled. â€œI wonâ€™t change my mind about it. We always said those Jedi should have taken you with them. Nowâ€™s your chance, and youâ€™ll take it.â€

â€œBut you needâ€”â€œ Shmi began.

â€œOne less set of hands wonâ€™t ruin the harvest,â€ he grumbled, shoving food into his mouth and quickly swallowing it. â€œYou always said youâ€™d go if you had the chance. We both knew it. Leia says sheâ€™ll take you, and crazy as she is, I think sheâ€™ll make it. So go.â€

Blinking furiously, Shmi reached across the table and placed her hand over her husbandâ€™s. â€œIâ€”I can wait. Iâ€™m sure Leia would be willing to come back. Sometime later.â€

Willing, yes. But now was the moment and Leia was grateful when Cliegg looked up, met his wifeâ€™s eyes and said, â€œBut sheâ€™s here now, and you can go this time.â€ A quick breath, and then, â€œDonâ€™t make us watch you carry that regret. Youâ€™ve never given us the others, no matter how often we wouldâ€™ve taken them.â€

Apparently Shmi didnâ€™t have any response for that. Her hand clenched into a fist and she took a deep breath. â€œI do want to see him again,â€ she admitted in a hushed voice. â€œI really do.â€

Something eased, not just in the room but in Leiaâ€™s heart. â€œThen weâ€™ll make that happen,â€ she promised, feeling the comforting weight of those words as she spoke them.

Shmi smiled, and Leia saw hope in her eyes.

Chapter End Notes

Thank you to everyone who commented, especially who left suggestions or asked questions. It helps. Hope you enjoyed chapter two.

Sky Walkers

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

It wasnâ€™t that she hated space ports, but Leia never really felt safe in them anymore. Especially not one with this many bounty hunters roaming around.

â€œIs everything alright?â€ Shmi asked, stepping closer as she did and eyeing a cluster of traders with the mistrust of a woman who had once walked very similar streets as a slave.

â€œYes,â€ Leia answered, willing it to be true as she tried to tune out the instinctual itch that came in a crowd with this many eyes on her (and maybe some of that tension had always been her sensitivity to the Force). â€œIâ€™m just trying to decide where to start.â€

She was also regretting sending Owen back so quickly. They had said all their goodbyes at the farm that morning and he was needed for work back home, but it would have been nice to have another warm body to stand behind her, creating a safe space there (a space a Wookiee had once filled, and no one else would ever quite manage), and looking a bit more imposing than just Leia could.

â€œThreepio,â€ she called, wishing the protocol droid had a bit more mobility to him, â€œdonâ€™t fall too far behind.â€

â€œOf course, Mistress Leia. I am right behind you,â€ the faithful droid answered, shuffling as fast as his stiff metal legs would allow. They needed to get him off this planet. The sand slowed him down just enough extra that he was practically useless.

An arm linked with Leiaâ€™s and she looked over at Shmi, who half whispered, â€œWhat exactly are we looking for?â€

Leia bit back her immediate response (a miracle), and smiled as confidently as she could. â€œWeâ€™ll know it when we see it.â€

Which didnâ€™t seem to inspire much confidence in Shmi, but the older woman just nodded and Leia thanked the stars for a grandmother who understood that some things just couldnâ€™t be explained out loud. Like the conviction that Leia had that they were, in fact, in the right place right now. They just needed to be patient. And keep looking.

Probably.

â€œYou lost?â€ an overly helpful pilot asked them at one point, eyeing them in a way that made Leia immediately defensive.

But she just gave him a look (perfected on Han, in a very different time), and he instinctively took a half step back even before she had vocalized her clear and concise, â€œNo.â€

There were two other times that people almost approached, smiles broad and overeager. Leia kept her hand on her blaster, her eyes narrow, and her nose just a little in the air.

Thankfully, that at least seemed to work. The patience was a more dubious pursuit.

She was starting to severely question her gut instincts when some anxious chatter reached her ears.

A party of twelve or so rodians had caucused near the entrance of a docking bay, gesticulating and making a number of high pitched tones in their native tongue that made Leia hesitate instead of passing them.

â€œWhat is it?â€ Shmi asked, at almost the same moment Leia turned back to Threepio and asked, â€œWhat are they saying?â€

There was the familiar slight head cock and arm twitch as Threepio answered, â€œWell, it seems they are having trouble with the pilot of their ship. Apparently he doesnâ€™t want to take them any further, not at the rate theyâ€™re offering to pay him. How unfortunate. Do we have enough money to hire a pilot?â€

Instead of answering Leia moved forward, slipping away from Shmi and asking Threepio to introduce them. He tapped one of the rodians on the shoulder and made a series of noises Leia hoped were the proper greeting for this kind of circumstance.

The rodian responded and Threepio turned to Leia to relay, â€œThey offer their greetings and want to know what we would like from them. He also,â€ Threepio hesitated, â€œmade a rather rude and idiomatic statement about this being a public street and being allowed to stand here.â€

Smiling, Leia turned to face the rodians and started speaking, pausing every so often so that Threepio could translate. â€œWe got the impression you could use some help getting off planet and thought weâ€™d offer our services. Where are you heading?â€

â€œHerdessa,â€ Threepio informed her when one of them answered. â€œThey thought about stopping here rather than continuing, but apparently there isnâ€™t much work beyond bounty hunting, at least around here. Which they areâ€¦ not pleased about. What help are you offering? Work?â€

â€œA pilot,â€ Leia said, waiting for Threepio to translate and for the group to react. A few heads turned in her direction, and she felt something like the slight lightening of a pressure.

â€œHe says they have a pilot,â€ Threepio translated after a moment, â€œbut we know that canâ€™t be true, because we just heard them say they didnâ€™t.â€

Leia ignored the worry and said, â€œIâ€™m a better pilot. And you donâ€™t have to pay me.â€ There was a skeptical tittering as Threepio translated this before Leia added, â€œI would just want passage for me and for my companions, the woman and the droid. We want to get off of this rock as much as you do.â€

It was humiliating how long the crowd debated, Leia realized after the first couple of minutes. No one had ever questioned Luke or Han if they could fly a ship (and that sharp pain of regret wouldnâ€™t show on her face, she was at least a good enough diplomat to avoid that).

â€œThey would like to leave immediately,â€ Threepio told her, when the leader of the small group turned to the droid with an answer. â€œIf you really can get them to Herdessa.â€

â€œJust show me the ship,â€ Leia said, still projecting that unnatural certainty. The ships here might be older, but sheâ€™d been taught a thing or two about flying in the past few years. Enough to at least make the jumps necessary to get them to Herdessa. There would be more work options there for everyone, including Leia and Shmi.

Hopefully she wouldnâ€™t have to resort to bounty hunting. It was technically an option, but Leia wasnâ€™t sure her traveling companions would really like it.

The Millennium Falcon had always been the junkiest ship Leia had flown in. Until this moment. It was with more than a bit of bitterness that Leia realized her family and friends and even the rebellion had spoiled her with what to expect from any kind of transport ship. Or freighter.

The ship in front of her was actual junk. Probably literally pulled from some sort of scrap heap somewhere and cobbled together with desperation as much as skill. She could understand the rodiansâ€™ sudden transition of loyalty from their old pilot, and willingness to try Leiaâ€™s skills. These people had almost nothing left. And they would be damn lucky if they could even scrap this mess wherever they landed.

â€œI donâ€™t think,â€ Shmi said very quietly, â€œand Iâ€™m not an expert of course. But I donâ€™t think it should look like that.â€

â€œItâ€™s space worthy,â€ Leia answered. â€œIf theyâ€™ve made it this far. Threepio said they came from Khubeaie. Thatâ€™s not a nothing trip. We should be able to make it to Herdessa, no problem.â€

â€œAnd from there?â€ Shmi prodded. â€œThat wasnâ€™t our actual destination.â€

Facing the reality that no one here (except possibly, maybe C-3PO) thought she was capable of doing any of this, the once princess squared her shoulders and admitted, â€œIt may take some time. But Herdessa will be a safer, easier place to work with. To get to where we really want.â€ She could try and look up old (or rather, at this point very young) contacts, people that had soft enough hearts Leia could spin some sort of lie (or even truth) and get them help. â€œItâ€™s also a refugee stop, which is probably why the Rodians are heading there. We can use this.â€

And they could. The controls were less clunky than she had been expecting, more familiar than she would have thought. She asked a couple questions to confirm a few things, made sure they had completely refueled the ship, and winced when the leader admitted through Threepio that with Hutt â€œtaxesâ€ they hadnâ€™t quite managed to get all the resources that they wanted.

â€œRight,â€ Leia grumbled as she turned back to the console, fingers gripping the controls to prevent her from rubbing her head. â€œHutts are here.â€

And damn that fat worm and his putrid breath and stubby, slimy hands and bulbous, flat face. That wriggling, slithering blob had the audacity to be alive again after all the work she had done to remove his gross presence (and the flood of emotions and memories that came with the rancor and the sarlacc, and Han frozen against the wall, and having to rely on Lando after his betrayal, and the dark and mysterious Luke that had led them after Bespin because of Vader, and all that he had done and stolen), and Leia wasnâ€™t ready to forgive that.

She would be back. If only to finish that.

â€œYou look comfortable there,â€ Threepio said, on behalf of Coq Zita, the rodian answering Leiaâ€™s questions. â€œYouâ€™ve done this before?â€

â€œA thousand times,â€ Leia answered, and the slight snout twitch that Leia recognized as a rodian smile made a brief appearance. Coq spoke a bit more and Threepio added, â€œHe says they like you much more than their last pilot. Youâ€™re much prettier. And more polite.â€

â€œIâ€™ll bet I smell better too,â€ Leia smirked, and was a little embarrassed when the protocol droid decided to translate that too.

â€œHe says most certainly, yes,â€ Threepio informed her after Coq had laughed. â€œAnd I think it was rather impertinent of him.â€

Leia laughed too, started preparing the ship and setting the nav computer, and two hours later (because a host of other, Hutt marked ships got clearance first) they were off.

Shmi joined Leia in the cock pit after a few hours. Impressed that it had taken that long for Shmi to lose interest in their traveling companions, Leia didnâ€™t say much when the woman came and leaned up behind the pilotâ€™s seat, staring out the window at the blue white stream of hyperspace.

A half glance back confirmed to Leia that Shmiâ€™s eyes were wide, her lips pressed firmly together.

â€œHow fast are we going?â€ she eventually asked.

â€œReally fast,â€ Leia answered, taking a more relaxed posture, letting her hands rest on the controls without gripping them. â€œThatâ€™s why the ship is doing most of the work at this point.â€

Moving her hand to one of Leiaâ€™s shoulders, Shmi gripped tight. â€œItâ€™s wonderful. And terrifying.â€

â€œCan you imagine Anakin flying in this?â€ Leia asked, and noticed that Shmiâ€™s grip eased.

She chuckled. â€œOh yes. Yes, he would love it.â€

â€œIâ€™m sure he would.â€ After another silence, Leia volunteered, â€œI actually prefer the parts of travel outside of hyperspace. Itâ€™s beautiful, and you get a real sense of how large the galaxy really is. How much life and light are out there.â€

Nights on Tatooine had been hard, but when she couldnâ€™t sleep Leia had snuck out to the open courtyard, braved the chill, and laid back and stared up into the night sky, trying to remember the location of all her favorite stars (and relish that within the orbit of that sun, Alderaan was still alive). The little dots of light had been a soothing blanket that covered a multitude of hurts.

She loved the coldness and the distance of those lights. And the darkness that held the stars and kept them hung in the sky.

â€œI donâ€™t know if I was meant for this,â€ Shmi admitted softly, and Leia didnâ€™t answer right away.

â€œBiologically speaking, youâ€™re not. No life form Iâ€™ve ever met was. Thatâ€™s probably whatâ€™s so terrifying about this. Your body knows itâ€™s not supposed to be here. You just have to convince it to suck it up and fly anyway.â€

The feeling of Shmi trying to conquer her fear rolled around the small room. Leia recognized it and trusted that she knew what it was. Reading Shmi was somehow easier than reading other people. It came more naturally and created a solid baseline for Leia to gauge whether other things that she was feeling were from herself, or were an impression left by movement in the Force.

â€œI think I will go back and sit with the others,â€ Shmi said. â€œThank you, for sharing this.â€

Leia nodded, turning her attention to the screens in front of her. â€œAny time.â€

The door hissed open and closed and Leia was left alone again, watching the blurred movement of space. Leaning back in her seat, she tried again to figure out what Luke had meant about clearing her mind, tickled by a sensation like stars flickering in darkness that skimmed over her skin.

It was the rough equivalent of the middle of the night, and Leia was starting to regret not taking Coq up on covering her for a bit to let her catch some sleep before she would be needed at the controls to handle landing. With the interplanetary time differences, Leia knew they would be setting down mid-morning on Herdessa, for all that it would still feel like the dark abyss before the crack of dawn.

Sheâ€™d thought she could handle the sleep deprivation. Sheâ€™d managed it before.

Sheâ€™d forgotten about waking dreams.

Tapping into the well of energy that never seemed quite depleted, one that she had drawn from over and over again across the years (and it was so strange, that she had always had this access to the Force, and had never realized what it really was) kept Leia conscious. But it also triggered other senses.

Like visions of the past.

Here, in the cold light of space, her mind took her to a different ship. One that had often felt more like home than land had over the past five years. She could see the wookiee in the cockpit, trying to hold the ship steady while also maneuvering around heavy fire from a half dozen enemy cruisers. Could feel the slight rocking from the guns that were being manned down the hall. Could hear Chewieâ€™s final roar and a screeching beep from a droid behind her as two torpedoes in a large cluster made it past the dead eye shooting coming from the Falconâ€™s manned guns.

She saw fire.

She saw nothing.

She saw space.

â€œMistress Leia?â€ a metallic voice chimed and Leia jumped slightly in her seat. â€œOur passengers are wondering how close we are to landing, to see if they should wake the children up.â€

â€œForty minutes,â€ Leia answered, having checked the screen as Threepio had started talking. â€œThey probably donâ€™t need to wake anyone yet. Iâ€™d say wait another thirty minutes.â€

â€œOf course, Mistress Leia. Thank you.â€

Collapsing back in the chair, Leia allowed herself several deep breaths before she tried closing her eyes, not sure what would be behind them.

Fire again, as it turned out.

Instead of turning away from it, she tried to face it. To see past the bright heat to the crumbling ship and disintegrating form she had been watching before.

She could almost see it this time, she thought.

â€œJust like hell,â€ she muttered to herself. Then thought of Shmi and snorted. â€œOr close enough.â€

â€œAnd here I was thinking weâ€™d finally escaped it,â€ came an amused reply.

Leia turned and gave a tired smile to her companion. â€œApparently,â€ she answered with more heaviness than she had intended, â€œsometimes we just get to carry it with us.â€

The look Shmi gave her was a little too understanding and Leia turned back to the controls to avoid as much of it as she could. Thankfully, when she spoke all Shmi said was, â€Threepio says weâ€™re landing soon.â€

â€œThirty minutes out,â€ Leia confirmed.

When it was clear the younger woman wasnâ€™t adding anything else, Shmi asked, â€œWhat is it like, landing on a new planet? On Herdessa?â€

It took Leia a moment to find an answer. â€œLanding on a new planet isâ€¦ always nerve-racking,â€ she eventually managed. â€œEven when you think you know what to expect. Herdessaâ€¦ Iâ€™ve only been a few times, very briefly. But weâ€™ll be landing in the capital, which is where I visited. It will be busy, packed with people. And itâ€™s an industrial planet, so expect lots of buildings and droids and smog.â€

â€œSmog?â€ Shmi asked, and Leia had to think about that one too.

â€œDark smoke, but from industrial burning, not just simple fires. Not quite clouds, but it can make the air,â€ she struggled for a word that would make sense to someone from a completely arid environment, and settled on, â€œthicker. Or something.â€

â€œIt will probably be easier to explain once I see it,â€ Shmi replied with a grateful smile. Then she frowned again. â€œI donâ€™t have any papers. Cliegg only had my slave note, and I didnâ€™t think that would be of much use.â€

Nodding, Leia turned half her attention to the ship and dropping them out of hyperspace. â€œIt wouldnâ€™t be any use. Weâ€™ll be fine without papers though. Plenty of people travel without them. The Rodians have some, but they know what kind of work they are looking for, and what quarter they want to settle in. Papers help with that. Weâ€™re a bit moreâ€”Well, weâ€™re improvising. If we stay here long enough, we could look into getting papers, probably claiming some sort of refugee status. But if not, we can just pick them up on the next planet, or whenever we get to Coruscant.â€

â€œWe arenâ€™tâ€”Will there be a lot more planets? Before Coruscant?â€

Leia tried to sound as soothing as possible. â€œI doubt it. Herdessa is more likely to have ships heading straight there. I might be able to offer my services as a pilot again, but more likely weâ€™ll stay here for a bit, earn some money with odd jobs, and then pay for passage with someone else. Maybe at discount, if we volunteer to work on whatever craft we find.â€

â€œIâ€”I donâ€™t know much about ships. Anakin did. He was very good with them. I only know farm equipment. And housekeeping.â€

â€œYouâ€™d be surprised at how much you already know, just from the farm equipment,â€ Leia said, making sure to meet Shmiâ€™s eyes for a moment. â€œAnd what did you do forâ€”before Cliegg and the farm?â€

There was a brief pause before Shmi answered, â€œNot much. Watto had much more use for Anakin. I cared for his home, cooked his meals. Shopped sometimes, or rummaged for spare parts that Anakin could repair for him. Iâ€™mâ€”Iâ€™m not lazy. I just donâ€™t know that I know anything that will be usefulâ€¦ here.â€

As Shmi said the words they softened, as if the growing image of the planet outside had absorbed them. Thick, brown grey tufts hovered where clouds would normally be, over the massive cities that sprawled so heavily they could be seen in basic outline, even from this distance.

More grey than Coruscant, Leia thought. Dirtier, even from this height.

â€œIâ€™m sure weâ€™ll find something,â€ she managed to say after a few moments. â€œIt wonâ€™t be glamorous, but weâ€™ll make do.â€

â€œI donâ€™t think I belong anywhere glamorous,â€ Shmi retorted with a chuckle (and maybe a hint of bitterness, coloring the edges of it). â€œSo this will probably suit me just fine.â€

Rather than suggesting she was wrong, Leia focused on their flight, trying to ease the ship through the atmosphere.

There were a disturbing number of creaks and groans as they descended, but the ship held together and the systems all reported that everything onboard was still safe. Following directions from the landing operators, they eventually managed to touch down, almost smoothly.

â€œVery well done,â€ Shmi said with a smile. â€œWeâ€™ve made it.â€

Two hours later, things were looking worse, not better.

It had taken forever for a deck official to come to clear them, and nowâ€¦

â€œCoq Zita does not understand what the problem is,â€ C-3PO repeated probably for the tenth time. â€œTheir papers are in order and their ship has landed in an appropriate zone. Could you please clarify?â€

After a few frustrated snorts and growls, there was a mostly articulate reply from the official processing their paperwork, â€œItâ€™s not Coq thatâ€™s the problem. Not his people either. Itâ€™s the pilot.â€

â€œOh,â€ Threepio said cheerfully. â€œWell, why didnâ€™t you say so before?â€ He turned to Leia. â€œMistress Leia, it seems that weâ€”â€œ

â€œI heard him,â€ she said before he could get too excited. â€œWhatâ€™s the problem? We arenâ€™t asking to be processed with the rodians. Weâ€™re a separate group, who happen to have been traveling on the same vessel.â€

â€œNo pilotâ€™s license,â€ the official huffed.

Leia raised her eyebrows. â€œNo local one? Of course not. This is my first time on planet. And they arenâ€™t required on Tatooine.â€

Possibly a lie, but she was pretty sure it would stick. A confident posture and authoritative voice went a long way. And then there was the natural Skywalker charisma. Not something she had used to assume she had, but nowâ€¦

Well, something was unnatural about her. There was no denying it.

And it appeared to be working. â€œWell, I supposeâ€”I guessâ€”Thatâ€™s fine then. But no more flying here. And you canâ€™t be processed with them. You donâ€™t have papers.â€ He nodded to Coq and the other Rodians.

â€œFair enough,â€ Leia smiled. â€œWeâ€™ll stand over here while you finish. Threepio, can you please explain the delay to our friends?â€

The protocol droid was more than happy to continue to help, and Leia stood with Shmi, watching from a short distance.

Hoping to prepare them for whatever was ahead (this would be trickier than she had thought) Leia took the moment to close her eyes and try again to quiet her mind.

As usual, it didnâ€™t really work. The more she tried to reach out, the noisier everything became around her. It ebbed and flowed in moments of perfect silence (as if she had shut off all her senses and pushed everything away) and crushing awareness, where she was pulled in a thousand different directions by random scents, sounds, and sensations across her skin.

Trying to sort through it, Leia kept getting the impression of something glittering right behind her. She turned, opening her eyes and scanning the other landing platforms. Most of the ships nearby were only in slightly better condition than hers, but not too far away was a bright, shining silver vessel.

Leia blinked. It looked likeâ€¦ it looked like the government ship Senator Pooja Naberrie had always flown in.

Almost without thinking, her feet started carrying her away from their passengers and ship and toward this new, bright spot in her vision. She made it about ten steps before she felt someone catch her arm and turned to see Shmiâ€™s confused face.

â€œThereâ€™s something over there, I think,â€ Leia tried to explain. â€œIâ€™m just going to look for a bit.â€

Crossing two other landing platforms and dodging the irritated crew members, Leia made it within throwing distance of the ship, Shmi trailing slightly behind her, before she came to a stop, suddenly leery.

Something tightened like a vice in her chest and her head snapped to the right, finding a group moving towards the ship.

â€œSenator, please.â€ The voice was unfamiliar, but the vice feeling tightened even further as Leia heard it. â€œI know this is a difficult time for youâ€”â€œ

â€œSenator Amidala, I agree with you,â€ came a slightly harried reply. â€œThere is a growing crisis and I want to help. But the Senate isnâ€™t providing the funding necessary for us to keep taking on more and more refugees, and I donâ€™t know how long we can keep making things work like this.â€

â€œShea,â€ Senator Amidala had stopped walking and placed a hand on the other womanâ€™s arm, â€œI know how difficult this is. Iâ€™m willing to do everything I can to make it happen. Please, just tell me youâ€™re willing to help.â€

There was a brief silence and a long, exasperated sigh from the other Senator. â€œI want to, Senator Amidala. You know I do. But I have my people to consider, as you have yours.â€

There was a flash of hurt on Senator Amidalaâ€™s face (and Leia might be having a slight panic attack because she was looking at the heroic, beautiful, intelligent, courageous Senator PadmÃ© Amidala of Naboo) and Leia felt a stabbing sensation right through the tension that was grabbing her heart. The sensation of betrayal cut deep and even with her extraordinarily limited experience, Leia knew this was the Force.

An awkward silence was growing, and Leia was as surprised as anyone when Shmi stepped forward and in a tentative voice called out, â€œPadmÃ©?â€

The full attention of the senatorial party was now directed their way, and Leia watched in fascination and something close to envy as Senator Amidalaâ€™s expression moved from confusion to complete surprise.

â€œShmi? Shmi Skywalker?â€ The senator crossed the distance between them with quick strides, coming right up to the older woman and looking into her face with delight and wonder. â€œOh. Oh itâ€™s so good to see you again!â€

â€œYes, of course,â€ Shmiâ€™s hands fluttered a bit. â€œI didnâ€™t thinkâ€”I wasnâ€™t expecting to seeâ€¦â€

Senator Amidala frowned, â€œWhat are you doing here?â€

There was a slight hesitation before Shmi answered, â€œWeâ€”We were just stopping here. On our way to Coruscantâ€¦â€

â€œWe?â€ Senator Amidala turned to look at Leia, and the poor one-time princess immediately forgot how to speak. Or think. Or breathe.

â€œThis is my friend,â€ Shmi answered when it became clear that Leia wouldnâ€™t. â€œLeia offered to travel with me, to make sure I was safe.â€

The smile Leia got from the senator was a bit hesitant, but thankfully some part of Leiaâ€™s brain had reengaged (and how in the hell that was Tatooine did Shmi Skywalker know Senator PadmÃ© Amidala of Naboo), and she was able to smile in response and execute something more formal than a nod, but not quite as proper as a bow.

â€œSenator,â€ she managed to say without stuttering. â€œItâ€™s a pleasure to meet you.â€

The sincerity echoing from each word earned the senatorâ€™s smile and Leia felt like she had been exposed to a very focused shaft of sunlight.

The vice-like grip on her heart somehow tightened even more and she desperately hoped she wouldnâ€™t have to speak again until it let up. She wasnâ€™t entirely sure she could.

â€œI canâ€™t believe it,â€ Senator Amidala said, turning back to Shmi. â€œI never would have guessed, suspectedâ€”â€œ

Shmi folded her arms, shaking her head. â€œIt was a surprise for me too. Being hereâ€¦ itâ€™s like a dream.â€

Senator Amidala opened her mouth for a moment, then hesitated. Leia was stunned to see the senator looked a bit ashamed. â€œIâ€”I owe you an apology.â€

Shmi blinked several times. â€œFor what?â€

The senator met Shmiâ€™s eyes, her own a little moist as she said, â€œIâ€¦ I didnâ€™t come back for you. I should have. Iâ€™m so sorry.â€

A taste of longing and regret filtered through the pain that was still constricting in Leiaâ€™s chest for a moment before Shmi shook her head. â€œWe had no deal. You made me no promise. Itâ€™sâ€”Itâ€™s alright.â€

â€œI still should have come back. It would have been right.â€

Voice cracking Shmi said, â€œI justâ€¦ wanted to see my son. To see Anakin again. Thatâ€™s all.â€

There was a pause while Senator Amidala took a deep breath. â€œI canâ€”â€œ

â€œSenator Amidala?â€ The Herdessa senator approached along with two of Senator Amidalaâ€™s guard and an all too familiar blue and white astromech (and Leiaâ€™s clenched heart screamed and she heard a warning beep and saw fire and nothing), all eyeing the two strangers with some concern. â€œAre these friends of yours?â€

Before the Naboo senator could answer, there was a shout of, â€œOi, you two! You havenâ€™t been processed yet!â€

The official from the other landing pad was storming over, fur bristling while C-3PO scuttled along behind him. Leia heard an expressive blat from Artoo, but couldnâ€™t decide who it might be directed at.

Coming to a halt a couple paces away from Shmi and Leia, the landing official began, â€œAnd just what do you thinkâ€”â€œ

â€œTheyâ€™re with me,â€ Senator Amidala said, moving Shmi aside slightly and stepping forward. â€œIâ€™m Senator Amidala, of the Naboo.â€

â€œCoo, they didnâ€™t come with you, my lady,â€ the official said, narrowing his eyes. â€œCame in just now with that pack of new rodians. Looking for work, they are, and not likely to find it here, I tell you. And this one,â€ he pointed a finger at Leia, â€œnot even licensed to fly.â€

â€œHere,â€ Leia corrected, voice strained more by the bizarre and heavy sensations in her chest than actual anger. â€œIâ€™m not licensed to continue flying here. We already discussed this.â€

â€œWell, sheâ€™s not going to keep flying here,â€ Senator Amidala intervened. â€œSheâ€™s coming with me. And our pilots are licensed to fly anywhere in the Republic.â€

The official seemed slightly appeased by this, but seemed to realize he had also been derailed from a point. Before he could find it again, the Herdessa senator added, â€œThey do still need to be processed though. And they shouldnâ€™t have left their landing platform until they were.â€

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ Leia managed to get out in a mostly normal voice. â€œThat was my fault. Of course weâ€™ll go back and finish being processed properly.â€

This mollified the official, but when he continued to grumble as he was retreating Senator Amidala stated, â€œIâ€™m coming too.â€

The grumbling stopped, and the travelers ended up being escorted back to the ramshackle ship (which Leia delightedly and embarrassingly noticed that Senator Amidala eyed with no small amount of horror and scorn) by both senators, two of each of their guard, C-3PO, R2-D2, and someone who was probably the Herdessan senatorâ€™s assistant.

Paperwork finished and ship designated for scrapping, Leia turned back to the task at hand. â€œIâ€™m sorry for the trouble,â€ she directed her words to both senators. â€œThank you for all of your help.â€

â€œWe did nothing,â€ the Herdessan senator said a bit stiffly, watching Leia with more than a little wariness. â€œAll of this was standard procedure.â€

â€œThen Iâ€™m sorry we interrupted your conversation,â€ Leia tried instead.

The senator winced and looked anxiously at Senator Amidala, who was glancing at her colleague out of the corner of her eyes. The Naboo woman eventually sighed. â€œSenator Sadashassa, we both know things canâ€™t continue the way theyâ€™ve been.â€

â€œNo,â€ Senator Sadashassa agreed. â€œBut Iâ€™ve already explained how little there is that I can do to help you. Our cities may not, strictly speaking, be full, but our systems are overrun with people fleeing the increasing conflicts around the outer rim. We canâ€™t process them quickly enough, even if we have the space for them. Eventually.â€

Senator Amidala thought for a moment, fingers touching her chin as she stared at the ground. When she looked up, she smiled. â€œI know. And I know you have reservations because you feel Naboo isnâ€™t doing what it should be to help.â€

â€œI never said that,â€ Senator Sadashassa murmured.

Senator Amidala just kept smiling. â€œDidnâ€™t you? I thought you had, in your own way. No,â€ she raised a hand, â€œdonâ€™t apologize. Youâ€™re right. Iâ€™ve been so busy with work in the senate, I havenâ€™t coordinated enough with the Queen and her council, to make sure that matters are being taken care of properly at home. That weâ€™re setting the right example.â€ Her chin came up. â€œIf we create, and implement, a higher volume refugee program on Naboo and it succeeds, will you agree to be the next site to test it, so that we can recommend it to the senate?â€

Senator Sadashassa smiled, her shoulders relaxing. â€œIâ€™m willing to promise that.â€

A feeling like sunlight rolling off of her, Senator Amidala grinned, â€œThank you, Shea.â€

As the two women bowed and shook hands, Leia felt the vice grip on her heart give one last, horrid squeeze, before the pressure released and she could breathe again. In that moment, as everything inside her expanded, she felt the world almost twist slightly, lurching from where the two senators stood holding hands.

â€œIâ€™m sending you to someone safe. Probably the only one who can help you actually fix everything. Do whatever is necessary.â€

Leia had no idea if this was right or not, but she knew, knew in her bones that now sang with the shifting sands of the desert, in her heart that now filled more space in her chest that it had before, that something had definitely changed.

â€œAnd donâ€™t look back.â€

Chapter End Notes

I like to think that Bail shamelessly encouraged Leia's rebel streak partially accidentally by trying to make sure that she knew every story he could possibly think of about her biological mother. Because even if she couldn't know she was related to PadmÃ©, it would just be such a waste not to tell Leia all the stories.

Leia's greatest dream has secretly always been to meet Senator Amidala. She maybe a little subscribed to the conspiracy that PadmÃ© never really died and was out there, fighting for the rebellion, somewhere.

The Lap of Luxury

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Naboo was green.

It shouldnâ€™t have surprised Leia, but there was something about the greenness that stood out to her as the ship approached the ground. It wasnâ€™t the dark, dusky green of Endorâ€™s moon. It wasâ€”

It was more like the blue touched green of Alderaan. It was rolling hills and hints of mountains, and lakes and rivers that stretched for miles.

â€œIâ€™ve never seen anything like this,â€ Shmi whispered reverently, leaning towards Leia as they both stared out the window. â€œHave you?â€

â€œIâ€”â€œ Leia stumbled (shattered in a bolt of green, blue then black and nothing). â€œYes. Iâ€™ve seen places like this. I love them. Theyâ€™re like home.â€

The words were true, but the last one in particular tasted hollow on her tongue. Acrid and bitter in comparison to the sweet sight of Theed, and the generous senator that was standing beside the pilot, looking back at them and smiling. Senator Amidala murmured something to her guard and with surprisingly quick, strong strides came over to join her guests.

Leia was only a little envious that the senator addressed Shmi first. â€œDo you want to come up a bit more? Thereâ€™s plenty of space. You wonâ€™t distract anyone and the view is lovely.â€

â€œWe noticed,â€ Shmi replied, still giving most of her attention to the view port. â€œIf it isnâ€™t any trouble?â€

â€œNone at all,â€ the senator promised, offering her arm to Shmi and walking her over.

They made their way forward and Leia followed, lingering behind. She heard the metallic scuffle of Threepio coming forward and her lips twitched as he caught his first glimpse of the planet and exclaimed, â€œOh, how marvelous!â€

Shmi and Senator Amidala both turned back with knowing grins, catching the expression on each otherâ€™s faces and chuckling as they turned back to the view. There was a pervasive serenity in the moment, and Leia could see that Shmi was much less anxious about this landing than the previous one.

Which was good, because Leia was more nervous, and doing everything in her power to hide it.

â€œWeâ€™ve got clearance, Senator,â€ the pilot said. â€œWeâ€™ll be docking soon.â€

If it was meant as a suggestion that the passengers should get ready to get off, it was ignored. Senator Amidala thanked him, and pointed out the palace to Shmi as they approached.

â€œAnakin came with me here,â€ the senator was explaining. â€œBefore he went to the temple to train. He, ah, accidentally got stuck in one of the ships and was in the middle of space before anyone could catch him.â€

There was clearly more to the story. Leia saw it more in the faces of the senatorâ€™s guards than heard it in her tone, but it would be worth exploring. For now though, it was just a relief to hear Shmi chuckle ruefully.

â€œHe did always want to be a pilot,â€ she acknowledged. â€œHe always talked about it.â€

â€œThe way he told it, he already was a pilot, even then,â€ PadmÃ© answered with a broad grin.

Sadness struck, vicious and unsuspected. In the calm of that moment, Leia saw another pilot, another child of Tatooine. One who had wanted to be just like his father (â€œIâ€™m a Jedi,â€ he had told her when he had come back from the Death Star, â€œlike you could be.â€), and who had been the galaxyâ€™s greatest pilot those past four years. Brave and strong and full of promise.

Struck down by the horrible remaining fragments of the ruined Empire.

It wasnâ€™t until Threepio said something that Leia realized she was crying.

â€œMistress Leia, are you alright? Is the landing too rough for you?â€

Stepping out of her memories with a force of will she was just starting to master, Leia shook her head and did her best to smile at the two women now looking at her. Shmi at least understood grief that could not be shared, and the senator was polite enough to ignore what wouldnâ€™t be spoken. So when Leia said, â€œNo Threepio. Itâ€™s just the light here. My eyes are adjusting,â€ there werenâ€™t any awkward questions.

Which made Leia grateful.

And sad.

(Theyâ€™d never know him, that bright and shining star in the universe, and all that he had done and become, and all he knew he could be, and she grieved for that, with bitter longing and remorse.)

The pilot announced, â€œHere we are,â€ and the craft glided to a gentle stop, lowering slowly and touching down with only the tiniest of shifts felt on the inside.

â€œWelcome to Naboo,â€ Senator Amidala said, looking first at Shmi and then to Leia. â€œI hope you enjoy it here.â€

â€œWe plan to,â€ Leia managed to answer, blinking a few times to keep any lingering moisture from leaving her eyes. â€œThank you for inviting us.â€

They disembarked without any mishap and with only modestly interrupted fanfare. While the current queen of Naboo was not in attendance, several of her court were, and they were clearly surprised to see that PadmÃ© had arrived with guests. But years of practice and a very natural courtesy took over as they were formally introduced. An amphibious humanoid called Jar Jar Binks was particularly obsequious in his welcome, but it was such a cheerful, honest display that Leia felt only mildly annoyed and partially charmed.

It was Threepioâ€™s comment of, â€œOh dear, youâ€™re not that clumsy fellow, are you? Please donâ€™t get stuck in anything this time,â€ that cemented her opinion.

â€œI'm not clumsy no more,â€ Jar Jar said defensively, and the looks on the faces of everyone else in the room pronounced this to be a complete lie. Leia found herself smiling as she extended her hand to the poor man.

â€œItâ€™s a pleasure to meet you,â€ Leia said, and was not surprised when he took her hand in both of his and shook it very vigorously.

â€œItâ€™s a great great pleasure to meet any friend of the senator!â€ he exclaimed cheerfully, and Leia had to bite back a correction. She glanced a bit nervously at Senator Amidala, who smiled at the exchange.

â€œThank you, Jar Jar,â€ the senatorâ€™s voice had the hint of a laugh in it. â€œIâ€™d like to show them inside now, is that alright?â€

The suggestion was met with true enthusiasm and the whole party made their way out of the large hangar lined in yellow fighters to enter the main part of the palace.

â€œIâ€™ll need to report to the queen immediately,â€ Senator Amidala was explaining to Shmi, guiding the older woman along. â€œWeâ€™ll stop by the senatorâ€™s suite here in the palace and Iâ€™ll leave DormÃ© and CordÃ© with you and Leia. Theyâ€™ll help you get settled.â€

There was the faintest hint of concern as Shmi answered, â€œWeâ€™re staying here?â€

It was probably covering outright panic, and Leia wished she could claim that was a Force reading and not just intimate knowledge of Shmi Skywalker.

â€œJust for a few days,â€ the senator said in a soothing tone. â€œThen Iâ€™ll take you to meet my family. Theyâ€™re outside the capital, so Iâ€™ll need to finish some work here before I go and see them.â€

Shmi nodded, and Leia noticed her hands twitch a few times, but nothing else.

The rooms they were settled in were gorgeous, with high ceilings and luxurious furnishing done in warm, neutral tones and sprinkled with hints of vibrant color. Each room of the suite looked out over a scenic snapshot of the city and sparkling water ways. The large windows did not open, and Leia assumed that meant they were also made with blaster proof glass, given whose suite this was. It was disappointing, she thought there might be a good breeze outside, but the rooms were comfortable enough to make up for it.

"Feel free to pick any of these," CordÃ© said, gesturing to the rooms on the left. "PadmÃ© will be in the one over there, and either DormÃ© or I will be in the one next to her."

That left three rooms to choose from, each with a large bed, plenty of storage space, and a refresher attached. Shmi blinked at all the opulence and eventually walked into the room next to the one Leia chose, as far from the senator as possible.
