Face twisting with guilt, PadmÃ© shook her head. "I can't get them to agree on things they already promised, much less focus on a broader scale of attack. It's a problem that is only getting bigger, and if they would deal with it then it would make these other issues less of a crisis. Better trade routes, more loans through providers who don't have a monopoly on interest rates. But do they listen?"

"No," Leia handed PadmÃ© a cup and made sure the senator actually drank. "Any support?"

"Shea," PadmÃ© sighed. "But I can't even get Bail to budge on this. He's caught up reacting to it too. Well, and trying to hold the coalition together."

But wars were won and lost by small actions as much as big ones. "Mon Mothma?"

"No, she's like me. Too new. Relatively speaking. And Uncle Ono is thinking of heading back to Rodia. He's not sure he can keep his seat with things going the direction they are. Not if he also votes against military action."

"His people need better trade options."

"Oh, I'm aware," PadmÃ© slumped into a seat, rubbing her face with both hands. "We've even talked about it. He likes our ideas, he's just not sure we can get the movement we need."

"Tens of thousands of systems," Leia mused, "With several thousand senators representing them. And we still can't get a single thing done."

She could, objectively, see the appeal of having an executive leader who pushed things along. It was just hard to also come up with a list of the correct limitations to prevent them from pushing only their own agenda.

Although, making sure they weren't a Sith lord would probably help. A lot.

"I just don't understand," PadmÃ© said, pulling Leia's attention back. "Why doesn't anyone want to get things done?"

It was hard to not just nod at the sentiment, but Leia forced herself to say, â€œThey do. They just want to get things done that relate to them."

"There's also the issue of money," EirtaÃ© pointed out. "Or just resources generally. Once the Republic started changing the terms of entry and representation, systems had different concerns for qualifying to be part of the body. And you know how many just opt out, or allow themselves to be pulled into someone else's district."

A numbers game. Leia had been enjoying those first few weeks, sorting through the data and making it make sense. But now she needed the numbers to do her bidding, and that was a much harder task. Because what the numbers represented were people, who were frequently irrational andâ€”

"What do they want?" she asked, mostly to herself. "What do they want to have? To maintain?"

Leverage, they needed leverage andâ€”

"Leia?" PadmÃ© and EirtaÃ© were both watching her curiously.

"Why do they want an army?" Leia asked. "Really want one? Who is it that wants the military force? They have the Jedi," which didn't factor into her calculations nearly enough, she realized. "Where do they think the soldiers are going to come from? The supplies? The ships? Who do they think is going to be taxed?"

They spent twenty minutes working through that, and lifted PadmÃ©â€™s spirits enough that when she got a request to go and talk to the Trade Federation delegate, she had fire in her eyes again.

When she had left, Leia asked, "Where do the staffers meet to share the best gossip? I've tried the refectory and several of the lounges, but it seems like those are still too public."

EirtaÃ© blinked. "We didn't show you? Come on, there are a few good options."

"Mixed company?" At EirtaÃ©'s baffled look, she added, "Mixed delegations. Staff low enough on in the hierarchy they don't mind fraternizing with the enemy a bit."

The really dangerous ones, who sometimes stayed in those positions for years, had the best information and the best sabacc faces. They were Leia's favorites.

"Iâ€¦don't know. We don't go down there as much now."

Well, they would need to fix that.

Ten days, and Leia's head was already swimming with the feeling of being back on Coruscant for too long. She needed calm, she needed quiet, she needed peace. And she wasn't really sure where she could go to get it.

Something in the air here tasted like Palpatine. She wouldn't have noticed, but she had finally lived in a world without him, and now having him backâ€¦

Sometimes it was like the very air she breathed was slick with the oily feel of his corruption.

"How are things going?" Leia asked Shmi, trying to focus on the call instead of her own misery.

"Well enough. Things are moving a bit faster than we anticipated. We've already processed ten ships."

"Ten?" Leia didn't know if she should be impressed or horrified.

"Ruwee and Jobal say this is good. Our system is holding so far. Not flourishing. We're still working out problems with every flight that lands. But we haven't been overwhelmed, and the camps and stations that have been set up aren't generating more problems. The locals currently barely know we're here."

That would change, Leia thought, when people came looking for work and education. Started integrating with the current populace. But if they'd processed another six ships already, that meant the process wasn't just working in Theed, it was working across the planet, and even further out in the system. Which was good. It meant they were off to the right start.

"Do you have any idea how many more you can expect?"

"Not immediately. Ruwee's in conversations with several Outer Rim contacts, but most of their people don't want to settle here. Which is one of our big problems. We have plenty of transplants, but not the best ground to plant them in."

Which meant, "I assume he's contacting other systems."

"Yes. But things have been slow as far as reception."

It was delightful to see the spark of anger in Shmi's eyes. For the first time in her life she had the power to do something, to change other's circumstances. She was made for it. "I'm sorry. I'll talk to PadmÃ© and see if she has any ideas of people who might be willing to get on board with the test runs. It would be better to see if the process holds up in other systems."

She'd talk to Shea about it, Leia thought. That was where all of this had gotten started anyway.

â€œJust as long as it doesnâ€™t add to your workload,â€ Shmi said sternly. â€œYou have enough on your plate already.â€

Thinking back to her own years working in the senate, and then to the multiple positions sheâ€™d had to simultaneously fill in the Rebellion, Leia could only shrug. â€œI have space for this.â€

Shmi took a moment to give Leia the most motherly stare before asking, â€œHow much sleep are you getting?â€

â€œOn average?â€ Leia stalled, scrambling for an answer that wasnâ€™t a lie. Shmi was too good at spotting those. And also half-truths.

â€œLeiaâ€¦â€

â€œNot enough,â€ she confessed, shrugging as nonchalantly as she could. â€œBut Iâ€™m used to it. Iâ€™ll catch up later andâ€”â€œ

â€œThatâ€™s not how sleep works. And you need your mind sharp for your work.â€

â€œYes, Grandmother,â€ Leia muttered, freezing as she realized what she had said.

Shmi had frozen too, then relaxed and smiled, something in her expression warming in a way Leia couldnâ€™t pinpoint. â€œI love you, Leia.â€

Tears pricked at the corner of Leiaâ€™s eyes and she whispered, â€œI love you too.â€

And it was true. Shmi was family and friend and companion, brave and gentle and strong. Leia was proud to be a part of this womanâ€™s legacy. It healed so much hurt that had been haunting her since that lonely night on Endor.

â€œI know you like to work hard. But donâ€™t forget to take care of yourself.â€

â€œIâ€™ll do my best,â€ Leia promised.

â€œDo better.â€ The dryness was offset by real affection, but Leia got the message.

She ended the call with Shmi and leaned back against the couch, glancing around at the empty apartment. PadmÃ© was at some sort of dinner party tonight, DormÃ© was seeing someone special she thought no one knew about, and the other handmaidens on planet were nominally watching PadmÃ©. Leia guessed they were more likely flirting and spying.

She needed to get in more on that part of their work. But how to convince them? Showing up uninvited was a definite no.

As happened often now when she didn't have enough to do, Leia found herself in her quarters, digging the misplaced lightsaber out of her bag and turning it over and over. She rarely turned it on. There was something about the hum of it that made her hair stand on end. Something angry and heartbroken.

Sometimes she saw yellow eyes in a red face and feltâ€¦ nothing (like the blackness she felt every time she'd met the Emperor's eyes).

Sighing, Leia put the saber back. And plotted how to get PadmÃ© to let her help with the military creation movement. She'd be good at helping, she knew she would. And if she were indispensableâ€¦

When all else failed, repeat what had already worked.

â€œYouâ€™re up early.â€

Finishing the sentence she was reading, Leia used the time to pull herself together before she looked up to greet the Jedi. â€œMaster Gallia. Not really, just having breakfast here instead of at home. Things are a bit tumultuous this morning.â€

â€œSo you came here for peace and quiet,â€ there was an almost envious looked on Master Galliaâ€™s face as she looked around the room.

â€œOnce. It wasâ€¦I only had the chance once.â€

Sheâ€™d gone with her mother, as a special treat while her father was gone. Leia still wasnâ€™t sure if heâ€™d been scandalized that they went, or just jealous they had gone without him.

Unsettled Spirits

When the numbers started to jumble on the screen in front of her, Leia knew she would have to call it a day. There was just too much data here and she needed to find a more efficient way to sort through it now that she had about ten times as much of it to handle.

Without having PadmÃ© hire someone else. Leia wasnâ€™t ready to have the nagging suspicion someone was (even accidentally) outing their plans as a constant worry just yet.

â€œAre you finished for today, Mistress Leia?â€ Threepio asked, looking up from his own work. Heâ€™d been asked to come up with a list of more casual events they could invite delegates to for fostering better working relationships.

â€œYes, Threepio. If you want to stay here and finish anything, Iâ€™m sure the senator or CordÃ© would be more than happy to bring you home.â€

Laughing at that particular standard, Leia suddenly stopped. â€œDo you know where he is right now?â€

â€œI would assume with Senator Amidala. He tends to follow her around during the day when she isnâ€™t in private meetings.â€

â€œAre you up for an adventure?â€ she asked, hoping heâ€™d get into enough trouble to keep him entertained, but little enough that she wouldnâ€™t get called on it.

Artoo gave a strong affirmative.

â€œGood. I was hoping you could compileâ€”â€œ A thought flashed. â€œNo. I needâ€¦ Artoo, do you know how to access official reports from the senate database?â€

He asked which ones, but she knew him well enough to know it was more to gauge what how much trouble she would get him into, not lack of ability.

â€œI need the financial and transport records for the Trade Federation, and also the other trade groups that are approved by the senate. I need to compare their official reports to the primary source records and see if the patterns they are officially listing actually match their monetary and resource movement.â€

Artoo whistled something she didnâ€™t quite get and she looked at Threepio. â€œHeâ€™s wondering where you got the information you already have, and what you were hoping to compare it to specifically.â€

â€œIâ€™ve got the public record reports that were submitted by the senate committees, but not their internal committee reports. And I have manifests and records from the systems Iâ€™m most concerned about.â€

â€œWould you?â€ Leia asked, relieved. â€œIt would be a huge help.â€

She didnâ€™t need a translation of the affirmative beeps and whistles, and she thanked both the droids before offering to take them home. â€œAlright. Just make sure you let PadmÃ© know that she needs to bring you both home.â€

â€œYes, of course.â€

Checking her chrono, Leia grimaced as she made her way out of the building. It was early. Her sleep was starting to seriously impact her work. She needed to do something about that.

Her immediate plan to return to the apartment and take a nap failed when she got there and could only toss and turn, sleep evasive in spite of her tiredness. Instead of rest she got wandering thoughts and the quiet that led to things she did not want to be thinking about.

Dodging memories of her father, Luke, a ship whose crew quarters sounded very appealing right now, and the impression of fire in her mind if she spent too much time thinking about Artoo or Threepio, Leiaâ€™s thoughts eventually started circling back to the lightsaber hidden in the room.

And how it wasnâ€™t hers.

And how it was somebodyâ€™s life, and had ended up in a literal trash heap.

Nothing poetic in that at all.

When sleep proved to be far enough away that it wasnâ€™t worth the effort, Leia threw herself out of bed and stomped over to the lightsaber, pulling it out and turning it over and over in her hands. Flashes of faces she didnâ€™t know clouded her mind and she almost threw it out the window, sick of the whole mess, before she realized there was something so much easier she could do with it.

So she left a note for whoever got back next and hopped onto the rail at the nearest station, lightsaber tucked under the folds of an over robe she had picked up here on Coruscant.

She dreamed in flashes of color and unintelligible sounds with her eyes open all the way to the Jedi temple.

The crowd outside ebbed and flowed as groups approached and left the structure. Ships of all shapes and sizes seemed to be docking in landing bays around the upper levels, many of them personal sized vessels, others definitely not. Some of the crowd that wandered through the gate was pairs of Jedi, or even occasionally a single Jedi or a small group. But mostly it seemed to be scholars, political attachÃ©s, or just tourists here for the famed sight of the home of the Order.

â€œYou here to see someone, miss?â€ one of the guards asked as she made her way in. She shook her head and he encouraged her to enjoy the grounds and take all the time that she wanted.

Once she had made it inside, past the thick outer walls, the noise dropped off abruptly. Not to silence, but the sounds of Coruscanti traffic were diminished, and the people that moved around out here, many though they were, seemed to have dropped to hushed tones and whispers.

The Jedi were clearly the most prevalent and comfortable people present. Leia wondered what the exact significance was of all the robes they wore and the different colors and styles. Many of the younger ones, looking adolescent as much as she could guess depending on species, seemed to have some sort of braid or chain and short cropped hair where applicable. Younger than that and they usually had some sort of older escort and were dressed in pale colors. And there was a broad mix of ages. Some of the garden paths and groves were usurped by what had to be lessons.

There was an uncanny lack of blasters but an overwhelming number of lightsabers. Leia would have felt more nervous if she hadnâ€™t known she was carrying one herself. For all the sense of peace that Master Gallia had promised, there was an underlying sense of danger that Leia just couldnâ€™t shake.

These people were powerful. And they knew it. And they expected to be treated like it.

She visited a few shrines and eavesdropped on what were probably a couple of informal tours, picking up various historical details about the building and its various structures, but not finding anything useful in the information. She found herself looking up to the central tower, where the High Council supposedly met, and wondered if they were in there and if anyone was looking down into the gardens, amused or irritated or just ignoring the mass of people down here.

â€œAre you lost?â€

The question had an unusual hesitance to it, and when Leia looked up she was surprised to see a face that had the slightest hint of being familiar. Human, possibly mid or early thirties, male, shoulder length hair brushed back, neatly trimmed beard, blue eyesâ€¦

â€œMiss?â€

â€œSorry,â€ Leia managed a short smile, hesitant. â€œNo, Iâ€™m fine. I mean, Iâ€™m not looking for anyone in particular. â€œI will certainly do my best,â€ his expression was pleasant and unsuspicious, but Leiaâ€™s skin tingled like he was observing her much more closely than his eyes belied. â€œDo you need to forward a request for something? â€œNo,â€ Leia shook her head, hand reaching into her robe and noticing that prickling feeling focusing on that movement, even as his eyes stayed fixed on hers. â€œItâ€™s not exactly personal. I just found something, and Iâ€™m not sure what to do with it.â€

Sheâ€™d expected surprised when she pulled out the saber, but what she got was another moment of sharp shock, suddenly there and suddenly gone like she had felt from Master Gallia. â€œIâ€™m sorry, but where exactly did you find that?â€

â€œOf course,â€ came out of her mouth, but Leia was sure she was bleeding reluctance. It wasnâ€™t hers, no matter if she had found it. She didnâ€™t need to be armed, even if more than half the people around her were. Even the children. â€œYou recognize it?â€

â€œI am. That is, I work for Senator Amidala.â€ He was too smooth. She was tripping over her own tongue like she was a first year senator again and it rankled. She needed to focus. â€œI wouldnâ€™t consider this official business though.â€

â€œYou said it was personal. I assume you were the one that found this. Did the senator recommend you bring it here?â€

â€œIâ€™ll try to remember that,â€ she promised, feeling on shaky ground again and searching for some way to take back the conversation. Hopefully that was a good thing.

She really needed to sleep.

â€œTell that to Master Yoda,â€ Anakin grumbled, thinking of any number of misleading comments the grandmaster had made over the last ten years. The old troll loved subtle wordplays and getting people into trouble.

â€œPadmÃ© was here?â€ Anakin felt something sparkle inside him, looked out the window even knowing that if Obi-Wan were here, she would already have to beâ€”

â€œNo,â€ his master was far too amused and Anakin glared. â€œNot the senator. One of her aides. Leia, she said her name was.â€

â€œNo,â€ the diminishing patience tone wasnâ€™t much better than the amusement. â€œLeia was just returning the saber. She barely mentioned the senator at all.â€

â€œExtract the crystal, probably, and see if I can use it. The hilt design doesnâ€™t really suit me anymore.â€

â€œDonâ€™t you have course work to finish?â€ Obi-Wan asked.

â€œNo. What do you think Iâ€™ve been doing all evening?â€

â€œI had assumed you went to go see the new ship that came in today and volunteer to help with the test run.â€

Well yes, but that hadnâ€™t taken all evening. There was a limit to how much Anakin was willing to beg, and they never told him yes unless it was a star fighter. As if it was safer if he was in one of those. â€œYou underestimate me, master. Itâ€™s very disheartening.â€

â€œShow me what youâ€™ve done,â€ Obi-Wan seemed okay with being teased now. â€œAnd then if we have time, maybe Iâ€™ll let you help me test my old saber.â€

Tactical Governance

Chapter Notes

I... grossly underestimated the reactions people would have to Leia and Obi-Wan's meeting last chapter. Which is kind of silly on my part.

As a more general note, I've been updating the tags these last few chapters to reflect the broader cast of characters that is actively involved in the plot and will probably update again as more relevant changes crop up. You have been warned.

â€œSo where did you run off to last night?â€

Leia had to give PadmÃ© props, she knew when it was pointless to be subtle. â€œThe Jedi Temple. Master Gallia suggested that I visit it sometime, and Iâ€™d been meaning to go. I had time yesterday.â€

â€œYou got back late.â€

That was true. Instead of coming straight back, Leia had wandered for a while, pondering the existence of Obi-Wan Kenobi, trying to remember how her father had described him to her verses how her brother had talked about the Jedi as a ghost.

Theyâ€™d been painful recollections, constantly tripping over grief from Alderaan and her brother and everyone else she was now missing. â€œI was thinking about things. Hoping the fresh air would help me clear my head.â€

Fresh being a very relative term. Nothing on Coruscant really qualified as fresh air. Although the Temple grounds had been cleaner than most places she was familiar with.

â€œDid it work?â€ There was something measured in that question, and Leia wondered what PadmÃ© meant by it. A glance at the handmaidens at the table wasnâ€™t enlightening.

â€œFor a given value of clarity, yes,â€ Leia admitted. Actually, now that she thought about it, â€œDo you know Jedi Knight Obi-Wan Kenobi very well?â€

That caught the table by surprise. EirtaÃ© was frowning, DormÃ© looked puzzled, and CordÃ© was smiling in a way that Leia was not sure she liked. But PadmÃ© simply answered, â€œNot especially well. I knew his master, Qui-Gon Jinn, for a little while during the siege of Naboo. Shmi might remember him. He took charge on Tatooine of getting us ship parts.â€ The way her mouth moved told Leia her friend had not been happy about that in some way. â€œObi-Wan was training with him at the time, but I didnâ€™t spend much time around him. I know heâ€™s a good Jedi though. He fought the assassin the Trade Federation sent after me who was trained with a lightsaber. His master didnâ€™t survive the fight,â€ she added softly.

Something clenched in Leiaâ€™s gut as she recalled the images, visions, sheâ€™d experienced as sheâ€™d held that lightsaber. â€œThey sent a Sith after you?â€

â€œA what?â€

â€œI didnâ€™t think there were any more Sith,â€ PadmÃ© said after a moment. â€œI thought they had all been killed a long time ago.â€

Never assume that evil is gone, her father had always told her. It has an uncanny tendency to always find a way back, especially in prosperous moments, when it has the most to feed on. â€œItâ€™s an ideology,â€ Leia said instead, shrugging. â€œAnd training. â€œOh,â€ DormÃ© twisted her napkin in her hands. â€œDo you think theyâ€™ll come back now then? Since the Jedi already killed them again?â€

A master and an apprentice, Leia thought bleakly. And cursed the Jedi. Keeping people in ignorance was not a good way to protect them.

Specific time traveling exceptions aside, of course (she could almost hear Luke and Han laughing at her).

â€œYouâ€™d have to ask the Jedi,â€ she decided on. â€œIâ€™m not really an expert.â€

CordÃ© caught that one as a lie, Leia thought as she took another bite of food. And PadmÃ© might have noticed, because she asked, â€œHow did you meet Obi-Wan?â€

â€œAt the temple. He was wandering the grounds.â€

After a moment of staring, PadmÃ© said, â€œHeâ€™s training Anakin.â€

â€œOh?â€ Leia knew she hadnâ€™t gotten the tone right on that one. She should have been more surprised. Shmi had no idea who Anakinâ€™s master was.

â€œSince Master Jinn couldnâ€™t,â€ the senator was ignoring her food, and Leia knew sheâ€™d be blamed for that. â€œHe took Anakin as his padawan on Naboo.â€

Scrambling for a clever dodge, Leia tried, â€œDoes Shmi know that?â€

â€œIâ€”I donâ€™t think I mentioned it. Not specifically.â€ Well, flustered was better than on the hunt.

â€œPadmÃ©,â€ EirtaÃ© interrupted, â€œyou need to finish. We have a meeting this morning. The queen is calling.â€

There was some deliberation, but Leia decided to stay. There was going to be an official update on the refugee situation, and while she trusted Shmiâ€™s observations it was just as important to know what the higher ups were saying. If they were getting the same information.

Leia also used the time to try and recalibrate after the conversation this morning.

If she kept doing odd things, it would only get harder and harder to explain why.

The council update itself was illuminating. Governor Bibble seemed fine with the policy changes as they hadnâ€™t damaged his image in Theed. Leia made a note to keep an eye on him to see if his support was too fair weather. The other members seemed mostly onboard, with the exception of the head of the cultural preservation committee. No surprises there.

The queen herself seemed delighted, and Leia almost wondered if it was as much finally having something significant to put to her own name as it was the success of the project. â€œDo you need anything from us to keep things moving smoothly?â€ PadmÃ© asked once the details had been reviewed.

â€œMore refugees?â€ Governor Bibble suggested. â€œWe should probably test this to its breaking point if we can.â€

â€œMaybe not that far,â€ the queen corrected. â€œBut yes, we need more people to help. And more places to send them, if possible. That was doable, but Leia didnâ€™t say anything as PadmÃ© hedged instead of making promises. Her mind drifted to Senator Darsana, but Leia immediately rejected the thought. The anselmi had enough territory trouble without introducing another species to the mix.

Although, if they could pick a fully aquatic oneâ€¦ It would be something to occupy the nautolans. She would have to think about it.

â€œThat wasnâ€™t so bad,â€ DormÃ© stretched carefully, making sure not to hit Leia. â€œDo you think it will continue to work?â€

â€œAsk Threepio to coach you,â€ Leia suggested. â€œHeâ€™s good at catching major cultural gaffes at least.â€

â€œHeâ€™s all yours.â€

The conference room was empty when Leia got there. She set up, knowing that the meeting had probably been cancelled and PadmÃ© had just been too busy to mention it. â€œItâ€™s no trouble,â€ Leia said, already packing her things. â€œI figured something had come up.â€

â€œFloor vote tomorrow,â€ the boy, Rashi she thought, managed between breaths. â€œSomething happened and theyâ€™re pushing to make a committee for the military stuff.â€

Panic was a close enough description of the feeling dancing in the office when Leia entered it. PadmÃ© was giving instructions on things she wanted people to work on while she was busy with the rest of the coalition. Each of the handmaidens had a world or two to approach, gauging interest. â€œDo you need me to do anything?â€ she asked, stepping further into the room.

â€œMostly only the Loyalist Committee,â€ Leia had to admit. â€œDo you know if anyone else needs help though? Has anyone talked to the Jedi about this?â€

It slid off her tongue without thinking and everyone who heard her went quiet. It was PadmÃ© that answered, â€œThe High Council will meet with the Chancellor to deal with the logistics of things that involve them. But they stay out of the details of Senate business.â€

â€œWhen theyâ€™re the enforcement?â€ that sounded wrong, but she shouldnâ€™t be surprised. â€œCan they at least speak to their friends? Not persuade but test the waters? Gather information?â€

â€œThey really donâ€™t like implying theyâ€™re favoring any particular delegates,â€ CordÃ© was shaking her head. â€œAs though inaction isnâ€™t just as bad in most cases.â€

Yes, well, never ask a Jedi to solve a problem before theyâ€™d tried to meditate about it. Luke had gotten more and more frustrating on that point as things had gone on.

Although he had been nervous, always wanted to get things right (sheâ€™d had no idea how it worked, wanted nothing to do with it, if sheâ€™d just been there, supported himâ€¦), and her brother had been nothing if not incredibly responsible for things he had nothing to do with.

â€œI can at least wander the halls,â€ Leia offered. â€œTake Artoo and Threepio. Gather information. Nothing helps more than a lot of gossip at times like this.â€

And the droids wouldnâ€™t miss anything important, or forget it. They wouldnâ€™t even have to be advised beyond follow and listen. They were smart enough for this.

Twelve hours later, Leia was on clean up duty, making sure that the senators that were still in the building had eaten sometime that evening and were getting rides home if they werenâ€™t flying themselves.

â€œItâ€™s no fun sleeping on a desk,â€ Leia told Shea, â€œno matter how good it sounds.â€

The Herdessan chuckled as she shoved herself away from her work. â€œWeâ€™re not ready for this,â€ she whispered, glancing around at the few other members still in the room. â€œWeâ€™ve been trying to put it offâ€¦â€

â€œCivil war conflict,â€ Leia was just as quiet in return. â€œNo oneâ€™s ever ready for that. For what it really means.â€

That there were people around you, neighbors and lovers and friends, that you couldnâ€™t believe in, couldnâ€™t trust. That you might be smiling today and outright enemies tomorrow. And the people you might need to rely on, who might agree with you in principle, were people you would almost rather die than work with.

To say nothing of the scale of the conflict. The Rebellion had traveled the length and breadth of the galaxy, but their problem had been that, so often, there was enough of a semblance of peace. And no one wanted to release that.

â€œHas anyone had any successful contact with the Separatists?â€ she asked, watching Sheaâ€™s reaction.

It was very muted. â€œNot officially, no. Almost all of us know someone, personally, that felt they had to secede on a matter of principle or honor. A few because they would have lost the support of their planet. Most of us that are left that want to negotiate are suffering from similar conflicts, but have an older system in place that makes us harder to supplant, even if our constituents turn against us.â€

Naboo appointed people to the post through the queen, it didnâ€™t hold a general election. Alderaan had an election, but it was based on delegates that were preselected by the council, which was how Leia had even been considered. To say nothing of other systems where the local government wasnâ€™t elected, and they appointed their representatives.

What a mess.

â€œDo you know if Jar-Jar Binks is coming?â€ she asked Shea, not really expecting her to know. Theyâ€™d left the gungan to help with the refugee settlement (and it had been almost shocking to realize that he was Junior Representative), but he would probably have been a great help in a moment like this. No one could accuse him of being anything less than sincere.

â€œPadmÃ© hasnâ€™t mentioned it to me, but that isnâ€™t unusual. She plays things pretty close to the vest.â€ Shea quirked a brow, â€œAnother thing you two have in common.â€

â€œPolitics are politics,â€ Leia suggested, giving the senator a knowing look. â€œYou play things pretty close with me.â€

â€œLess than you might think,â€ Shea was just smiling now, and there was something surprisingly affectionate in it. â€œWhich probably means youâ€™re right and I should head home to bed. Offering a hand that the senator accepted, Leia kept steady and pulled Shea to her feet. â€œTake care of yourself,â€ Leia said. â€œHowever this ends, itâ€™ll be a long fight ahead.â€

Tapping Leia on the nose, Shea actually giggled. â€œPretty sure I should be the one telling you that.â€

Leia hoped she hadnâ€™t actually blushed. She wasnâ€™t that bad.

It was surprising how similar and different the senate floor was in this time.

Leia looked over the hover pods, the round chamber, the dais in the middle that rose and fell at different times when the Emp- Chancellor used it, the sporadic and thus dramatic lighting.Â  The echoes of the chamber, carrying the muted tones of even the lowest whisper.

In other ways, it was completely different.

There was a sense of purpose in the room now that Leia might not have noticed had she not been in the same environment when it was not present. Representatives visited each other in different pods, conducting last minute business before the floor opened. That never happened in the world she remembered. Business had always been conducted in fine restaurants or exclusive clubs, maybe in the offices (or even chambers) of the Emperorâ€™s closest associates. The senate floor had just been the stage from which the Emperor had announced his edicts and the desires of his sycophants that he was willing to allow for a time.

There were also more representatives. Each pod was actually filled, and most spots had more representatives in them than Leia was used to.

It was a little overwhelming.

â€œThe first time is the hardest,â€ DormÃ© whispered into Leiaâ€™s ear. She was smiling reassuringly and Leia smiled back, letting her ruefulness at getting caught staring carry a slightly false message. â€œDonâ€™t worry, youâ€™ll adjust.â€

â€œI plan to,â€ Leia whispered back, turning to look out over the room again. This time her gaze was more deliberate, slowly moving across the room and testing her knowledge of the people she saw.

Orn Free Ta was present, which made her skin crawl slightly. Then there were dozens of others that fell under her gaze but brought no sense of recognition. There were a series of nemoidians, which also made Leia twitch, more because of the stories from PadmÃ© than her own distant history. There was Mon Mothma in her pod with a number of other delegates, probably trying to organize how this morningâ€™s vote was going to go, reassuring them in that gentle put steadfastly firm way she had.

Bail Organa.

Even expecting him, Leia felt a strong tightening in her chest as her eyes landed on him. He was smiling, laughing with some of his associates and shaking hands confidently.

Also securing votes. Her father had always turned up his indefatigable charisma when he was working the hardest to get what he wanted.

There were others that Leia recognized, but most were unfamiliar to her. The variety of species that were less humanoid impressed her. And horrified her. Because their lack of being present in her memories had no good implications about how they had been made to disappear. And in a relatively short time.

Thousands of systems, removed from the circle of power that had once been the Republic.

How had they ever thought that the New Republic would work itself out?

â€œPadmÃ©,â€ DormÃ© greeted as the senator arrived, smiling confidently. â€œDid you make your rounds?â€

â€œOf course. We should have everything in place for stopping more aggressive action.â€

Leiaâ€™s eyes drifted towards the neimoidians, and then back across the room to the Banking Clan representatives. â€œDid we secure much of the Outer Rim votes?â€

DormÃ© frowned and PadmÃ©â€™s brows drew together a little. â€œI believe we had a senator working on them, but it wasnâ€™t Bail or me. I think weâ€™ll be alright. Theyâ€™re usually pretty reliable. A prolonged conflict doesnâ€™t work for them.â€

â€œUnless it creates a standing army that can be repurposed to fight pirates,â€ Leia suggested quietly, with growing unease. With Count Dookuâ€™s success in assembling the Separatist congress, they had a slimmer margin for error than PadmÃ© probably believed. And somehow Leia had failed to properly convey that.

Fortunately, â€œWeâ€™ll have some time to make opening remarks,â€ PadmÃ© said confidently, catching Bailâ€™s eye from across the floor and tapping her wrist. â€œIâ€™ll give Bail warning about what we might expect.â€

That brought relief. The smallest bit.

Now was the tricky part. Making herself stand back and just watch.

It was awful.

Not that she'd had many opportunities to take the floor during her short time as senator. Emperor Palpatine had had little time to offer to anyone not himself, or singing his praises. She'd spoken the most in committees, and that in direct proportion to how much the committee had mattered. The more it had mattered, the less safe to have said.

Now, there was an open debate on the floor and Leia had to bite her tongue and squeeze her hands behind her back to remind herself to stay behind, to say nothing, don't interrupt.

This wasn't her fight. She shouldn't have come.

It was like watching Luke flying, she thought distantly. She knew what he was doing, saw the beauty of it, could even imagine what it felt like, and how his trust in the Force just made everything right. But she wouldn't do it herself. It was his battlefield up in the sky. Her place wasâ€¦ her place was down below. Planning. Watching. Being ready when the ships started to go down.

The first big hit was from the neimoidians, irritatingly enough. "Wouldn't you agree, Senator Amidala, that a standing Republic army would be of great benefit to a planet like yours. You have had some difficulty in the past, have you not, with keeping your people safe?"

It was a low blow, and did earn a rushed murmur, but it was a risky one, and one that PadmÃ©, though clearly angry, was ready for.

"I don't understand why the Trade Federation is so constantly insistent that they personally need access to an army," PadmÃ© shot back. "Naboo has no need of military forces if the members of this Republic are willing to acknowledge its sovereignty and treat it with equitable respect. We have never," she added, "been under assault by any forces from outside the Republic."

It was a good sting, but led to several minutes of vicious chaos. And did not change the point made by Malastare, "Yes, but even if Naboo has not been attacked yet, Count Dooku is building a coalition of systems that stand in opposition to the Republic. Surely we must consider how this changes the circumstances."

"We have plenty of open lines for negotiation," Mon Mothma interjected, responding to some signal that Bail had sent. "Many representatives of these systems have been our close friends. Have served in this Senate. If they have objections to our governance, we have an obligation to hear them, and allow them the representation they were granted as members of the Republic."

"But they're not anymore!" someone shouted, and Leia had to agree with them. Treaties had been signed in some cases. Having a voice in the senate for some of these systems would mean renegotiating entrance to the Republic.

And that, Leia knew from personal experience, would be a mess.

Sheâ€™d tried so hard, she thought, hands throbbing from how tightly she held them. Why was it never enough?

(Luke had always managed. Always. Always, always, always. Exceptâ€¦)

It hurt.

But she swallowed the grief and pain and failure and stepped forward slightly, reminding PadmÃ© of her presence. That the senator wasnâ€™t alone.

She could feel the comfort and PadmÃ©â€™s confidence as she noticed Leia and knew it gave them both hope.

It still felt like a failure when a committee was voted in to investigate what resources the Republic had available to create a standing army.

Silent at Your Grave

â€œYour friend is charming and lovely.â€

â€œSheâ€™s been overwhelmed, Bail. Give her some time.â€

â€œShe seems fine now.â€

Sheâ€™d noticed. Sheâ€™d noticed that Bail Organa made Leia uncomfortable. PadmÃ© was going to try and control the first meeting with him. Maybe even give Leia warning, a chance to back out.

She had been doing that, Leia realized with a lurch. And sheâ€™d had been taking PadmÃ© up on it. Leia had met everyone else from the coalition, except Bail. Because PadmÃ© had always offered her a discreet escape.

This was going to be a mess.

â€œâ€”wonâ€™t press the issue,â€ she caught Bail saying, more softly now. â€œI just wonder what I, or my people have done to offend her.â€

And also because Senator Sadashassa came over, offering Leia a drink and whispered warning, â€œThe Chancellor wants to meet you.â€

Yes, one emotional nightmare of a meeting was enough for today.

â€œYou must be our new consultant,â€ the mild tone sent ice down her spine as it always did, somehow worse coming from a face that was younger and more vibrant than the one in her memory. Leia swallowed bile, twitched her lips into a nervous smile, and found the floor with her eyes as often as possible. For now, shy was the best she could manage.

â€œIâ€™m working on behalf of Naboo, yes,â€ she murmured, playing with her glass, glancing up through her lashes. â€œSenator Amidala was good enough hire me.â€

â€œAnd you were good enough to be hired by her,â€ seeing him smile so much was unnerving. And so was the lack ofâ€¦ anything around him. There was a mild pleasantness, but it didnâ€™t seem to be coming from him. More like a cloak he was wearing.

Leia wondered what she felt like to him and hoped that whatever training she had been doing wasnâ€™t enough to make her more noticeable than her first days in the senate.

Sheâ€™d need to consult a Jedi about that wouldnâ€™t she, dammit.

â€œIâ€™ve been very grateful for the opportunity. Although I wish I were doing more to help.â€

â€œYes, this is a dreadful business,â€ every movement, every sigh was so exaggerated. Leia was exhausted just watching him. â€œOne does not want civil conflict in the galaxy. I have to adhere to the will of the senate, of course, but it will strangle negotiations if the Separatists find out about this.â€

Surely he wasnâ€™t planning on keeping it from them? That wasnâ€™t remotely possible. The results of floor votes were public. â€œWhat was the vote listed as on the official register?â€

â€œA vote on a committee to investigate our aid resources,â€ he answered promptly, obviously pleased with himself.

Leia had to bite her tongue to not point out that if the vote had failed, that would have been bad for the senate, in the Republic if not out of it. But then, that was exactly what he wanted, wasnâ€™t it? Sheâ€™d need to make sure PadmÃ© knew about that. And Senator Organa. And probably Shea too. They would understand, and have influence in the future.

â€œYou have a plan for everything, Chancellor,â€ she managed after a moment. She hoped he took her silence for awe.

There was the sound of footsteps, the swish of fabric, and a hand tucked itself through her elbow. â€œAre you saying hello to our newest member?â€ PadmÃ©â€™s voice held fondness, but there was something tremulous and aching in her that Leia tried to avoid noticing. â€œSheâ€™s been working wonders for us.â€

â€œSo Iâ€™ve been told. I havenâ€™t been able to see any of her reports yet, however. Are they still in the works, or do I need to scold my secretary again?â€

â€œStill in the works,â€ Leia said before PadmÃ© could answer. â€œI had some preliminary ones that were done on a very small scale, but I havenâ€™t presented my new findings to any committees yet.â€

Sheâ€™d surprised him. â€œYouâ€™re presenting to the committee? Well, well. Senator, it looks like youâ€™ve finally taken my advice and claimed a protÃ©gÃ©. How marvelous. Such a pity you couldnâ€™t find anyone in the youth legislative program.â€

Something wrenched in PadmÃ© then, and Leia wondered what that was about. â€œIâ€™ve done my best to mentor all of the people that Iâ€™ve worked with,â€ the senator said, her fingers a little tighter on Leiaâ€™s arm. â€œOf course, Iâ€™m still also being mentored myself. Senator Organa has been a tremendous help in teaching me how to navigate the senate and still hold to my principles.â€

That was an accusation, and while Palpatine might look like it had stung him, Leia was pretty sure it rolled right off him. Or hit his pride, rather than his conscience.

Leia was fiercely proud of her father just then.

â€œWell, I hope that you and he can do better finding votes for us going forward. Our efforts at negotiation will be for nothing if weâ€™re overtaken by the bureaucrats.â€

PadmÃ©â€™s answering smile was thin. Thankfully, someone came and caught the Chancellorâ€™s attention and he drifted away to condole with another member of the Loyalist Committee.

â€œThat wasnâ€™t very kind,â€ Leia remarked, taking the smallest sip of the drink Shea had brought her. A very mild wine. Shea was a good friend.

Her lips managed a smile, but PadmÃ©â€™s voice was tight as she answered, â€œWe had a bit of a falling out when I let Bail look after me when I got started here. At first I just didnâ€™t want to waste the Chancellorâ€™s time. I didnâ€™t have a claim on him, in spite of our history. And I didnâ€™t want to start any talk, or make it look like he was playing favorites. Butâ€¦â€ she spun her glass in her hands, â€œhe just doesnâ€™t do what he says he should.â€

There was an impulse to offer comfort. To make inane statements about how difficult politics was, how as Chancellor he had to balance so many interests, how it wasnâ€™t anyoneâ€™s faultâ€¦

And then Leia remembered who he was, and what he was doing here, and it took all her strength not to scream at him from across the room. To shout his crimes to the sky and reveal him for the fraud he was.

She had no proof and would only make things worse.

But the temptation was strong.

Instead she said, â€œIâ€™m glad you found someone who could be a trustworthy mentor. Senator Organa makes sure everything he does is in line with his principles. And while I know youâ€™re naturally inclined to be that way as well, itâ€™s always nice to have support. And someone to show you the ropes.â€

There were so many questions in PadmÃ©â€™s eyes when Leia stopped speaking, but they would have to wait. Even if her friend had voiced them, Leia would have never answered them here.

It was another three days before Leia worked up the courage to have PadmÃ© introduce her to Senator Organa. It took a while to find the right excuse, but eventually she managed, â€œWould you mind formally introducing me to Bail Organa? Threepio says Alderaanian tradition respects the commendation of mentors or teachers.â€

True in that Threepio had probably said that at some point in her life. Not this Threepio, here and now, but one of them.

Thereâ€™d only been the slightest hesitation from PadmÃ© before she had agreed and Leia took it as a good sign, mostly from desperation.

She could barely breath when she was led into the office.

Nothing was different from her memory. The decorations were sparse, a few hints to his homelandâ€™s culture. But this was his place of work to reach out to the galaxy, and heâ€™d carefully curated it to be as unimposing as possible. The scent of his favorite tea was a lingering hint in the air and Leiaâ€™s knees almost buckled as she realized that she had forgotten it.

His hair was darker, his face less lined. But she could remember everything about him so clearly in that moment. In a few yearsâ€™ time, he might have been her father, the one in all the happy memories of her childhood.

Hating her weakness (in all fairness to herself, she would have never really been ready for this), Leia found her eyes automatically drifting down, her hands seizing as she forced them not to clench into fists. Her eyes burned, but she refused to shed tears.

One second, three, four. Leia made sure her breathing was under control and her face was at least passive as she finally looked up, catching the tail end of PadmÃ©â€™s greeting. â€œâ€”since we had some time. If itâ€™s no trouble.â€

â€œNot at all,â€ Senator Organa (he had to be Senator Organa, not Papa, she couldnâ€™t let him be Papa) smiled as he turned to her, and it only faltered a little. She caught the hint of suspicion on him and was hurt by it until she realized what it was. Concern, for PadmÃ©. Leia was new, and a stranger, and PadmÃ© was his friend.

He wouldnâ€™t let anything happen to her.

It should probably have worried Leia more that his suspicion made her relax, but there was just something about it. Something so calm and soothing to see him acting in the defense of another. â€œWe have,â€ he agreed, offering his hand to her, and she was very proud that she managed to shake it and pull back before she started trembling (there would be no escape if she threw herself into his arms and started weeping). â€œAnd weâ€™ll be busy for a while, yet Iâ€™m sure. â€œIâ€™m sure youâ€™ll be fine,â€ it was hard to make the words sound right, they felt so inadequate. That twitch of his lips was an aborted smile over a personal secret. Probably something to do with her moâ€” with Queen Breha, Leia thought, if the shift of his eyes and the hint of a blush was any clue. â€œNot often. And I try not to repeat my mistakes.â€

â€œTheyâ€™re hard enough to swallow the first time?â€ Leia found herself asking, hoping for reassurance and realizing he had no idea that was what she was looking for.

And yet, â€œPain is never easy,â€ he said, and she could feel him looking at her, trying to see something he knew he was just missing. â€œI think we all try not to repeat it. But if we canâ€™t avoid itâ€”â€œ

â€œThen we carry on,â€ she finished, feeling the start of her own blush as she realized what she had done, reciting his words from memory.

â€œDo whatever is necessary. And donâ€™t look back.â€

â€œWe do.â€

Leia managed not to shudder, to end the conversation quickly and politely and without collapsing into complete and utter panic.

And then she left PadmÃ© and left the building and didnâ€™t stop moving until she had found herself once again at the Jedi Temple, surging through the gardens to someplace quiet where she curled up in on herself from every possible angle and wept and wept and wept.

The Negotiator

Jedi werenâ€™t a rare sight in the Executive Building, but Leia hadnâ€™t been expecting this one. â€œMaster Kenobi!â€

War Rooms

Chapter Notes

It is impressive how ten seconds of Palpatine talking to Anakin unearths such a depth and breadth of rage that lingers in the hearts of readers.

The look on EirtaÃ©â€™s face was almost worth the misery of having this conversation. â€œYou got invited to the dinner by a Jedi?â€

â€œI didnâ€™t think they were allowed to date,â€ CordÃ©â€™s face was half hidden by her drink, but even if Leia hadnâ€™t spotted her crinkled eyes, her amusement was dancing clearly about the room. â€œHe must fancy you.â€

â€œYou mean my brilliant and neurotic mind?â€ Leia shot back, keeping half her attention on PadmÃ©. Sheâ€™d been a bit somber since lunch. â€œHe did make it clear he wanted me there for professional reasons.â€

The name still tasted wrong. She could say it to Shmi easily enough, when they were talking about his childhood stories. But when Leia said it, in her own context, she was always swallowing Vader first. And burying the memories that came with it.

Well, that was fair. There wasnâ€™t anything honest Leia could do to argue with it.

â€œMay I join you?â€ Master Kenobi was almost lurking in the doorway, more hesitant than Leia would have expected.

â€œOf course. What can I do for you?â€ She gestured to a chair that was in front of her desk, clearing her workspace so that she wouldnâ€™t be tempted to split her attention.

â€œOf course. PadmÃ© was saying she met him during the siege of Naboo.â€

â€œYes, something like that.â€

â€œThatâ€™s true, butâ€”â€œ

â€œI see,â€ he didnâ€™t seem happy about it, but looked ready to concede.

Sheâ€™d have to do some refreshing, and make sure to check current Coruscanti styles so that it didnâ€™t end up too Alderaanian. She could find happiness in a crowded bunker with cheap liquor and tasteless food rations as long as she was with good friends. She could find courage in the middle of a battlefield, friends and allies dying around her, because she knew her cause was just.

Even the Best Laid Plans

When her chrono pinged Leia stretched as far as she could in the chair and rubbed her eyes, letting the words sheâ€™d been reading sink into her mind. Once she was sure she would remember them she tried to turn her mind to tonightâ€™s dinner and found the effort sluggish and ineffective.

It felt important.

Once comfortable, she peeled her mind away from the information she had been processing, sinking away from the numbers and names and systems and into that cool, dark feeling that was her self.

It had been speckled with lights once, glowing like dozens of stars littered in her senses. She felt now, sensed, that those stars and lights were still there, she just couldnâ€™t see them. Could feel them beyond the thick, dense haze that was her grief and sorrows, her anger and despair. But that haze between her and them was so cold.

She should probably deal with that.

She wouldnâ€™t tonight.

Once sheâ€™d centered and grounded, Leia reached out, beyond her sense of self to the pearlescent glow that was the world around her. That was power and being and yesterdays and tomorrows and sometimes even the clearest perception she ever had of the now.

Sometimes it brought noises, various sounds. Feelings or warmths or blazing heats or a cold of its own, sometimes ambivalent and others very sinister.

Tonight it was quiet. Quiet and peaceful calm. Like the center of the storm, or the stillness right before a disaster. It reminded her of being trapped in that cell, waiting for the return of Vader. Then composing herself, putting herself back together to face Tarkin.

Just before her world had ended.

It was clarity. And a warning.

And the luxury helped hide her youth, which was probably a good thing in these circumstances. The only issue, â€œIs purple the color of the evening for all the loyalists?â€

â€œNo. Is it a problem?â€

Not inherently, but, â€œDo you know what the Chancellor is wearing? He favors a lot of purples and similar dark colors. I was wondering if you would match, and if it was deliberate.â€

Frowning, the senator stepped further in to borrow Leiaâ€™s mirror for a moment. Leia took the chance to fold and wrap her sash, grateful that the sand tone stood out so clearly against the blue. It made it much easier to tie, and then twist and reposition until it lay mostly flat against her stomach and sides. She slid a few combs into it to test how visible they were and was pleased with the results.

â€œIt could be similar,â€ PadmÃ© admitted, sounding dubious. â€œIâ€™ll have to ask Bail if I resemble the Chancellorâ€™s party too much.â€

â€œIâ€™m sorry. I should have said something before.â€

Shaking her head, PadmÃ© moved to the door. â€œNo, we left you out of the planning on purpose. At least that worked. You and I donâ€™t look anything alike.â€

Well, not more than passingly, Leia thought. But yes, their styles were very different. PadmÃ©â€™s satins shone and shimmered as she moved, holding their shape with their stiffness. Their colors did not compliment, and theyâ€™d gone for very different styles in their makeup. Leiaâ€™s was minimalist, while PadmÃ©â€™s harkened back to her time as queen. Another decision to disguise her age and emphasize her experience.

â€œYouâ€™d better be going,â€ Leia said, checking the time. â€œI know you were planning on being early.â€

â€œTake care. Weâ€™ll see you there.â€

When the door closed Leia was already back in front of her mirror, placing a few more pins and putting on her jewelry. Sheâ€™d add her stole a few minutes before Obi-Wan was supposed to arrive. That and the sash should balance out the dark blues, she thought, and add the implication of the flowing impression of Jedi robes without imitating them.

As far as being dressed for battle, she was feeling mostly prepared.

â€œYou look lovely.â€

He didnâ€™t need to sound so surprised. But then, Obi-Wan had gotten the first word in because heâ€™d caught Leia staring at him. â€œThank you. Youâ€™re looking very nice yourself.â€

His smile told her he knew heâ€™d won the surprise round, but Leia counted it a victory on her part. He looked much better with short hair. And he was standing straighter too, which she wouldnâ€™t have guessed would be a side effect.

Or maybe it was just the image he was projecting for tonight.

Either way, it looked better.

â€œThank you for coming to pick me up,â€ she said as she grabbed her things. â€œItâ€™s a bit out of your way.â€

â€œIâ€™m fairly certain youâ€™re the one doing me a favor in all this,â€ Obi-Wan pointed out, actually offering her his arm as they made their way to the lift. â€œIt wasnâ€™t any trouble at all.â€

â€œThen Iâ€™m glad to be of service.â€

Her dress didnâ€™t move with the shushing silkiness she was used to, but it was comfortable and fit in a way that allowed her more freedom of movement than she had used to have at these events. Which was probably good. Sheâ€™d have to work her way back into more restrictive dresses if she wanted to attend any really fancy parties.

â€œAny new updates you can provide?â€ Obi-Wan asked as they climbed into the speeder. Leia gave him the most relevant notes she had compiled over the last week. He seemed equal parts worried and impressed. â€œWeâ€™re not walking into a very advantageous situation, are we?â€

â€œItâ€™s partly problematic because what motivates the Core worlds is a desire to avoid more bloodshed. But for those that are leaving the Republicâ€”â€œ

â€œTheyâ€™re already losing so many lives, having soldiers might actually be a benefit to them.â€ He sighed, moving through traffic with more caution that she would have expected. â€œThe Jedi are not an army. And we arenâ€™t equipped to act like one.â€

Leia nodded. â€œThatâ€™s probably for the best. Youâ€™re isolated enough as is. If you were full time combatantsâ€¦â€

She thought of the humanity that had been lost when people looked at her brother, seeing only the Death Star destroyer, the Emperor killer (and he hadnâ€™t even done that one, not that anyone ever listened) and Leia mourned the opportunities that had been missed to place him where he would have excelled.

Luke would do what was necessary. But he was also forgiving, had discovered that it was healing. And that, more than anything else, had been what their new Republic had needed.

Theyâ€™d sent him to be an enforcer instead. A subtle threat of what the systems would be standing against if they didnâ€™t listen to the Alliance.

Once heâ€™d figured it out heâ€™d hated it, and resented that he hadnâ€™t been told. Leia didnâ€™t even try and claim it had all been for the best. She knew better than that.

"I didn't intend for that to be such a depressing comment," Obi-Wan remarked, and Leia gave herself a mental shake.

"No, that was me. I distracted myself.â€

He didn't say anything, and Leia allowed what she assumed was a comfortable silence. His, "Do you get distracted often?" made her wonder what he was thinking.

"It depends on the situation," she admitted. "But when I'm working, I generally stay very focused."

"Not making any promises then?" he asked, and there was humor in his tone, but an undercurrent of worry that she couldn't miss.

She shifted in her seat, catching her first glimpse of the formal hall they were using, all lit up and glittering, even against the millions of lights around them. "I have done this before," she managed. "I'm just loath to make any absolute promises on anything. Life has taught me that nothing is certain."

"There is always the Force," Obi-Wan seemed to be quoting, or at least repeating a very familiar refrain. "That much is certain."

Maybe, but it wasn't much of a comfort. The Force hadn't saved Alderaan, or Han, or Luke. It hadn't even been the one to send her back. That had beenâ€”

"You really are very distracted," Obi-Wan said, and she was a little surprised by the gentleness in his tone. "I can't promise that no one will make any comments, but I can promise I will stay with you all night and help mitigate anyâ€¦ pretensions as best I can."

It was a kind promise, if a weak one, hard to uphold. Leia steeled herself, putting as much confidence into her voice and expression as she could. â€œI really am ready for this, that much I can promise.â€

More than the rest of them perhaps. She didnâ€™t know for certain if Palpatine had organized this event in her past, if Obi-Wan Kenobi had been at it, either with someone or alone. She didnâ€™t know the exact details or how different people would react.

But she knew it wasnâ€™t really a stage for reconciliation, it was for sabotage. And knowing that meant she knew what tools she would need to deal with it.

Obi-Wan at least seemed reassured. â€œI am confident in your competence. Come on. Letâ€™s see whatâ€™s going on inside.â€

They left the speeder in capable hands and made their way up a long series of steps to the hall. Leia wasnâ€™t technically breathless when they reached the top, but she had her suspicions that Kenobi had been using the Force. He was too collected when they reached the top step.

Not ideal, part of her thought, or welcoming to have so many stairs.

Inside glittered almost as much as out. The entryway was filled with delegates and guests, milling about, handing over cloaks and coats, making initial greetings, and gauging the atmosphere.

The noise immediately around them stopped when they walked in, and eyes turned towards them for a moment. Leia swallowed, breathed in a sense of invisibility and nothingness, but not too much, and met those stares with as much composure as she could manage.

Obi-Wanâ€™s arm wasnâ€™t linked with hers, but she felt his hand hovering near the small of her back, acting as a shield and a guide as they made their way into the part of the hall that had been set up for dinner.

The Chancellor was easy to spot at the front of the room near the head of the table, and Kenobi was clearly planning on heading that way first to make his greetings, but Leia stopped him, indicating with her eyes more than her head that they should approach Bail Organa first, and some of the guests that he was chatting with.

None of them were from the Senate.

Catching her intentions, Obi-Wan squeezed her wrist briefly, with a touch of a nod, and started moving them in that direction.

â€œMaster Kenobi,â€ Senator Organa said when he spotted them. â€œItâ€™s a pleasure to see you this evening. May I introduce you to our friends?â€

The crowd had varied reactions, some delight and relief, others suspicion, and the rest somewhere in between. Obi-Wan bowed to the company and Leia dropped a curtsy and a nod, smiling as sweetly as she knew how.

â€œIt would be our pleasure, Senator Organa. Please.â€

These were representatives from systems around Glee Anselm, Leia realized, and others from Felucia and its nearby systems. Around the room she could hear other names being thrown about, Christophsis, some systems she knew were near Naboo, and some places she had never heard of even.

When he had finished introducing the visiting delegates, Senator Organa said, â€œThis is Jedi Knight Obi-Wan Kenobi, and his associate, Leia Skywalker.â€

His face didnâ€™t slip, but Leia felt something plummet around Obi-Wan in the Force when he heard that name.

Shit. Sheâ€™d forgotten that she hadnâ€™t told him.

â€œAssociate?â€ the representative from Felucia asked, eyeing Leia skeptically. He was one of the only people in the room shorter than she was.

â€œAdvisor and associate,â€ Obi-Wan managed. To someone less familiar he sounded calm, but Senator Organa seemed to catch whatever it was in Obi-Wanâ€™s tone that was also telling Leia the man had been badly shaken. â€œSheâ€™s one of the consultants tracking trade information around the Republic and the Jedi Council have found her advice invaluable.â€

â€œHave they?â€ the felucian blinked a few times. â€œAnd what have you learned?â€

â€œMany things that make us concerned,â€ Obi-Wan said honestly. â€œIâ€™d appreciate hearing your perspective on how things look on the ground. Data can show patterns, but it canâ€™t inform us in the same way as experience. And the AgriCorps arenâ€™t in all of the systems that have a vested interest in being here tonight.â€

Listening, Leia thought, trying not to blink too much in the onslaught of lights (another minor offense?) and followed that thought. These people thought no one was listening. If Kenobi was going to do something to help that worked, the Jedi would have to do something at the end of all of this.

She would have to think about that. Leia didnâ€™t have any direct connections to the Jedi Council. Yet.

They only spoke in vague terms for a few moments before mixing with other crowds as they made their way up toward the Chancellor. People began sitting before they had quite made it, and Leia only shrugged when Obi-Wan indicated with his eyes to see if they should push forward. She had no interest in facing Sheev Palpatine tonight. But if the Jedi insistedâ€¦

He didnâ€™t. Winding through the crowd, they made their way to their seats and Leia had time to curse the placements at the table.

The guests who were being influenced by the Separatists were all seated on one side, across from the Loyalists and others the Chancellor had invited. It was clear too, which of them he had been working with personally, because they were the ones seated closest to him. It would be difficult, almost impossible, for informal conversation to happen across the parties during the meal. Which meant the evening would be long when they were mingling later.

Leia groaned internally, then braced herself. Sheâ€™d faced worse.

Glancing at her dinner partner as he held a chair for her, Leia wasnâ€™t entirely sure he wouldnâ€™t be the most difficult part of this evening.

Reunion

Shmi Skywalker was a force to be reckoned with.

Reflections

Curled up on the bed next to Shmi, Leia did her best to keep quiet as the tears streamed down her face. She might have gotten away with the slight trembling, but the hiccups interrupted her grandmotherâ€™s sleep, and Shmi blinked awake too quickly for Leia to cover the signs.

When the moon is mirrorbright, take this time to remember

â€œThe Jediâ€”â€œ

â€œArenâ€™t an army and arenâ€™t a police force. Thereâ€™re what, several thousand of them? Based here? At best thatâ€™s enough to assign one per a handful of sectors. Thatâ€™s enough to add to a negotiating team, or have as a consultant for oversight. Not an army.â€

And where was the army, Leia wondered. Based on Bail Organaâ€™s age, the Clone Wars had to be starting soon. And would require, as far as she was aware, clones. Which would take time to make. Grow? And no one had mentioned them yet.

Concerning.

â€œSo maybe we need something,â€ PadmÃ© sighed. â€œBut notâ€¦ this.â€

A shrug and a wave of the hand that encompassed the nightmare that had been the past few weeks. Yes, Leia understood exactly why PadmÃ© was standing in the way of all that.

But when it came to votes, â€œPeople are hoping that if we make an army it will end any potential conflict with the Separatists. And then weâ€™ll still have an army to do whatever we want with.â€

Maybe defend Republic trade routes. Maybe take Hutt space (that had Leiaâ€™s vote). Or maybe take back some of the systems that might have been, oh, reluctantly conscripted into the Confederacy. Or colonize parts of those systems that had trade goods people wanted. Orâ€”

Or any number of other unpleasant things.

Yeah, Leia understood why PadmÃ© didnâ€™t want an army alright.

So, â€œIâ€™ll talk to Senator Darsana some more,â€ Leia promised. â€œNot to get his vote, but to see if I can wheedle out what he wants for it. Maybe, if we can find other ways to address his concerns, weâ€™ll have something to work with. But Iâ€™m not going to just ask him to join us.â€

â€œThatâ€™s fair,â€ PadmÃ© conceded. â€œIâ€™ll talk to Bail and see if thereâ€™s anyone else he can think of with similar motivation. Not wanting a Republic army, but trade or travel enforcement. Balanced between sectors. I can do that.â€

There was peace between them again, of a sort. That was fine. Leia didnâ€™t need PadmÃ© to always agree with her, just for their relationship to work.

And.

And to be a friend. Leia liked PadmÃ©, how confident and sure she was in every move she made, every choice she stood for. Her queenly bearing, never mind that now she was a senator. Her long suffering patience and her quiet but unrelenting hunt for vengeance against those that had done her wrong. Robed in the civility of justice, chained by necessity to be less than pure rage, but still singing in the Force every time PadmÃ©â€™s eyes landed on Nute Gunray.

That man would pay for what he had done to PadmÃ©â€™s people. If it took the queen a lifetime and a drop by drop extraction of blood for what had been lost. Sheâ€™d settle for nothing less.

â€œSo what do you think of this place?â€ Leia asked as they finished, reluctant to head back to the Executive Building.

Shaking her head, PadmÃ© admitted, â€œI still canâ€™t believe Obi-Wan recommended it.â€

â€œHeâ€™s a Jedi. And a man. Supposedly they arenâ€™t picky about such things.â€ And if her visual sweeps of the room and casual eavesdropping had been any clue, he probably came here less for the food and more for the information.

â€œCan you imagine him bringing Anakin here though? What would Shmi think?â€

â€œItâ€™s not that bad,â€ Leia protested. It was at least civilized. Not a makeshift bunker with mud and bugs and only ration bars masquerading as food. â€œAnd I think I could like Dex quite a lot.â€

â€œOh thatâ€™s your type?â€ PadmÃ© giggled and Leiaâ€™s lips twitched. â€œPoor Shea.â€

â€œSheâ€™sâ€”â€œ No, not going to have that fight. â€œThink we can convince Obi-Wan that Dex spilled all his darkest childhood secrets?â€

PadmÃ© let it go. â€œEven better. Iâ€™ll bet we can convince him that Dex told us all the stories of how embarrassing it was when Obi-Wan brought Anakin.â€ They both laughed at the thought.

From the corner of her eye, Leia caught a reflection of them off of the glass. But when she turned to look, instead of her own smile, she saw her brotherâ€™s laughing face.

Regroup

â€œGo home.â€

â€œBail, I canâ€™tâ€”â€œ

â€œPadmÃ©, we donâ€™t actually know who did this. It could have been about the vote, or someone at the dinner that night, or something not related to our work at all. We have to be cautious.â€

Caution was all well and good, but Leia was more concerned that they didnâ€™t know what the motive had been. Politically motivated attacks should have a clear line to someone to take the fall at least, so that it would add weight to a message.

It was a lot. And it was stacked on top of her day to day work.

That hadnâ€™t gotten better after Alderaan had been destroyed. If anything, the bounty on her head had made it worse.

I want to help you, Leia was desperate to say. I want to solve your problems and save your people. I know what itâ€™s like to watch your way of life be dying and have no way out. To have stop gaps and desperate measures and have it never be truly enough.

This mattered.

â€œI want to see you again,â€ Leia admitted freely, allowing her hand to curl into a fist on her desk. â€œI hope I see you again.â€

â€œAnd that when you do, we are still friends?â€

His smile was teasing and something in it reminded her of Han a little (and how would he feel about that?), but even more he reminded her of Lando. Smooth and unflappable, oozing charismatic charm and subtly, underneath, ready to face any danger for his people.

It wasnâ€™t a promise that he would be here, but it would have to do. Leia made a bow of her most formal farewell and he matched it with his usual flair. Tears pricked her eyes, but she smiled as she saw him out and was delighted when he shook and then kissed her hand.

â€œYou could,â€ CordÃ© shrugged. â€œSome people do. But I think this is too personal for you for it to be something as altruistic as that. Youâ€™re like PadmÃ© in that way. She cares, but never as much as when sheâ€™s under attack. Or someone she loves is.â€

Beyond the sleepiness there was a keenness in those eyes and after the initial suspicion and panic had subsided, Leia acknowledged that CordÃ©â€™s timing was minutely deliberate. Over and over, from her biological parents to her adopted ones, to her long-lost brother and the man she had almost called husband. The family sheâ€™d been born with, the one that had chosen her, the one she had chosen. All of them stripped away, until there was only darkness left.
