She met CordÃ©â€™s eyes, unable to even guess at what was shining in her own. â€œI want to make them pay. And I want to make sure it never happens again.â€

Chapter End Notes

I just wanted to take a moment again to thank everyone who has left comments. It's exciting and entertaining to see your reactions (and your guesses). Your enthusiasm is appreciated and makes it easier to keep going. I, uh, grossly underestimated what I was getting into with this project. I expect it to drain me dry (and then some) before it is over. Your interest makes it easier and more worthwhile to keep going. So thank you to all of you.
And to the silent readers, thank you too. I do watch the numbers creep up each chapter I post. I'm glad you keep coming back. I hope you're also really enjoying this.

Worth Less

Sipping tea and staring out over the city, Leia hummed and tried to pretend that she didnâ€™t notice anyone coming up behind her.

For all the good that had ever done.

â€œYouâ€™re up early this morning,â€ Shmi didnâ€™t pretend that Leia hadnâ€™t noticed her (or was she like this with everyone, because she had been used to it with Anakin?), just got straight to the point. â€œI thought you slept well last night.â€

It was getting really bad if Shmi knew how well Leia was doing even when they werenâ€™t sharing a room. â€œI did. Early morning is when I think best.â€

â€œAnd what are you thinking about? While you are on vacation?â€

There was something so delightful about Shmi being a nag. Her tone was just too perfect. It had to be proof of their biological relation that Leia liked it so much, even when it was directed at her.

Especially when it was directed at her. â€œTechnically, PadmÃ© is on vacation. Iâ€™m just perpetually dubiously employed.â€

â€œIs that how she would put it?â€

The words had so much zing to them. Leia smiled as she took another sip. â€œNot a bit.â€

â€œWill you at least come inside and help me get breakfast ready?â€

Suddenly the humor was a lot less. Leia grimaced but nodded, accepting that whatever she contributed to this meal would be dubious at best.

Sheâ€™d been avoiding practice while she was on Coruscant. And Shmi was bound to notice.

â€œYouâ€™ve lost weight,â€ her grandmother mentioned as they sat down at their table, Leia proud that not everything that she had touched was now charcoal.

â€œIâ€™m always skinny,â€ she retorted, shoveling food into her mouth and ignoring when it crunched in places it wasnâ€™t supposed to. â€œOne of the few gifts of my genetic makeup.â€

She couldnâ€™t have been tall, no. That would have been too much to have asked to have gotten from her biological father (though Luke had been cheated there too, technicallyâ€¦) in the short list of things she knew she could blame on him.

Like being Force sensitive.

Maybe her mother had been short.

â€œYou have many gifts,â€ Shmi countered. â€œOne of which is access to enough food to take care of yourself.â€

It was dawning on Leia that Shmi was getting more comfortable being pushy. Which was nice, and probably necessary for Leiaâ€™s better health. But was also inconvenient. â€œI get plenty to eat.â€

She earned a very skeptical look.

They finished their meal in silence, Shmi focused on her food while Leia stared at the far wall and tried to find that happy place she had been visiting earlier where she hadnâ€™t actually been thinking about anything.

â€œI donâ€™t like you involved in this,â€ Shmi said, standing and beginning to clear dishes. She wouldnâ€™t meet Leiaâ€™s eyes now. â€œIâ€™m not comfortable with it.â€

Leia first bit back a retort that it didnâ€™t matter if Shmi was comfortable with it, it was Leiaâ€™s choice, she was an adult. Then she swallowed a series of platitudes where she emptily promised that everything would be fine. And finally Leia closed her eyes so that she didnâ€™t have to see the look on Shmiâ€™s face when she said, â€œI donâ€™t expect it to get better before it gets worse.â€

â€œI know.â€

Closing her eyes hadnâ€™t really helped. That tone said so much. â€œI canâ€™t not do it.â€

â€œI know,â€ the dry understanding in Shmiâ€™s tone coaxed Leiaâ€™s eyes back open just in time to catch the tremulous half smile her grandmother offered. â€œThat doesnâ€™t mean I canâ€™t try.â€

Try what, Leia didnâ€™t know. It was hard to believe Shmi wanted Leia to stop doing what was right. And her grandmother of all people had to know that sometimes that was dangerous. Even before her son had been taken awayâ€”

But that was what this was about, Leia realized, swallowing slowly. What it had always been about. Anakin had only wanted to do the right thing, and the right thing had beenâ€”

â€”To leave his mother behind.

â€œShmi,â€ Leia found herself standing, moving around the table and holding out a hand, again forcing herself to not utter lies for the sake of comfort. â€œI love you.â€

And that was the most painful truth of all, Leia realized as she looked at Shmiâ€™s face. That someone could love you and want whatâ€™s best for you and still leave. Because they felt like it was right.

(Sheâ€™d hugged him goodbye and demanded he come back and heâ€™d smiled and stepped away to let Han tug her hair and give her a kiss, and his eyes hadnâ€™t been smiling because her brother knew what they wanted, and he didnâ€™t want it, but he was trying to be rightâ€¦)

â€œI love you too,â€ Shmi answered, voice thick with emotion. And it hurt, because loving Leia was hurting Shmi and Leia didnâ€™t want the people she loved to be hurt by loving her.

â€œThereâ€™s no way,â€ Leia whispered (a crowded room, dozens of faces staring at her as she screamed, screamed because she couldnâ€™t breathe, her chest had been ripped out), â€œthat Iâ€™m worth the risk.â€

(He wasnâ€™t coming back. He was never coming back. Heâ€™d promised and was never coming back and she had to live with it.)

Shmi was brushing away tears and Leia tried to stop it, to say what needed to be said most. Donâ€™t love me, Iâ€™m not worth it. Iâ€™m not worth the risk.

(Thunder and flames every time she closed her eyes. Never there, never able to unsee.)

â€œLeia,â€ she was wrapped up in Shmiâ€™s arms, her grandmother disgruntled and still so patient. â€œYouâ€™re already part of me.â€

She couldnâ€™t close her eyes. She couldnâ€™t but she needed to because in the glass of the window all she could see was Lukeâ€™s face, staring soulfully back at her, his hand raised as though it was pressed against the glass, trying to reach.

Her eyes squeezed shut and Leia felt the tears and felt her tripping breaths and for a moment the past was present and she could almost feelâ€¦

(The touch of a hand on her shoulder, ghostly fingers suddenly pulling back.)

â€œIâ€™m not worth it,â€ she managed.

Shmi snorted. â€œI wouldnâ€™t have come with you if I believed that.â€ Warm, brown eyes smiling down at her. Offering peace and comfort and a feeling (in the Force?) that all was right, right here, right now. â€œYou wouldnâ€™t have brought me. Not if you believed that.â€

Youâ€™re worth it, she wanted to say. I always knew you were worth it. Thatâ€™s why he sent me here, back to you. The only one he could trust.

To keep me safe.

But to admit that out loud would be to admit everything (that he lovâ€”) and there was no way she could do that.

â€œI want to be worth it,â€ Leia managed.

Shmi kissed her forehead. â€œYou are a gift, Leia Skywalker. A wish that I never had granted. You may not be safe,â€ and that was the look of a woman who had definitely raised Anakin Skywalker, â€œbut you have been given. And for that, I am grateful.â€

â€œMistress Shmi, I believe you have a call.â€

Rolling their eyes, Leia and Shmi turned to Threepio who was hovering in the doorway. â€œTell them Iâ€™ll be right there,â€ Shmi said.

As the droid left, Leia chuckled. â€œHe always had impeccable timing.â€

â€œBlame Anakin for it,â€ Shmi tucked Leiaâ€™s hair behind her ear. â€œHe wanted a droid with peak attentiveness.â€

So Threepio would always know Shmiâ€™s business and when she needed help, Leia realized with a start as her grandmother left. He wanted her to have a friend, a protector, so she would never be alone.

And Leia had taken him with her to Coruscant.

Damn.

â€œIâ€™m not okay with this.â€

Seed of the Lotus

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

A strong breeze was grazing across the rooftop and Leia let herself be caught up in it, leaned into it as she closed her eyes on the pearlescent city sunset that shimmered in front of her.

The smell was wrong.

Sheâ€™d been feeling warm, caught up in the beauty of the moment. But once she closed her eyes all she expected was the thin, sharp scent of Aldera, crisp with an evening chill. And what she got was the thick warmth of flowers and water, brushed with old, worn stone.

It was wrong, and she hadnâ€™t expected it, so she wasnâ€™t ready when Threepio asked, â€œAre you ready to come inside, Mistress Leia?â€

Princess. Sheâ€™d expected him to say princess, and had to catch her breath before she answered, â€œIn a minute. I want to see this.â€

Shmi wasnâ€™t fond of sunsets. Sheâ€™d occasionally joke that sheâ€™d seen twice as many of them as any other woman her age and didnâ€™t respond much to Leia pointing out how different a sunset was when there was only one sun.

Night, it seemed, was not a time to be out of doors for Shmi Skywalker. No matter how much beauty the sky created.

To be fair to Threepio, he was quiet until the sun had dipped below the horizon. There was still a reddish pink glow around the buildings, but Leia accepted his, â€œI believe itâ€™s dark now, mistress,â€ as she looked straight up and could see more than a handful of stars.

One of the many perks of being away from Coruscant.

â€œIâ€™m coming,â€ Leia told him, lingering as long as she could before accepting it was time to go back inside.

She did have work tomorrow.

The droid kept chatting about the sequence of the day and complaining about Artooâ€™s antics. Leia mostly tuned it out, missing what was, for her, the necessary beeps and trills to make the complaints into an amusing banter. But she didnâ€™t discourage him as they made their way slowly down the stairs. She only rolled her eyes once, and that when sheâ€™d half caught a reflection of herself in a window and could have sworn sheâ€™d seenâ€”

She had.

The shadow that was her brother blinked back at her, trapped in the light bouncing back off the panes. He stared at her soulfully, a hint of mischief in his eyes, but mostly grief.

Sheâ€™d never be sure if it was the grief or mischief that made her believe.

Her lips formed the word, â€œLuke,â€ but no sound escaped as she brought up a hand, achingly slow, watching him mirror her until her fingers touched glass and the image of his palm pressed against hers.

His prosthetic hand.

The faintest line on his wrist to mark her memory, to test if this was right or just some cruel, delusional vision. She looked up again, into his face and there was only kindness there. Or maybe a bit of worry. She watched his mouth say, â€œLeia,â€ but no sound reached her.

It never would. Sheâ€™d never hear his voice again.

But he was here. How?

Slowly, so slowly, she almost couldnâ€™t breathe for how much this hurt, Leia turned on the narrow stairs, bringing her other hand up to meet his. Sheâ€™d almost pressed it against the glass when she paused, hesitating. So unsureâ€¦

â€œMistress Leia?â€

Her right foot wasnâ€™t braced right. She jerked, slid, yelped, and thudded on her butt down several of the stairs, throwing her arms behind her head in a desperate flutter.

Threepioâ€™s, â€œOh Mistress Leia!â€ was echoed by Shmiâ€™s, â€œLeia, are you alright?â€ as her grandmother dashed around the corner, assessing.

â€œIâ€™m fine,â€ Leia grumbled, taking a moment to catch her breath before she tried to stand. Her tailbone hurt. â€œI just slipped.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t slip,â€ Shmi noted as she helped Leia up, checking for injuries.

Leia snorted. â€œEverybody slips. Iâ€™m due, I promise.â€

And better here than somewhere else, where someone important might have been watching.

Shmi smiled a little, but Leia could feel an almost probing in the air around her. â€œAre you alright?â€

There were some things Shmi could do lightly, but looking after someone she loved wasnâ€™t one of them. The intensity of her words was a balm though, and Leia leaned into it and into Shmiâ€™s offered hug, taking a moment before she answered. â€œI keep seeing ghosts.â€

â€œGood ones? Or bad ones?â€

It was such a practical answer Leia almost giggled. â€œGood ones. One,â€ she corrected absently. â€œJust one.â€

â€œYour brother?â€ Shmi asked, and now she was gentle, so very careful.

Blinking tears Leia just nodded into Shmiâ€™s shoulder, breathing as slowly and evenly as she could. Noticing the smells, the sounds, in the half lit hallway.

Taking nothing for granted.

Shmiâ€™s quiet, â€œIâ€™ve got you,â€ kept Leia grounded, even as she felt like part of her was slipping away. A warm hand making circles on her back soothed tension, a hum in her ear kept her present and calm.

Sheâ€™d pulled back and offered Shmi a weak smile when Threepio said, â€œIâ€™m so sorry Mistress Leia, but Iâ€™ve just realized I donâ€™t know where youâ€™re from or how you honor your dead. If you tell me I can get you anything you need and make any necessary arrangements for you toâ€”well, would it be to release or invite the spirit of your brother? Oh dearâ€¦â€

It shouldnâ€™t have been funny, but Leia chuckled, reaching out to brush her knuckles across his cheek. â€œThank you,â€ she whispered before he could splutter with too much indignation. â€œI really appreciate you offering that.â€

â€œI couldnâ€™t offer you less,â€ he protested. â€œYouâ€™re part of the family. We have to take care of you. Especially since youâ€™re always getting yourself into trouble.â€

She could hardly argue with that. â€œWell, thank you. I really, really do appreciate it.â€

â€œYouâ€™re quite welcome, Iâ€™m sure. But where exactly are you from?â€

It wasâ€¦ painful to admit it. She was so careful to guard so many of her secrets. But this was Threepio, and if sheâ€™d learned anything it was that for all his talk, he could keep a secret.

And Shmi would never tell. Not a soul.

Leia whispered, choking over years of memories (and it was real and would never be dead again). â€œI grew up on Alderaan.â€

It wasnâ€™t as simple as just sending Threepio out, unfortunately.

First, Leia had to decide what kind of ceremony or memorial she wanted to have, given that most the traditional options for Alderaanian funereal memorials werenâ€™t really an option in Theed. And that Lukeâ€™s ghost was apparently haunting her in mirrors (that was not how heâ€™d described dead Obi-Wan and Yoda) and she wasnâ€™t sure she really wanted to get rid of him and send him peacefully on to the afterlife.

If he would even allow it. She was pretty sure he wouldnâ€™t.

â€œWhat would you like?â€ Shmi asked, sipping her tea and keeping a sharp eye on how often Leia sipped hers.

It was hard. Hard to even think about it. â€œI feelâ€¦â€ so hard to say it. â€œI feel like he has a message for me. But Iâ€™m not sure Alderaan has anything to invite wisdom like that.â€

Once she said it, she knew it was wrong. Knowledge and wisdom of the ancestors was frequently sought on Alderaan. Mostly in old tomes and poetry, bit and pieces of wisdom that had survived ages by process of elimination. But sometimesâ€¦

Sometimes you went to the mountains, the temple made by the gods, and asked for a vision.

Not that Leia believed in all that. Even with the Force. And there were no mountains around here. But it was as good a place to start as any.

â€œYou need a sacred space,â€ she murmured, turning her mug in her hands. â€œMaybe a holy one, but moreâ€¦ private. Personal.â€

Intimate. Quiet.

Meditative.

Damn Jedi, ruining every good, normal thing she had left. Couldnâ€™t even think about meditating any more without feeling a sense of foreignness to it.

In the end, she and Shmi had come up with something that was a mix of various ideas and cultures, frequently unrelated, and yetâ€¦

Cleansing baths were a common tradition between Alderaanian and Naboo culture, with small detail variance. Alderaan favored hot or cold sacred springs, Naboo, elaborate ritual baths with herbs and flowers, each with their own symbolism. Leia wasnâ€™t intimately familiar with it, but Shmi had been learning about the local flora and was able to prepare a mixture.

Sword lilies, rosemary, and blue salvia for remembrance, wisdom, and healing. Red and white chrysanthemums for love and truth. Basil, thyme, and lionâ€™s paw (a touch of home) for courage and luck. Hyssop for cleansing and lotus blossoms. For insight and eternity and being reborn.

And salts. Shmi insisted on the salts and Leia only felt that it was right. She wasnâ€™t visiting one of the sulfurous springs in Alderaanâ€™s mountains, but she did want to feel grounded. Besides, salts were also cleansing and Shmi said they were the sign of the desert that people carried in them, that bound water in flesh and reminded that the desert could give life just as much as it could take it away.

Leia liked the weight of that promise. The hope it carried with it.

Even in their relative poverty (Leia still hadnâ€™t been able to get Shmi to relocate, even with both of their improved work situations), they had a good sized bath in their home. Shmi dimmed the lights and insisted on candles, placed at specific intervals around the room.

Leia was pretty sure the pattern if not the candles was a Tatooine feature. Hopefully it would mean something to Luke.

The water wasnâ€™t just warm, it was hot, and the air was thick with steam as Leia slid in and got comfortable. She made herself relax as Shmi got to work, washing Leiaâ€™s hair and massaging her head and neck until she was almost limp with comfort. Leia didnâ€™t notice Shmi leaving as she soaked in the silence, the only sound the slight pop of the candles and the steady rhythm of her own breath.

When the water was tepid she forced herself out, shaking a little as she dried, her limbs reluctant to carry her own weight.

The lights in the rest of the house were dim. Shmi met her and gave her tea to drink, warm and spicy. She drained the cup as quickly as she could, accepted her grandmotherâ€™s hug, and slipped into her room to curl up on her bed.

The room smelled of the same flowers that had been in her bath. Leia drifted to sleep half caught up in a memory she knew wasnâ€™t hers, redolent with the scent of wildflowers.

Luke Skywalker was one of the kindest people Leia had ever met on any world. And even he could be a real ass sometimes.

It was an open field, empty and yellow gold. Not Alderaan, not Tatooine, and (thank goodness) not Coruscant. It almost looked like it could be on Naboo. Wherever it was, Leia had appeared here (only partially voluntarily), and her brother wasnâ€™t anywhere in sight.

â€œWhat do you want?â€ she demanded, lying back on the grass and staring up at the sky. It was bright blue, just after midday she thought. â€œI know you brought me here, so why wonâ€™t you tell me why?â€

â€œI kinda hoped we could just say hello first.â€

She was sitting before she could think through the motion, reaching out and almost shrieking when he actually caught her hand, pulling and helping her get to him, to crawl into his arms before she screamed and cried like she hadnâ€™t dared since she was a child. â€œLukeâ€¦â€

â€œI know,â€ he whispered, and she almost couldnâ€™t hear it, it sounded so faded and distant even though she was in his arms, him speaking into her ear. â€œBelieve me, Leia, I know.â€

â€œYou left me,â€ she wasnâ€™t sure he could hear her, the words were so choked, but heâ€™d always understood her better than other people, and she knew he had to be feeling her in the Forceâ€”

Everything. Everything here felt real, in ways that almost made it feel fake and false.

He stroked her hair, and she could hear the tears in his faint voice. â€œI know. I didnâ€™t mean to. Iâ€™m so sorry.â€

â€œYou canâ€™t go,â€ she was wailing, whining like a small child, and she knew and she refused to stop. â€œYou canâ€™t leave me ever again.â€

She felt more than heard him chuckle. â€œI wonâ€™t. I promise.â€

The feeling of raw longing was dancing over her skin. Painful, it crawled along the surface of her face, creeped down the back of her neck, licked over her chest and ribs, seeped into her bones, sang down her legs and flicked back up and across her arms, itching into her toes and fingers and burning on the tips of her nails. She almost imagined that her hair was burning too.

It was a surreal sensation.

Damn the Force.

â€œHhng,â€ Leia groaned, trying to roll over and only making it about halfway before flopping onto her back again. The pain flared, then faded slightly, leaving a tingling sensation behind. She imagined it would be back to pain the moment she tried to move again.

It was, but this time she made it onto the floor.

The thump summoned Shmi.

â€œLeia? Are you alright?â€

Hints of dawn creeped across the hall floor. Leia watched them for a few moments before forcing her eyes to move and look at her grandmother, unwilling to add dignity to the position of a single one of her other limbs.

It would be too much effort.

â€œHnneh.â€

Shmi actually chuckled, but held back her touch when Leia flinched. â€œThat good, was it?â€

Voice, she needed to voiceâ€”

â€œI saw him.â€

She sent it out in the Force and felt Shmiâ€™s shock as the words reached her mind, settled there without invitation or seeming origin. Then her grandmother just sighed, curled up comfortably next to Leia on the floor and gently laid her fingers over Leiaâ€™s, the softest echo of words coming back, â€œWill you miss him?â€

Which was not what Leia had been expecting. Especially since Shmiâ€™s mouth at least still worked. But, â€œHeâ€™s still there. Somewhere.â€

It was hard to explain, really. Hard to elaborate since she hadnâ€™t told Shmi about the sky growing in her heart, covered in darkness that had used to be stars. How it felt like one of those stars was now peeking out, shoving back the blackness, making it retreat.

And it sure as hell didnâ€™t cover why she felt like someone had lit her on fire or dragged her through the desert, leaving her as raw as she had felt the first day that she had arrived on Tatooine. But as sensation came back and pain receded, she knew she didnâ€™t need to. The words wouldnâ€™t have been adequate but the feelings, those Shmi understood. Even as they halfheartedly crawled their way across the floor from Leiaâ€™s mind and heart to her grandmotherâ€™s, oozing reluctance all along the way.

Exposing herself was a danger. Leia couldnâ€™t escape that. But in this moment, she didnâ€™t want to. It was too right.

â€œMay I see him?â€ Shmi whispered when sheâ€™d had time to understand, to absorb. When Leia immediately stiffened she added, â€œNot right now. Butâ€¦ someday?â€

It was a reasonable question. And Leia couldnâ€™t answer it. Because if she showed him, if she introduced him, she would have to tell Shmi the whole truth. And Leia was not ready to do that.

But Shmi wasnâ€™t just Leiaâ€™s grandmother, she was Lukeâ€™s. The one he had actually known about. Leia had no right to keep Shmi from him.

Not if he really was staying. Wherever he was.

â€œSomeday,â€ she managed to force out, the words scraping out of her throat, cutting past her lips. â€œIf he stays, Iâ€™ll introduce him. Someday.â€

If she ever figured out howâ€¦

Chapter End Notes

I've maybe been really excited for this chapter. Just a bit.

Resistance

As a reminder, this fic has been tagged with "politics" for a reason. You have been warned.

â€œLetâ€™s not confuse treason with disagreement,â€ Senator Organa said firmly, leaning forward. Actually, that was fundamentally untrue. Leia knew from plenty of personal experience that systems could dabble in rebellion by negotiating trade deals, arms trades, and travel agreements, all without ever lifting a weapon against their central government. The Alliance had relied on that to continue when they hadnâ€™t been able to get more offensive results.

But that was what it would do, especially at this point in the negotiations. Suggest that the Republic was willing to enforce their points by more violence, rather than solving the underlying problems. Problems that could be aided by first passing more restrictive legislation for certain trade guilds and commerce unions, and then having the physical organizations to enforce them.

Bless Shea, she really understood. It had taken some time and a few more meetings, but sheâ€™d won Shmi over with her persistence and straightforward acknowledgment of the problems most refugees faced. Being unwanted. Being foreign. Being displaced.

They were having a good deal of success on Herdessa, placing people in jobs more quickly than they had on Naboo. It was harder for families with children, the education options were more restricted. â€œMistress Leia, thereâ€™s been an explosion near the palace!â€

Shmi.

The thought made Leia pause, long enough Threepio almost crashed into her. She ignored his yelp and concerned questions as she followed the logic of that thought.

The people of Naboo might have smaller gaps between some of their classes, but the government in particular was run by a close knit community of family and old friends. Damn Palpatine. He must have known that.

â€œIs something the matter?â€ Joff Kareen hadnâ€™t been happy to see Leia and seemed more than happy to see she might be going, but he could read situations as well as any dubious entrepreneur could. No.

â€œTake my ship.â€ He seemed almost as shocked that heâ€™d offered as she was. But he persisted. â€œItâ€™s a newer class than yours, one thatâ€™s still technically in testing and development. Sheâ€™ll get you there faster, and sheâ€™s easier to maneuver in city traffic.â€

The blackness of space was speckled with stars. Stars that didnâ€™t blur together nearly enough for how fast they were going. Leia watched, taking the time to breathe and try not to panic. There was a white blue sheen reflecting off of Threepio and Leia tried to see if she could spot Luke in it. He wasnâ€™t consistent with the surfaces he appeared on, or when, but sheâ€™d seen him a few more times since that night, always with a smile, maybe with a wink or a nod.

She hadnâ€™t dreamed of him since that first time. But she knew she could again. She just needed to be not busy and with so much else to think about.

â€œOh definitely or something.â€

â€œWeâ€™re approaching atmo,â€ the pilot said, flipping switches and easing back into their seat. Leia shuffled a bit and let her head fall back, going limp rather than bracing for the transition. She found it easier on her ears during reentry.

And she wanted to hear her brother again.

â€œCouldâ€™ve fooled me.â€

It was still so distant, but this time she saw him too, as the ship arced and a sliver of sunlight caught the view port. He was smiling, but there was a tightness to his eyes. Mild, not panicking. Something had happened. Something not good, but not unspeakably bad either.

Not something he had to baby her by showing up for, hopefully.

â€œI promised.â€

His mouth didnâ€™t move, but the words were a little more clear this time, as if seeing him had brought him a bit closer.

He had promised. Promised he wouldnâ€™t leave her again. And that made her wonder just where exactly he was when she couldnâ€™t see him.

But that was a mystery she would have to unravel later, Leia realized as the angle of their descent sharpened. Right now, she needed to give her attention here.

Fishing

Absolutely not.

Philosophical disagreements.

Which was an easy thing to say given that Ondera was actually Inner Rim. But the wildness of the planet had always made its reputation sharp edged. How nice it probably felt, Leia thought, to have the attention of a man as powerful and smooth as a once Jedi.

As Our Dreams

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

It was two weeks before Ruwee was released from the hospital, less because of his injuries and more because of concern over the lingering threat. Like with the shooting, no one stepped forward to claim credit for the garden attack.

Leia had given up on sleep.

Instead, she was working full time in the Refugee Relief Movement offices, helping cover for PadmÃ©â€™s father and doing her part to make sure the project expansion was ready for its new trial phases.

â€œYouâ€™re just wearing yourself out.â€

It wasâ€¦ incredibly annoying how her brother could be silent for so long, not bothering to talk to her, and then just show up whenever he felt like it and start being a nag.

Then again, if dreaming was where she heard him clearest, it probably wasnâ€™t the best sign that he was now always around.

â€œSomeone has to do this,â€ Leia grumbled, making sure no one else in the room thought she was doing more than swear at her work. â€œAnd I donâ€™t see youâ€”â€œ

The words caught in her throat and Leia had to swallow when nothing she did brought them out. She didnâ€™t see him, not often. Even when she could hear him. She knew Luke was there, in an intangible way. But she couldnâ€™t see him and sometimesâ€¦

Sometimes she thought she was crazy.

â€œI love you,â€ the whisper wasnâ€™t in her ears or exactly in her mind. It was a thread that vibrated in her soul, sang in her heart, songs sheâ€™d forgotten she knew how to sing. Cut and dragged around her spirit like sand carried by a desert wind. A relief and a warning.

Well, she may not be ready to go to sleep, but sleep should probably happen at this point.

It only took a minute to save her documents and pack her things. â€œNo. Iâ€™m still working on a way to present the species specific data that doesnâ€™t make it too obvious we donâ€™t have a large enough pool to be statistically valuable while making it clear that they shouldnâ€™t base their efforts on our results. â€œAnd many of the children brought here speak mostly the language of their native planet,â€ Klara agreed, shaking her head. â€œYour mother and Threepio have been indispensable.â€

â€œAs always. Try and get some sleep tonight.â€

â€œSweet rest.â€

She said it using words Han had taught her, had whispered when he had been there to try and ease her own dreams away from haunting nightmares of pain and death. Dreams of thunder and fire. Leia knew how hard it was to escape from that, even once youâ€™d gotten used to it.

â€œGood plan.â€ The words werenâ€™t cocky, they stumbled too much for that. But Leia did manage a solid smile as she turned to leave.

They let Threepio fly them home. â€œWe have to go back.â€

â€œAnd makes the senator a greater target,â€ he snapped.

She really ought to stop baiting these people, but it was so hard sometimes. Their sense of impending doom was just too much to carry in these situations. â€œWeâ€™ll need to come up with a new plan,â€ Captain Typho was emphatic. â€œThere are too many people in the senate who are familiar with our old ones.â€

â€œOur friends are as trustworthy as ever,â€ PadmÃ© said, her tone soothing. â€œBut our patterns are more predictable. Unease rose again and there were awkward glances around the room. Advisor Brandes tittered, â€œA new plan does seem to be in order. I assume, for safety reasons, we donâ€™t need to be involved?â€

The nervous energy had Leia on edge, but she did agree with Advisor Brandes. Having made the decision to go, the fewer people knew what their plans were, the better.

Especially, â€œI donâ€™t think we need to inform Coruscant of any changes,â€ Leia suggested the moment the door to Padmeâ€™s office had slid shut and only her handmaidens, head of security, and Shmi were inside. â€œTheyâ€™re already aware that our shuttle is going to have an escort for additional security. And would prevent news from reaching a certain madman.

â€œIâ€™d already thought of that,â€ PadmÃ© admitted, settling into her chair. Leia only partially agreed, but she tried to keep quiet as CordÃ© and DormÃ© suggested steps that could be taken to contact Coruscant mid-flight, to further layer the deception. Captain Typho agreed to all of them, but insisted they needed at least two more guards, if not four, to act as cover.

â€œThey tried to shoot you and there was an explosion. Even wearing armored gowns isnâ€™t going to be enough if they try similar tactics.â€

And what Leia wouldnâ€™t give to have a chance to take a look at some of those. Sheâ€™d always been impressed that PadmÃ© could wear clothing that was so heavy. It had been thrilling to know some of that weight was subtle and practical.

â€œIâ€™m not putting more people than I need to in the line of fire,â€ PadmÃ© made each word a clipped decree. â€œAnd Iâ€™m not showing up looking scared. Dooku. PadmÃ© hadnâ€™t asked Leia to look into him, but she knew how to work Artoo around, and he had been helping DormÃ© and VersÃ© on that investigation. A few personal requests and small adventures were enough to get Artoo to tell Leia the whole tale, such as it was.

And at one point his apprentice had been Qui-Gon Jinn.

Yeah, if that wasnâ€™t the beginning of a nice revenge plot, Leia didnâ€™t know what fit.

And it looked like PadmÃ© wasnâ€™t either. Thank goodness.

â€œSince when are you trained as a bodyguard?â€ Captain Typho objected.

â€œNo.â€

â€œLeia,â€ even EirtaÃ© was trying to be gentle, and that, thatâ€”nothing could be worse. â€œDuring the shooting. You froze.â€

She had failed. There was something she had meant to do, a place she had meant to be, and she had failed to prove that she should be there.

(Again. Again and again, she wasnâ€™t enough, never enoughâ€¦)

â€œStrength now.â€ Shmiâ€™s hand was on Leiaâ€™s arm, offering support, her voice a gentle whisper in Leiaâ€™s mind. â€œIâ€™m with you.â€

â€œDo we?â€ Captain Typho was a threat. His whole aura was sharp and pointed at Leia. At Shmi. And she wouldnâ€™t let him hurt Shmi. â€œSeems like these attacks didnâ€™t start happening until after they showed up.â€

â€œThat isnâ€™t fair,â€ and it was EirtaÃ© that came to their defense. A surprise. â€œThings have been escalating in the Senate that have nothing to do with Leia. And she has no Separatist contacts.â€

â€œBy your leave, Senator,â€ Leia offered a half bow, still holding Shmiâ€™s arm. Shmi made her own farewells and let Leia lead her out, saying nothing as they wandered the halls.

Leia didnâ€™t look at the windows as she walked. The sun was past its zenith, dragging reflections of light everywhere. She knew if she looked she would see him, following their steps, worried as he watched her.

But there. When he hadnâ€™t been there before. Shmi on her right, her brother on her left, Leia at least knew that she didnâ€™t walk alone.

Chapter End Notes

I mentioned this when I first posted, but my knowledge of the Star Wars EU is dubious at best and if you recognize things from it, it's either a complete accident, or I know just barely enough about whatever I've mentioned to borrow the loose outlines and then make changes for the purpose of this fic. I appreciate the details that people share or corrections they make. I like knowing what my readers expect and new things I learn may (but probably won't) impact the fic. If you notice I go off the rails a lot, well, you've been warned. Again.

On a completely different note, it's always fun to read your guesses about what things are going on and what may happen next. It helps me keep up my own enthusiasm. Thank you all for taking your time to read this. I'm glad you're enjoying it.

Taste of Ashes

Making food was hard, but right now that helped. It gave Leia something to focus on so she could ignore the turmoil just under her skin, inexplicable in its intensity, jealous and enraged at being excluded.

Which was stupid. Sheâ€™d practically kicked herself out.

â€œYou want to stir it,â€ Shmi murmured from where she was cutting vegetables. â€œNot beat it.â€

Well, so much for containing her mood. â€œYes, Grandmother.â€

There was a spark of pleasure from Shmi as Leia said the word, as there always was, and it was a relief and a balm to her soul. A touch of the anger dissipated, leaving humiliation in its wake.

Sheâ€™d thrown a tantrum. In the middle of PadmÃ©â€™s office. Like a spoiled child, all because she hadnâ€™t been allowed to chase danger. Never mind that PadmÃ© and the handmaidens were right. Ignore that if she kept being in the wrong place at the wrong time Captain Typhoâ€™s accusations might become justified as suspicions.

Sheâ€™d whined like a petty princess because sheâ€™d wanted an adventure and she couldnâ€™t have it.

â€œItâ€™s more than that.â€ Lukeâ€™s voice was only the barest brush against her senses, and she was almost petulant enough to ignore it. She knew herself better than he did.

Except.

Except that Luke did understand her. Sometimes because they were similar, and others because they were different. Opposites even. He made himself understand her because he loved her, and he forgave her because he saw her as worthy of that love.

Even when she doubted herself.

Well, if she needed someone to bounce ideas off of, â€œI should have just kept my mouth shut, shouldnâ€™t I?â€

Sliding the vegetables into the pot, Shmi flicked a half glance at Leia before saying, â€œMaybe.â€ Well, there it waâ€” â€œOr maybe not.â€ A hum. â€œI hadnâ€™t realized that Captain Typho felt so strongly about our presence.â€

Leia hadnâ€™t either, and that bothered her. She should be better than this. Not being in the Empire was making her slip. The stakes were just as high, higher here. She couldnâ€™t afford a misstep. â€œMaybe heâ€™s right. At leastâ€¦ maybe being here puts PadmÃ© in more danger.â€

â€œHow?â€

Since discussing time travel was out of the question, â€œWe both are sensitive to the Force. It responds to us. Thingsâ€¦ happen.â€

But it didnâ€™t feel right as she thought about it. PadmÃ© was surrounded by people that manipulated the Force. Even if she wasnâ€™t especially close to any of the Jedi (and Leia wasnâ€™t sure where exactly to put Obi-Wan on that scale), the Chancellor was a Sith and very powerful.

So even if Leia had just left PadmÃ© aloneâ€¦

â€œI cannot think of a single thing,â€ Shmi said solemnly, â€œthat you or I have done to bring PadmÃ© misfortune, by our presence or our acts. She is brave and capable and dangerous. And more than happy to be a target without any input from us.â€

Fair enough. Bail would have put PadmÃ© in charge of fighting the Military Creation Act even if Leia hadnâ€™t arrived. It was something Leiaâ€™s father had spoken of a few times, that PadmÃ© had been deeply involved, even in that other life.

And she was making plenty of people mad with her position on it, regardless of Leiaâ€™s existence.

Still, â€œYouâ€™re right. But I still should have kept my mouth shut.â€

â€œDo you think it is wrong to want to come to her defense?â€

No. Leia had been raised with at least as strong a sense of responsibility as PadmÃ©. Alderaan was gone, it had been a long time since sheâ€™d functionally carried the full weight and burden of a princess. But putting other peopleâ€™s lives before her ownâ€¦

Sheâ€™d been doing that on instinct her whole life.

â€œWhat I want doesnâ€™t matter.â€

The words carried a cadence that was so flat is was almost numb. She rarely said them out loud, but in her mind? They circled over and over and over. For every fallen ally, every lost battle, every dream of Alderaan.

Of Luke and Chewie and Han.

What she wanted was often impossible. What was more important was what she had.

And what she didnâ€™t.

And she didnâ€™t have PadmÃ©â€™s trust. Or the handmaidensâ€™. Definitely not Captain Typhoâ€™s.

â€œLeiaâ€¦â€ Shmi wiped her hands, watching Leia and being watched in return. The frown wasnâ€™t just on her mouth or in her eyes. Something about it had settled into her spirit. â€œWhere do you go when you are lost?â€

Home.

At least, that was where she had used to go. To her parentâ€™s room to hide under their blankets, even when she was too old to need such a thing. To the Falcon, and to Han and Luke and Chewie directly when it wasnâ€™t enough to just be on the ship.

To Lando, those last few days before sheâ€™d come here, trying to find in him the peace that she had known.

To Shmi.

â€œYou,â€ she whispered, and Shmiâ€™s eyes softened.

She stepped forward, taking Leiaâ€™s hands, bringing each one to her lips and then pressing them to her forehead. There was a whisper of words Leia recognized but didnâ€™t know, some sort of blessing. And then Shmi spoke. â€œI will always be here for you. You may come to me whenever you need. â€œThere is a place you can put your anger. I can show you.â€

The memory of those words made her shiver, almost wrench. Heâ€™d said heâ€™d be gone, gone and gone and finally for forever. But she still remembered, still couldnâ€™t forget.

But Shmiâ€™s hands held hers and Leia knew what she had to do.

â€œI should probably talk to my brother,â€ she admitted in a whisper, and Shmi smiled. Sweet and sad.

The last spices had just been added when the door chimed. Leia froze, tasting spoon halfway to her mouth.

At this time of night. After what had happened.

â€œShmi, donâ€™t,â€ Leia hissed, but her grandmother just leveled a Look and headed straight for the door.

Since she was avoiding looking behind her, Leia couldnâ€™t shoot Shmi a return look, so she kept her eyes focused on the pot. One more minute of simmering, and if PadmÃ© was going to eat it then Leia couldnâ€™t actually let it burn.

So tempting.

PadmÃ© was really, really good with her words. Leia was a little jealous.

It hurt, and Leia couldnâ€™t be sure all the pain she was feeling was just her own. But she had put in so much effort on Coruscant and sheâ€™d thought it had been enough to seal her place working with PadmÃ©. In the Senate, not just helping Shmi back at home.

â€œI know youâ€™re working with the RRM, but unlike Shmi, you are still on our payroll.â€ PadmÃ©â€™s voice was carefully even. â€œAnd even if you werenâ€™tâ€”Leia I know you froze after the shooting, but you didnâ€™t at the banquet. And dammit, why, why had she done it?

â€œThat doesnâ€™t mean we donâ€™t need you.â€

â€œNo,â€ PadmÃ© admitted, putting the last of the bowls away. â€œBut I was hoping I could run what we have by you and see what you think.â€

Dishes were clean, leftover food was put away, Shmi was doing a final pass over the tabletop. Leia leaned against the counters and made herself look PadmÃ© in the eyes. â€œIâ€™m going to say no. And Iâ€™m going to do it because Captain Typho doesnâ€™t know youâ€™re here.â€

â€œFor a good reason.â€

â€œYouâ€™re not going to betray us. Itâ€™s never even occurred to you, you arenâ€™t a plantâ€”â€œ

â€œAnd heâ€™s still right,â€ Leia sighed, rubbing her face. â€œLook, Iâ€™m pretty sure no oneâ€™s bugged our apartment. â€œSo come to the office,â€ PadmÃ© shifted, settling in for a fight.

Leia hesitated, and then decided not to give it to her. â€œI decide whoâ€™s on my staff,â€ PadmÃ© protested.

â€œBut the Queen can veto your choices, if not directly then by threatening to remove you from your seat for poor judgement. And youâ€™re right, you are important to this upcoming vote. It ached to say the words, haunted her. By stepping back she was making a deliberate choice. If something went wrong she wouldnâ€™t be there. Would never know if it would have been different if sheâ€™d come to help.

If she did go, everything could still go wrong. And there was no way to know which would be worse in advance.

Alderaan. Alderaan and choices, and every choice she had made to be a spy, a damn good one, up to that point. Every choice to antagonize Tarkin (and there was every evidence things would have been worse if she hadnâ€™t pushed him), the decision to accept the mission to Scarif, lying to Darth Vader, sending Artoo off with the plans, letting the Imperials follow them back to Yavin.

Fighters had died. The Larses had died. Alderaan had died. Part of Leia had died with it.

And if she had to go back and do it all again?

Well, sheâ€™d certainly try and change it. She was responsible like that. But she knew better than to assume that doing the right thing always got you what you wanted. Or the best outcomes.

Or that you could guess what someone evil would use to hurt you, if given the chance.

She watched PadmÃ© consider her arguments and cross her arms. â€œI hate it when you make a good point.â€

â€œDonâ€™t lie, thatâ€™s the only reason you like me.â€

Everything around PadmÃ© softened. â€œNot the only reason. But itâ€™s a good one.â€ A deep breath. â€œAre you sure?â€

No, dammit, she was never sure. And she wasnâ€™t like Luke who could not only use the Force but had an uncanny knack to walk down paths with unnaturally low casualties (minus himself, of course). Any reaching or feeling Leia did only extended so far, and while her general sense of everything to do with this trip and this vote was ominous, it wasnâ€™t like she had a clear vision of what could be done to change that.

It was almost tempting to ask the Jedi. Almost.

But even Lukeâ€™s visions hadnâ€™t been perfect, and, again, you never knew what someone evil could pull out of nowhere to hurt you.

Leia already knew what they were. Advisor Brandes was a dreadful gossip.

She walked along the halls, quiet enough that she could hear herself think. And what thoughts they were. She remembered, vaguely, coming here several months ago. How everything had felt big and bright and polished. A little foreign, a little frustrating.

Shmi had been afraid.

Now she was walking these halls on her own, or with her own friends, arguing with Council ministers and proposing budgets and legislation. It was a startling difference if Leia let herself think about it. Shmi had adapted very, very quickly.

Which shouldnâ€™t have been a surprise. Sheâ€™d traded hands many times as a slave. Her grounded, focused nature had to also be flexible. It was a matter of survival.

"Lost?"

The tone was earnest, but Leia knew Rani was teasing. As the guard approached Leia slowed, ignoring the subtle wave of hostile curiosity Rani carried. Captain Typho was being much more careful about letting Leia wander around unaccompanied. She should have seen his accusations coming.

Sloppy.

Still, he was willing to let her be watched by a potentially friendly party. "Just wandering. The gardens are bitâ€¦ off-putting right now."

To say the least.

Rani considered that as they walked the halls, Leia occasionally waving at people she recognized or nodding. There was an air of tension in the building, the city really, that hadn't settled over the last few weeks. "Do you think we should be afraid?"

"No," Leia tasted the truth of the words as she spoke and wished they had been reassuring to her companion. "Not yet. One incident is reason for caution and action. Two is reason to hunt. More than thatâ€¦ then you should be worried. Especially if you don't have any hints of how it happened."

"The senator was targeted on Coruscant."

A casual observation, but it did mean they were up to two, if that was how you were counting.

Leia certainly was. "Which is why we're hunting."

"Senator Amidala says the hunt for the shooter has been taken from the Jedi. And we don't have the resources to look off planet here."

Which was almost as embarrassing as it was frightening. "Even after the invasion?"

Rani shrugged. "We've been rebuilding."

Which was fine. But that didn't mean you left your backdoor open for an enemy to just walk through again. "Well, you may need to redirect some of that effort. Because off planet is probably where you'll need to look. More likely off system," she added before Rani could make a comment about the miners on Ohma-D'un.

"You think so?"

"If they're after the senator? That would be my best guess. We'd hear more restlessness from the civilians if it were coming from here."

"The people love her here."

Leia bit back words until she could use an even tone. "Yes. Which is why we would be hearing about any danger if there were murmurs floating around. Someone would have noticed and reported it, especially with there already being attempts on her life."

"Unless they were being silenced," Rani suggested. And there was more than a hint of suspicion now, and that surprised Leia. What the hell had Typho been saying about her?

"In which case," she reached for calm, calm that was a defense and a weapon when she walked among enemies, everything contained and tight, wrapped like safety around her, "you would have bodies or missing persons reports. I'm not asking," she added when Rani's silence became sullen. "The work I'm doing here isn't the chase."

"The Captain says you volunteered to do a solo hunt on Coruscant."

Yeah, definitely an accusation. Well, "Because I'm very good at finding things and people that are trying to be hidden," Leia said calmly. "I've had practice."

"Where?"

So many places. "Mostly Mid and Outer Rim, but the underbelly of Coruscant is at least fifty percent refugees from those zones, living in squalor and surviving by introducing old habits. Have you ever been there? It not like the seedier parts of Theed, or some of the cities further out from here where there's still more agriculture than industry and they listen more to local noble lines than the central government. It's layers and layers of skyscrapers slowly descending into darkness. Roads that open up into chasms and pits where you can't always see the bottom. They have no daylight, they get no rain. Everything is piped down through old industry that wasn't pretty enough for the top dwellers anymore. And every year, the corruption grows higher, because why replace when you can just keep building up and painting over it?"

Why run a local government to solve problems when you want to corrupt the whole galaxy? Why not let the Jedi sit on a hive of death and despair, so wrapped up in their peace and their comfort that they couldn't feel that the very ground that they were built on was crumbling away, seeping into darkness and ash?

Why kill a man when you could sit back and watch him kill himself? Just take what he loved.

"You hate it." Rani sounded so surprised.

Leia stopped, met Rani's gaze full on. "It's a pattern. A pattern you use to break people, to exploit them, to beat them into submission. You don't fight them, you make them fight the world. You make them fight themselves. Yes, I hate it. I hate it with everything that I am. That's why I came here. To fight it."

"PadmÃ© wants to help people," and now Rani sounded uncertain.

"Which is why I'm helping her. The senator is a good person. We don't always agree on how things need to be done, but she wants to make the galaxy better. To stop people from being murdered and exploited. So yes, I volunteered to go on the hunt. The first time she was threatened. Because she wants to fix things, not paint over them. And that makes her a target."

One of many, so many, and still not enough. And Leia's efforts would only get her so far. She needed a better network (not that Shmi wasn't already helping Leia with that one, even while they were stuck here) and she needed better allies, and she neededâ€”

She needed Alderaan.

She was intimately familiar with their resources and their connections. She would be devastating if she could use them as leverage.

Unfortunately, to do that, she'd need to approach (Paâ€”) Senator Organa.

And right now, that was not going to happen.

Something in Rani was easing. Her smile was more relaxed as they started walking again. "I think you underestimate the handmaidens. They've been with the Senator for years. Many of them were with her during the invasion. They're nothing to scoff at."

"Oh, I'm not scoffing. As far as a dedicated personal guard, they're pretty much the best."

"But you're still worried?"

Shoving her hands into her pockets, Leia looked up at the ceiling. Studied the stone arches and crests that supported tons and tons or architecture, that had for at least hundreds of years. "Someone has to be."

"Generally," Rani was sober now, following Leia's gaze, trying to guess what she was thinking, "that's the Guard's job. Or just Security's in general."

Leia couldn't help but smile. "I like worrying. It keeps me sane."

It was clear Rani didn't understand or share the sentiment, but Leia had won over another ally. One who would hopefully convince Captain Typho to stop acting like an idiot.

Even if it was to keep PadmÃ© safe.

The hardest part of PadmÃ© leaving two days later wasn't being excluded from the crew, or knowing that there was danger, or wondering how the vote would go.

No, the hardest part was that Leia wasn't allowed to be on the landing platform to say goodbye. Forâ€¦ security reasons.

CordÃ© and EirtaÃ© had overruled Typho's concern about letting PadmÃ© visit Shmi and Leia the night before, sharing another meal and doing their formal farewells then. But he'd been adamant that he didn't want either of them near the ship before it took off.

Especially Leia.

Well, fine then.

"You're not amused." She was on a call with Senator Organa and Senator Mothma, going over notes on things she'd been working on that weren't directly related to the MCA vote. Another sop PadmÃ© had offered as a peace offering.

A rather bitter one, in Leia's opinion. "I don't think he's being unreasonably cautious," she admitted, biting back the desire to confide in Senator Organa even more (a habit as natural as breathing, even when for years he'd been deaâ€”). "PadmÃ©'s been vacillating on how serious she thinks this is, at least when she talks about it. But she knows, and that's why she didn't fight the captain. Better to be safe than sorry."

"Even if it means being offensive?" Damn, it was so hard to concentrate when he did things that were too familiar. He was testing her, and she knew only one way to respond.

"That depends on how much trust you have, and shared ideals. The senator knows even if I'm being implicated that I understand, under the circumstance, and can be patient."

"How generous." It was hard to tell if Senator Mothma's mouth was twitching towards amused or irritated. She'd always had excellent facial control. "You will not be joining us then, this session?"

"We're not sure yet," Leia said, although in reality the answer was at some point she would be going back to Coruscant, with PadmÃ©'s permission or without. There was too much that needed to be done. Andâ€¦ She needed an in with the Jedi. More than just casually knowing Master Kenobi, as convenient as that had been. "We'll have to see how things go with the vote and if my expertise will be of value, or if I'm better placed here."

She wasn't. Everyone knew it. Queen Jamillia had made several comments about it, in her own subtle way, when Captain Typho had explained that Leia would be remaining. She may have been focusing her research on trade routes and supplies (a not irrelevant topic with impending war on the horizon), but Leia's experience was broad and deep. And she had good political habits.

Most of the time.

"Senator Darsana was asking after you," Senator Organa said. And his expression was closed enough Leia had a hard time parsing it. "He seemed disappointed that you weren't coming back."

"I asked Threepio to pass along a message," Leia answered, wishing she could get the meeting back on track. "I'm hoping they get there in time for him to receive it before the vote."

Who knew what would happen after. If PadmÃ© and her contingent in the Loyalist Committee managed to stop the war efforts, there could be seriously bad blood between Naboo and many systems. And Leia knew, knew, that any number were waiting for the results in order to decide if they were going to leave or not.

What the Republic implied would make a huge difference.

"I'll see if I can reach out to him and let him know to expect a visit," Senator Organa promised, and Leia was worried to see there was something of relief in his answer. "He's been very busy these past weeks, and it might help to speed things along."

Or just open up the path. "Thank you. I would appreciate that." She hesitated. "Were there any messages you needed delivered here? I'd be happy to pass them along."

A stupid offer. He was only an associate to PadmÃ©, and while respectful enough to know details of her culture wasn't friends with her government.

But, "Actually, yes. If you could pass a message to Shmi Skywalker or Ruwee Naberrie," and wasn't that an interesting order, "I'd appreciate some additional details on the kinds of craft they have access to for moving refugees. We've already got a pretty robust system for handling refugees to Alderaan, but we have flight schools, pilots and ships that we can offer to any other systems, if they meet your standards."

Which would win Shmi over, Leia knew. And realized in that moment that she hadn't introduced them, had actively avoided it, because she wanted Shmi to think well of Bail Organa. Because Leia loved him and couldn't say it and didn't want Shmi to look at him and dismiss him as an idealist, passive Core-worlder.

"I'd be happy to pass that along. Should they reach out to you directly, or to one of your organizations?â€

"Me," Senator Organa said firmly, which made Leia jealous and warm all at once. He was being protective again. Of people she loved. "I know enough of what we have to offer to process the relevant information. And to make sure if we have what you need that they get in touch with the right people as quickly as possible." He hesitated and Leia tasted fear, even through the call. "Whether or not the Senate approves the formation of an army, we need better connections between systems for moving people, especially in an emergency. I'd rather not delay helping with that."

And as streamlined as many organizations were on Alderaan, it never hurt to have a little pressure coming from the top to move things along. "I'll make sure they know to reach out to you as soon as possible. Now, did you want to go over pirating rates on major versus minor hyperlanes? Or price variance on common trade goods in the last twelve years?â€

The two senators exchanged a brief look before Senator Organa said, "Both."

Where Our Scars

It was the middle of the night, the depths of darkness, when Leia woke, gasping for breath, drowning in a vision of fire.

Trying to calm her racing heart, she breathed, pushed on her face, forcing the tears to stay just under her lashes. Luke, Chewie, Hanâ€¦ She breathed and breathed and breathed and tried not to remember the exact details of the dream. The green toned light from the view port under heavy laser fire. The feel of heat and pressure as everything had exploded around her, too hot and loud to survive, too fake to actually take her life.

She couldnâ€™t handle more tears, but it was so hard to forget if she wouldnâ€™t open her eyes. She just kept seeing it, again and again.

â€œLeia, let it go.â€

The words were almost too quiet, the sentiment unwanted, the toneâ€¦

Not the deserts that had been her mother and father, when blood relations had been a dream. Not the secret springs of water, or the wheezing machines that desperately pulled moisture from the air. Not the boy who loved her in place of his mother. Not the man that she called husband.

None of it was home anymore. Even though those things still held the biggest places in her heart.

And she felt guilty for that, Leia guessed. That the people who had loved her, who set her free, werenâ€™t her home anymore.

Like Alderaan, Leia thought bleakly. She would always wander blind into a memory of that place that had raised her, shaped her, been her cage and her shelter in turn. That had held all the people that mattered to her most.

It used to be that when Leia meditated, she tucked all of herself away into a tiny ball, and anything that escaped she poked and wrestled with until she could get it back in. Marred by Memories

It wasnâ€™t true. It wasnâ€™t possible.

â€œâ€”hmi?â€

There was a buzz from the comm on the floor and Leia had summoned it before she could think the action through. â€œWeâ€™re here,â€ the words were breathless, but they did come. â€œWeâ€™reâ€”Can you repeat?â€

There was a pause before SabÃ©â€™s voice asked, â€œCan you please verify your clearance?â€

The tone, the words, flipped that switch that Leia had so often relied on. Part of her was wailing, consumed with disbelief and grief. The other stepped forward and recited the necessary codes, no hesitation in her voice. â€œCan you please repeat the report?â€

Shmi winced at every word. Leia didnâ€™t know why (military, Shmi wasnâ€™t military), but she couldnâ€™t solve that right now. There was a more immediate crisis. â€œWe have a report from Coruscant. There was another assassination attempt at the landing platform. The senatorâ€™s body double was killed.â€

And they werenâ€™t saying it was CordÃ©. Shmi had just assumed. Butâ€”

CordÃ© was dead.

And Leia would enjoy every minute of it.

Oh look, it's the return of the Jedi...

Remembering

Shmi had dinner ready by the time Leia got home. The house smelled of wildflowers and incense, which seemed odd to Leia until she remembered how thoroughly Shmi had researched Naboo grief rituals. Sheâ€™d probably already performed her own Tatooine remembrances. These were respect to CordÃ© in a form that would have been familiar to the woman.

That didnâ€™t diminish the tears that pricked at Leiaâ€™s eyes as she spotted the small bouquets in each room, near windows or doors.

She needed to hurry and eat before grief demanded her full attention.

â€œLeia?â€

Shmi seemed better and worse now. Her rituals had calmed her, but that just left space to feel the empty hole where a person was supposed to be andâ€”

Later. Hold. Just for a few more minutes, hold.

â€œDo you need me to set the table?â€

Mundane tasks to act as a shield for a few more minutes. Food to mouth. Dishes washed. Kitchen cleaned, everything put away.

It was stupid, but the moment they finished, Leia felt the emptiness of the room and it was oppressive. Task finished and done, now to rest, empty and silentâ€¦

Sheâ€™d been putting this off too long.

No tears while she lit her own sticks of incense, mind reciting the prayers for the dead, violently carried away (and how appropriate, that the Naboo had a separate remembrance for that). No tears as she made her way to the couch, stopping to touch the blossoms Shmi had bought, fingering silk soft petals and catching the scent of summer and sun and gentleness.

CordÃ© had been hard, Leia thought as she curled up on the couch, knees pulled up and in, making a barrier between her and the world. Hard, beneath the soft beauty that had so closely imitated PadmÃ©. Not unkind, but strong. Resilient. Sheâ€™d joined the handmaidens after the invasion, resolve and competence covering for the lack of experience she had compared to the others. SabÃ© had told story after story that day as theyâ€™d processed data coming in from Coruscant, as theyâ€™d prepared letters for grieving families, made calls, arranged for financial compensation, began preliminary work on memorials. It wasnâ€™t just CordÃ© they had lost, there were four others that had been on the landing ramp, two pilots, almost a half dozen droids on the ship.

And between each task, Leia had allowed herself to be an outlet for a grief so personal, it had almost stolen her breath away. SabÃ© had stepped aside as PadmÃ©â€™s primary double when CordÃ© had proved to be up to the task. Two hands, a right and a left, one more suited to Naboo, the other to the Senate. The relationship that PadmÃ© had described when she had shut down Leiaâ€™s attempts to join their retuning party wasnâ€™t just a two-person partnership. It had been three people, one always apart from the others, standing a little distant to watch what couldnâ€™t be seen from up close.

SabÃ© had missed the attack. From what she didnâ€™t say, it was clear that she saw CordÃ©â€™s death as her fault. Her cowardice. Her incompetence.

And CordÃ© and PadmÃ© had paid for it.

â€œYouâ€™re wandering,â€ Shmi said, invading Leiaâ€™s space and sitting right next to her, wrapping an arm around her shoulders. â€œIt will still be here, no matter where you go.â€

Right, it was time to face her grief, not avoid it by empathizing with SabÃ©â€™s. â€œIâ€™ve only known her a few months,â€ Leia whispered. â€œAnd stillâ€¦â€

It wasnâ€™t the grief of losing her brother, or her parents (or Han). But stars and fire, it hurt. Hurt because.

Because the moment she looked, that she was honest, she didnâ€™t just see grief. The darkness she expected was intertwined, interwoven, with red bright as blood.

Rage.

Twisted together with her sadness, with the truth of â€œis goneâ€ was a spite and malice that almost took her breath away.

It was shameful, to not make a pure space for CordÃ©â€™s grief. But Leia couldnâ€™t do it. Couldnâ€™t let go of the rage and the fire that coiled around her, seeped into her bones.

Or maybeâ€¦ maybe the fire had always been there. Banked sometimes by grief or hopelessness, reduced to the slightest flickering embers. But always to return. When grief had passed, or more blood was spilled.

Or when the cold coalesced in the darkness, shimmering blue, offering revenge.

Offering peace. Offering purpose.

â€œFamily,â€ Lukeâ€™s voice was the barest, faintest whisper. â€œOffering family.â€

Damn him, he was right. And she couldnâ€™t deal with that, on top of everything else.

â€œYou should talk about it,â€ Shmiâ€™s voice cut through the spiral, grounded Leia like the arm around her shoulders, the warm weight pressed against her side. â€œYou need to talk about it.â€

â€œNot now,â€ Leia whispered. â€œNot yet.â€

She thought Shmi would stay silent, but her grandmother asked, â€œAre you sure?â€

And Leia wasnâ€™t. Wasnâ€™t, because, â€œI hate them. I hate them all. All of them, taking people away from me.â€

It was so easy to blame Palpatine. But if he were the only oneâ€¦

â€œItâ€™s not fair,â€ she continued, burying her face in Shmiâ€™s shoulder, seeking comfort and refusing to be comforted. â€œItâ€™s not fair that I keep losing them. Whatâ€™s the point of even trying ifâ€”ifâ€”â€œ

Gods and storms, she was her fatherâ€™s daughter.

And she hated herself even more.

Because CordÃ©â€™s death wasnâ€™t SabÃ©â€™s fault, or PadmÃ©â€™s, or even the Emperorâ€™s.

It was Leiaâ€™s.

She just hadnâ€™t figured out how yet.

Escalations

The building was quiet. Oddly quiet.

Anakin was used to the constant hum of the Jedi Temple, which had its lulls of course. But there were nocturnal inhabitants of the Temple as well as those that were coming and going on missions on the schedule of other planets and systems. The communication lines were always manned, and Anakin remembered the few times he and Obi-Wan had been asked to take an overnight shift, probably as punishment for something. Which meant Anakin could spend time with PadmÃ© and Obi-Wan wouldnâ€™t be there to embarrass him. It was a real relief.

Leia was pissed. Leia was pissed because the last few days had been a cosmic horror and joke, all in one go, and because PadmÃ© was pissed and even systems away Leia was fully prepared to channel that as far as it would go because she was not above being pissed on behalf of two people.

Or twenty.

At a guess, Queen Jamillia was pissed too, but was too good at her job to say anything about it. Leia really wanted to be Queen Jamillia when she grew up.

SabÃ© was also pissed, and so was Captain Panaka, but SabÃ© was pissed because she didnâ€™t think a couple of Jedi were good enough at their job and Captain Panaka was pissed because SabÃ© kept letting Leia come to updates and overruled anyone who suggested it should be otherwise.

One plus to the last few days, Leia and SabÃ© were becoming fast friends.

â€œYou remind me of PadmÃ©,â€ SabÃ© had said at one point. â€œBut with more proactive intentions of punching people in the face.â€

Which was an impressive observation because Leia, in point of fact, hadnâ€™t actually punched anybody yet. But it was probably true. PadmÃ© had something of an exponential violence scale where she mostly just wanted to yell at people louder and louder until she wanted to shoot them dead. â€œWhat do you mean theyâ€™re sending her back?â€

â€œThey havenâ€™t told us much, but what they do know is there is still a bounty hunter loose, and one who may be able to hire others. The planet just isnâ€™t safeâ€”â€œ

â€œYes, I think we can.â€

Tip the Scales

In the silence between dusk and dawn, anything could happen, Luke had once told her.

Which had bewildered Leia, because she hadnâ€™t lived in places where the night was a time of quiet. Having been on Tatooine, she wasnâ€™t sure it was actually silent there either.

But she got the message.

Which was why she was awake in the middle of the night, curled up on the edge of her roof, warm drink in hand, counting the stars. Waiting for something to happen. SabÃ© hadnâ€™t called Leia yet, but it was only a matter of time. PadmÃ© should be up by now, and while Captain Typho would try and delay the argument, DormÃ© at least would make sure that things moved along as quickly as possible.

Not to mention at some point the Jedi would have to explain what they wanted.

All Leia had to do was wait, and try not to fall asleep.

Not like that was hard. Sheâ€™d been channeling so much energy in the last few days it was a miracle she had gotten any sleep at all. Although Shmiâ€™s presence was naturally soothing enough it shouldnâ€™t have been that much of a surprise. And the rest was good, because it meant Leia was ready for now, much more than she would have been if she hadnâ€™t slept at all.

â€œYouâ€™re gonna get yourself into trouble,â€ Luke sounded far too smug for Leia to be worried.

â€œAnd where did I learn that?â€

â€œUh, who rescued whom off a moon sized space station? I did not teach you how to get into trouble.â€

"The guy whose sister got herself suck on a moon sized space station. I wouldn't have been there if you weren't."

"Yes you would have."

"I'd have flown with the fighters to blow it up, later. I was on the station because I had to rescue you."

"Don't lie. Han complained for years that you never would have ended up on that thing if anyone had told him what was going on. You were heading for Alderaan, not me."

"I was coming for you," Leia could imagine Luke pulling a mock version of the face he'd used to make at her, when they'd first met and she could tell she was the first pretty girl heâ€™d met that he hadn't grown up with. "Ben's job was to get to Alderaan."

"The point isâ€”"

"The point is you were a rebel spy trying to steal plans for the Empire's secret weapon right out from under them. You were going to be there regardless of if I was coming.â€

â€œMaybe I wasn'tâ€¦â€ Leia muttered, sipping thoughtfully. It was so hard to parse, in retrospect, how much of her life had been influenced by her connection with the Force, and to Luke.

There were some things she could be sure of. The longing during her childhood for someone to be standing beside her, someone she knew she missed. The dreams, nightmares really, that were so real and painful she couldnâ€™t remember them when she woke. The edge of fear in her life that they had brought had been real. She may have attributed it to the undercurrent of her parents running a rebellion, but with hindsight, Leia knew better.

Normal people didnâ€™t go around that afraid of fire jumping out at them from shadows.

But her violent dislike of the Emperor, her discontent at the unfairness in the galaxy, her friendship with Pooja Naberrie, her tendency to occasionally leap without looking or even to plan ahead and still end up in catastrophically life threatening situations, those werenâ€™t Force things. â€œOf the two of us,â€ Leia mused, frustrated and sad, â€œI was the one who grew up in a giant palace with a full security force, overprotective parents, and the knowledge of a network of spies and insurgents who would have done just about anything to spit in the eyes of the Empire. And they had, which was the funnier part. But her brotherâ€™s voice was actually getting clearer, sharper now, as he voiced his disagreement. â€œAnd here? Whoâ€™s going to come for you?â€

â€œShmi would,â€ Leia said, although she could still see his point. Shmi would come, but what could she do? â€œPadmÃ©â€”â€œ

PadmÃ© might come. Probably would. If she knew where to find Leia. If it wasnâ€™t more important for PadmÃ© to be somewhere else, doing something else. If she was available, then she would come.

â€œYou know they would come, if they could. But youâ€™re not counting on it. If you get trapped, stuck alone with him, you wonâ€™t hesitate. Youâ€™ll do what needs to be done.â€

â€œLeia,â€ Lukeâ€™s voice was quieter, but not fainter. It was solid. Serious. â€œYouâ€™ll do whatever is necessary.â€

â€œAnd donâ€™t look back.â€

â€œYou stood up to Father,â€ Luke was so gentle, even when she couldnâ€™t see him. â€œYou stood up to Jabba. You stood up to anybody.â€

â€œSo I will now?â€ She was so tired. Not in her body, which was still buzzing, waiting for the next moment to move, to attack. But in her soul. She justâ€¦ she just wanted to rest.

â€œYou still havenâ€™t stopped. I donâ€™t think anything can make you.â€

It lookedâ€¦ kind of a lot like the world she was currently in, actually.

â€œDammit.â€

Luke laughed.

â€œYou think she should stay?â€ Anakin didnâ€™t care one way or another as long as no one was stupid enough to try and tell him to stop protecting her. And the Council had actually given him this assignment to do alone. As far as preparing for knighthood, that was a good thing. Right?

â€œI think we donâ€™t know who hired the killers, and sheâ€™s been targeted on Naboo before.â€ At Anakinâ€™s twitch in the Force, Obi-Wan carefully added, â€œShe didnâ€™t have you then, and she did survive all the attempts. But it would be inconvenient for her to be attacked again.â€

Off the Leash

â€œWell, Iâ€™m sure you look prettier when youâ€™re not backlit.â€

That was an eye roll. â€œOh, Iâ€™m sure heâ€™s paying attention.â€

â€œLeiaâ€¦â€

Right, she needed to reign it in. She wished she could say sheâ€™d only ever used them on Han, or strangers. But there were a couple she had perfected for handling Luke. If PadmÃ© saw Anakin as more of an innocent, floundering admirer.

Leia did not.

â€œNo, itâ€™s fine. Actually itâ€™sâ€¦ kind of nice? Donâ€™t tell him I said that.â€

There was a part of Leiaâ€™s brain that processed those words logically. That said, PadmÃ© was stressed, sheâ€™d been feeling beaten and unwanted. Another part of Leiaâ€¦ twisted.

Since she couldnâ€™t get a handle on it, couldnâ€™t wrap her mind around it to figure out what it was and why exactly it bothered her, Leia let it go. Tucked it away into a corner of her brain to figure out on another day.

â€œI wonâ€™t.â€

â€œOh, I, uhâ€¦â€ Actually sheâ€™d gotten her grandmotherâ€™s attention and made her requests already, through the Force. Shmi was working on them and should be done soon. Hopefully. â€œWeâ€™ll have enough. You worry about you, and getting to safety without dragging a politically unblooded, trainee Jedi into a sordid love scandal right before the biggest vote of your political career to date.â€

It was funny to see PadmÃ©â€™s face caught between laughter and horror. â€œDonâ€™t worry. If Iâ€™m going to allow rumors like that to start, Iâ€™ll at least make sure I get something out of it.â€

â€œI did not need to know that,â€ Leia said, which did make PadmÃ© laugh.

â€œSince when are you prudish?â€

â€œI donâ€™t get to know what it is?â€

â€œI suppose Iâ€™ll have to take your word for it.â€

It was hard to admit, but half of the reason that Anakin was staring at PadmÃ© right now was because she was wearing the outfit she had picked out as her best option for in transit as a refugee, and itâ€¦ It wasnâ€™t exactlyâ€¦

He understood why Leia had laughed. Even if it was rude.

â€œBe careful, miâ€™lady,â€ Captain Eye-Patch was saying, as the train was coming to a stop. â€œMake sure you stay safe.â€

Anakin tried not to roll his eyes. That was the whole point of him being here.

â€œI will,â€ PadmÃ© said, and Anakin thought her eyes sparkled a bit, even as she answered seriously. â€œThank you, Captain. And youâ€™ll make sure DormÃ© stays safe?â€

â€œOf course,â€ the captain replied, even more serious than PadmÃ©.

â€œAnd youâ€™ll make sure Leia stays out of trouble?â€

At her arch look Anakin had to swallow his mirth in the Force and bit his lips on a giggle.
