â€œGood.â€ And it seemed like PadmÃ© had actually been serious, not just baiting her guard. Why was everyone so worried about Leia? â€œUse your best judgement,â€ PadmÃ© was saying to DormÃ©. â€œWhatever you need to do to stay safe, do it.â€

â€œYouâ€™re going to regret that when I get creative,â€ DormÃ© said, and she smiled for a moment, looking to the captain, but when she turned back to PadmÃ© her face fell, and a tear escaped. Anakin almost flinched at the sudden pain.

â€œI have faith in you,â€ PadmÃ© said, her fingers reaching out and just brushing the handmaidenâ€™s. â€œYouâ€™ll be fine.â€

A split second half smile. â€œIâ€™m not worried about us.â€

Something happened then, something Anakin hadnâ€™t expected. He and Obi-Wan were the only Force users in the train car. PadmÃ© wasnâ€™t Force sensitive, and DormÃ© definitely wasnâ€™t. But it was as if something around them twisted, and in that moment they shared something between them. Not with words, but with trust and experience.

Anakin loved it when that happened. He didnâ€™t get to see it often, and almost never outside the Temple. But there was a rightness to it. Like being pulled into a hug by his mother, or the songs their neighbors used to sing together. Not magic, not mystic. Justâ€¦ being.

â€œIâ€™ll try to keep up,â€ DormÃ© was saying, â€œbut if I make too many appearances theyâ€™ll know youâ€™ve left the capital.â€

â€œThatâ€™s what Jar Jarâ€™s for,â€ PadmÃ© said. â€œTo be your cover. Heâ€™ll consult with you, youâ€™ll pretend on audio lines to be me. You can do this.â€

â€œI know.â€

There were a hundred things not being said in those words, and so many things being spoken in DormÃ©â€™s eyes.

â€œAnakin.â€ He turned towards his master, wishing he could keep following the other conversation. â€œYou be careful too. Donâ€™t do anything without first consulting either myself or the Council.â€

Right, as if that were practical. But Anakin knew what was expected and his, â€œYes, master,â€ was all Obi-Wan needed before he was turning to PadmÃ©.

â€œIâ€™ll try and get to the bottom of this as quickly as possible, miâ€™ladyâ€ he told her. â€œI know you and your people are in need of justice.â€

â€œAnd speed,â€ PadmÃ© insisted, nodding. â€œThank you. I know youâ€™ll do your best.â€

â€œYouâ€™ll be back here in no time,â€ Obi-Wan promised. â€œAnd then you can let Leia off her leash without fretting about it.â€

PadmÃ© was grinning. "I think we're talking about different people again."

Obi-Wan just smiled.

"It's time to go," Anakin said, watching the people loading onto the ship. They needed to hurry. There was only a small window where they could pull this off.

"I know," PadmÃ© was composed, nothing showing in her face. It made it easier for Anakin to stay calm, to not let off a hint of what they were doing that Obi-Wan might catch.

"Anakin." Oh no, had he slipped? Anakin turned to face his master. "May the Force be with you."

"May the Force be with you, Master." And let it help Obi-Wan catch these people before Anakin was subjected to another of Leia's plans. He was starting to get jitters.

They were off the train, just out of earshot of the guards, but not Obi-Wan if he was determined, when PadmÃ© said, "Suddenly I'm afraid."

Scrambling for something, they didn't have a code and he couldn't say he thought Obi-Wan might still be listening, "It's alright. It's my first time away from my master for an assignment." Lie, but he thought the look she shot him conveyed that she understood. "I'm nervous too." That was true. When they were far enough it should be safe he added, "Don't worry, we have Artoo with us."

She actually laughed.

Now for the tricky part.

They boarded the ship at the first open hatch, had their documents scanned (there would be a trail, if there was a leak it would look like they'd gone along with the original plan), and instead of heading for the lifts down, Anakin maneuvered them sideways, towards a hatch further along, halting them at the exit, tucked where they wouldnâ€™t interfere with the line.

They were cutting it close. They had to move soon or the hatch would close (and Leia might kill him, and Jedi training or not sometimes he thought she'd find it easy to do) and all of this extra planning would have been for nothing.

He'd promised PadmÃ© heâ€™d make it work. He wouldn't fail.

"Now."

It was a half whisper, but he could feel that Obi-Wan's attention had turned, shifted from being focused on Anakin's presence. Hopefully the train was getting ready to move.

They made it off the ship and Anakin had them stop behind some empty storage containers, waiting until the train had pulled fully away (taking no chances, Obi-Wan would definitely look back) before having them head to the shadows around the corner of the platform. They tried to move at the crowd's pace, like Leia had coached them, while sticking close to the wall and avoiding any attention.

Luckily Anakin was taller than PadmÃ© and he could partially cover her.

Unluckily they had a droid with them. Leia was right. As useful as Artoo was, he was in too good of condition to belong to a refugee. Especially as an astromech. Who had their own astromech and not their own ship? Or other property that required maintenance?

Their ship took off behind them and Anakin knew even if they weren't safe, they were committed.

"You're Shmi's people?"

The question came from a human female, closely followed by a female zabrak, who eyed the crowed around them with clear mistrust. Her focus and her stance told Anakin she was here as much as protection for the first woman as to help them.

"Yes," Anakin answered, offering a half bow and extending his hand. "I'm her son."

Which had both women looking more confused and uncomfortable for a moment before the zabrak shrugged and the human nodded. "Come with us."

Artoo may have been the slowest, but the women set a pace he could match and Anakin took advantage of that to drop to the back, letting the zabrak watch their front as she led them. The human woman fell into step with PadmÃ©, not speaking but offering an arm. Anakin was grateful. It eased some of PadmÃ©'s tension and made it easier for Anakin to sense what danger might be around them.

"In here."

It looked like, well not an abandoned building. No buildings were abandoned on Coruscant. But this one didn't seem completely structurally sound, and was definitely very dirty. The lift they entered was small and cramped with the five of them. Artoo chirped profanities at the state of things, especially when the lift jerked awkwardly about halfway down. PadmÃ© was startled enough to grab Anakin, but their guides only oozed irritation, not surprise.

Not an uncommon feature then.

Their path wound on probably for about another hour. It seemed very circuitous, looping around buildings with more lights and noises, wending through back alleys and tripping further and further down. PadmÃ© was almost visibly sagging by the time they made it to a door (off a side road, not a main one) where the women stopped and keyed in a code.

Anakin knew then that they didn't understand binary. Artoo's comments about how easy it would be to break in were completely inappropriate. Anakin told him so, also in binary. Which earned him some looks, even from PadmÃ©.

"What?"

She blinked. "I didn't knowâ€”"

"Inside, flirt later." The zabrak woman didn't look amused, but Anakin felt like she might be so he grinned. PadmÃ© may have been blushing, it was hard to tell in the dim light.

Inside there were probably twenty people in the front room, mostly women and children of various species. Halls and doors were faint in the background, but Anakin was busy searching with the Force rather than with his eyes. When he determined that there wasn't any immediate threat he nodded to PadmÃ© who nodded back, but seemed more than a little lost.

"We were told almost nothing," the human woman said, after introducing herself as Hailee, and her partner as Oobra. "But we have your change of clothes and will help with the droid."

At that Artoo whistled nervously, something about Leia getting carried away. Anakin asked Hailee, "What can we do to help?" hoping to get more details.

Hailee shook her head. "It will go faster if we take him. Don't worry," she added, seeing the look on PadmÃ©'s face. "He will be returned, and with all of his working pieces."

"Can he keep the broken ones too?" Anakin asked, aiming for an impish smile. He hoped it was covering PadmÃ©'s embarrassed look. "I like to collect those and make little speeders out of them."

Oobra smiled at that and Hailee hid her mouth behind her hand, her eyes dancing. "Yes, we will bring you the broken pieces too."

Good. He wasn't kidding about the mini-speeders. He wouldn't get in trouble for making them here and giving them to some of these kids. Some Jedi had no sense of humor about small gadgets getting caught in trailing robes.

Including his master.

PadmÃ© was led away by Oobra and one of the other women in the room and Anakin was invited to sit near the wall after his clothing was closely inspected by one of the roomâ€™s matrons and given a thoughtfully approving nod.

He was glad he'd gone for the poncho with the stain on it.

A few of the kids wandered up to him and it had been a while since he'd had to translate between four languages at once to follow a conversation, but after a few minutes he picked up the hang of it again. He delighted them by responding to each of them in their own tongue, instead of using Basic, and had two on his lap, tugging at his Padawan braid when PadmÃ© was led back into the room.

He recognized her because he'd seen her on Tatooine, dressed as a commoner, all those years ago, and because she was a light in the Force that he was always able to pinpoint when he was looking for it. But her fancy dress was gone and her hair was mostly down and he didn't think they'd actually rubbed dirt or grease on her face, but she seemed smudgy.

They'd taken her makeup off, he realized. And they hadn't worried about leaving stains and smears with it.

She'd gone from looking like a pristine statue, all wrapped and gilded in courage and fine robes, crowned with confidence, to looking almost like she had ten years ago, when she was just a displaced queen and he wasâ€¦ not who he was now.

This time, he wouldn't just help her. This time he would keep her safe.

Her fingers were rubbing the hem of her sleeves and Hailee led her over, a calm kindness radiating off of her. "Here she is. We have a transport for you, for the next stage. You won't be traveling far. Youâ€™re to be within two hours of the Senate building, in case of emergency." Her tone was reciting a message, one she didn't really understand. "We have a place prepared, as was asked."

"Thank you," Anakin said, extracting himself from the pile of children who complained that he was going. "Is there anythingâ€”"

â€œCompensation has been seen to," Oobra said solemnly. "Anything you do not need or want can be left at your residence when you are finished. We will take care of it."

Heâ€™d make sure to leave something for the kids, Anakin promised himself. They were playing games with each other, pretend stuff with little dolls and some well-worn figures. A few, maybe two people, had old datapads that flickered in ways Anakin wished he had time to fix. "We're very grateful," he said as they were led out of the house, through a back door this time, to a waiting speeder that Anakin wished, again, he could have fifteen minutes with. He knew what those noises meant, they didn't even need replacement parts yetâ€¦

PadmÃ© gasped under her breath when Artoo rolled out, painted yellow and brown and streaked with dirt and grease stains. When he got really close, Anakin could see something that imitated rust on some of his joints.

Anakin liked these people. They were thorough.

"Travel safely," Hailee said once Artoo had been loaded. It may have been directed to him and PadmÃ© or the driver. Anakin wasn't sure.

They were dropped off another level or two down on the side of a building that was speckled with doors. They were given an access card and made their way down a hallway lined with yet more doors, all battered and filthy.

If it wasn't to protect PadmÃ©'s life, Anakin would never have brought her here. He wasn't sure he should have brought her here anyway. Surely there was somewhere better.

"We should get inside," PadmÃ© whispered, eyes drifting to the other doors, scanning them for any sign someone was watching.

"Right," Anakin said, and he reached out with the Force, confirming there was no one inside, before opening the door.

Diagnosis

Anakin had expected an empty room and was surprised when they stepped in and several crates were scattered across the floor. They made him hesitate.

"Leia wouldn'tâ€”"

Couldnâ€™t have dropped them off personally, in any event. So he did need to make sure there werenâ€™t any unexpected surprises.

What?

â€œWhat is it?â€ PadmÃ© asked, and he could tell she was trying not to be impatient. He read her the note, but she seemed as confused as he was.

â€œWhat?â€ Anakin asked, trying not to trip in the small space. â€œArtoo, she promised what?â€

Open them with the Force and try and redirect any surprises, or inspect the box up close?

In the end, he opted for up close, running his fingers over everything, checking at different angles. If there was something hidden, it was completely inside. There was a faint smell of smoke, he thought. Almost like a grease fire, but also charred wires andâ€”

PadmÃ©â€™s ship had blown up. The only reason PadmÃ© wasnâ€™t dead was because PadmÃ© hadnâ€™t been on it.

Hole into eternity open in the bottom of his stomach, Anakin eased the lid off the first crate and had to fight back tears at what he saw inside. Part of an arm, a cracked and blasted torso, half a foot. And that was just the bits he could see on top.

â€œHe was in the explosion,â€ Anakin whispered, picking the foot up, running his thumb along the scorched, warped metal. â€œHe was on your ship.â€

â€œShmi wanted him to come with us. To help keep an eye on things.â€ Anakin didnâ€™t need to look to know guilt was written all over her face. â€œWe tried to have him looked at after, but everyone we consultedâ€¦ They said he was too customized. They didnâ€™t recognize any of his inner layout.â€

Well, yeah. Anakin had built him to be functional on Tatooine, not in ballrooms. Also, Threepioâ€™d been reconstructed when Anakin was nine.

â€œIs this all of him?â€ Anakin asked, unwilling to look back in the crate.

Her hand was on his shoulder. It was warm and kind and Anakin made himself look up and smile at her, knowing the look was more brave than happy and not caring about that right now. â€œIf she did, I can probably at least get started on fixing him.â€

He wasnâ€™t sure he would get very far. This was a lot of pieces, all of them seriously damaged. Heâ€™d need replacements for a lot of it. And toolsâ€¦

â€œI should check the other crates,â€ he said, standing and offering her a hand. She accepted and he pulled her straight up, so that she would still be right next to him. â€œAnd the other rooms. If theyâ€™re safe, you can stand in one until Iâ€™ve got everything cleared.â€

He would do this job right. PadmÃ©â€™s life was at stake and Obi-Wan thought it might sway the Council to think about knighting him andâ€”

He checked the other two rooms. They were small, tiny really. None of the other boxes exploded on him when he opened them. Which was nice.

â€œI didnâ€™t think he took up this much space,â€ PadmÃ© commented when she came back out. â€œIt doesnâ€™t look like thereâ€™s a lot of packing material either.â€

Travel rations and instant meals. Not the good stuff either. The stuff you got when it was just you and your master and you werenâ€™t part of an official negotiating team where you got real food because all politicians had weak stomachs.

â€œMaybe,â€ PadmÃ© said. â€œI donâ€™t really talk about it. And I donâ€™t do it much anymore. Leia canâ€™t cook, so I donâ€™t know that she would know what to send aside from this.â€

â€œShe canâ€™t cook at all?â€ Anakin couldnâ€™t imagine it. Hadnâ€™t she come from the Outer Rim? You had to at least know the basics so that you could tell if someone was cooking something that wasnâ€™t safe for your species. â€œHow does she survive?â€

PadmÃ© giggled as she took a seat on the (dubiously creaking) couch. â€œShmi helps her. I think sheâ€™s learning, but she wonâ€™t talk about it. I can only imagineâ€”â€œ PadmÃ© stopped, shrugged. â€œSheâ€™d rather not talk about it.â€

â€œAt least she knows droids okay,â€ he muttered as he started sorting through some of the other things in the crate. Artoo was happy to explain that they hadnâ€™t known the details of the damage and had erred on the side of safety. Anakin nodded, and then smiled. He could make a bunch of little toys from the extras, he thought.

â€œI donâ€™t suppose she left anything for me in there?â€ PadmÃ© asked as Anakin was just starting to pull apart the wrecked metal of Threepioâ€™s chest. â€œI donâ€™t see anything,â€ Anakin said, peering inside. â€œWait, no. Thereâ€™s a datapad.â€ He tossed it over, catching it again in the Force when PadmÃ© almost dropped it. â€œSorry.â€

She just smiled, grabbing it out of the air after studying it curiously for a moment. â€œNo, I missed it. Thank you.â€

He decided to wait a few minutes to see if she needed anything else before going back to his task.

â€œOh for the love ofâ€”â€œ PadmÃ© sounded irritated, but her lips were fighting a smile.

â€œWhat?â€

â€œNovels,â€ PadmÃ© sighed. â€œShe left me some of our notes on the MCA too, to keep me refreshed. But most of this is,â€ she hesitated, and this time Anakin did get to see her blushing, â€œromance novels.â€

Anakin stared. â€œWhat?â€

He had to stop saying that. He wouldnâ€™t sound smart if he kept saying just that.

â€œAnd a note that I am apparently to treat this as a forced vacation, and not only read the work documents,â€ PadmÃ© did not bother to explain more about the stories that Leia had left her, but her avoidance told Anakin most of what he needed to know.

â€œDo you like them?â€ he asked, trying to decide if he should be offended on her behalf. Leia was being pretty high handed in all of this.

A shrug. â€œI donâ€™t mind them, but I usually read historical records in my free time, especially about political figures from allied systems. Iâ€™m pretty young for a senator and I donâ€™t know as much about the history of my colleagues as I would like.â€

She was uncomfortable as she said it, as if it was reminding her of something she didnâ€™t want to think about. So Anakin opted for the first distraction he could think of and asked, â€œWhatâ€™s your favorite?â€

â€œI donâ€™t have one,â€ PadmÃ© confessed. â€œTheyâ€™re all interesting in terms of content, but the presentation is usually very dry. Although,â€ she scrolled a bit and smiled at the screen, â€œit looks like Leia has selected historical, political romances for me to read. So maybe this will be educational and interesting.â€

Heâ€™d have to take her word for it. Anakin liked reading, liked learning, but heâ€™d always preferred that any stories were spoken and signed, rather than just written down. You were missing something when someone didnâ€™t put their voice, their body, into the tale. â€œAre youâ€” Is it okay if I focus on this for a while? If youâ€™re reading?â€

He felt unsure again. The morning had been a tight dance of lying to and escaping from Obi-Wan, which had given all of this the taste of an adventure. Heâ€™d planned to be hyper-vigilant, all of his focus on PadmÃ© and their surroundings at all times, no mistakes.

Nowâ€¦

Now Threepio needed to be repaired, and he felt much safer in the anonymity of this frankly disgusting apartment than he had as they had approached the refugee ship. It felt like they had actually escaped from danger, that all they had to do now was to spend a couple of days waiting before PadmÃ© returned to do her job. It should be easy, maybe even nice.

But PadmÃ©â€™s comfort and safety came first, and if she needed his attentionâ€¦

â€œTake a look at Threepio,â€ she insisted. â€œI doubt you can get him all back together in two days, but itâ€™s worth a try. And if heâ€™s even only in partly working condition, having him would be a big help.â€ She smiled, and everything in the room went warm with the light of it. â€œIâ€™m glad Leia thought of this. Youâ€™re definitely the best person to try and fix him.â€

Well, if she needed Threepio, the droid Anakin had built, he would definitely start the repairs. Especially since, â€œI think I can at least get him pieced together and moving in two days. Iâ€™ve got enough spare parts, which wasnâ€™t true when I built him, and plenty of free time.â€

â€œYou do that,â€ she didnâ€™t believe him, but was willing to humor him. Anakin knew what to do with a challenge like that. â€œIâ€™ll start on some of these and see if theyâ€™re any good.â€

Heâ€™d just found his focus when he heard the first of her giggles. He glanced up, but she wasnâ€™t looking at him, so probably she didnâ€™t want to share.

The second and third time he was a little irritated, but she was happy and so Anakin made himself settled down again and refocus.

The fourth time PadmÃ© burst out laughing, almost doubled over, actual tears in the corners of her eyes as she almost choked.

â€œThat good?â€ he asked, half sighing and trying not to sound whiny.

She shook her head. â€œOh no, itâ€™sâ€¦ itâ€™s awful. Unbelievably awful.â€

Plausible Deniability

Muddy Waters

PadmÃ© was right about one thing. There were a lot of interesting things that you could do from a bed. Leia was currently virtually stalking Senator Darsana via the open chat channel for the senatorial aides, a complex conversation of shorthand codes, inside jokes, and half-truths meant to deliberately confuse the enemy.

Because the enemy was doing the same thing on the same chat channel.

It was a recruiting forum as much as anything else, so you had to risk exposure in order to catch the prize.

In this case, it really wasnâ€™t hard because the Neimoidians were obviously pursuing the senator (probably at least indirectly Leiaâ€™s fault) and were doing a terrible job of it because they thought the result of the vote was inevitable and it oozed off of their every word, not unlike the film that covered their skin.

She wanted to actively not think about the comments being made by Senator Organa and Senator Mothmaâ€™s offices. But her need to know would not allow her to avoid that well of information.

Apparently the codes hadnâ€™t changed that much over two decades. Bottom line, we donâ€™t know for sure weâ€™re losing, but itâ€™s going to be close.

And someone please stop Jar Jar Binks.

The problem, Leia thought as she rubbed her face and adjusted herself against her pillows, was that all Jar Jar wanted was to be helpful. And PadmÃ©â€™s idea of a baseline work ethic ran most people into the ground in less than a day, but not the gungan, so heâ€™d kept the job partly on virtue of being able to keep up. But while he had the energy and the desire, Jar Jar did not have an ounce of the deviousness in him needed to manipulate the Senate.

The obliviousness to resist its poison, yes. The tenacity to keep bouncing back after mistakes and fallout, certainly. The genuine goodness to baffle, confuse, and almost trick some people with its authenticity.

But not the duplicity. Not the conniving. Not the rage or the drive for power.

And when it came down to it, getting votes was a fight.

â€œGo to sleep.â€ Shmiâ€™s voice in Leiaâ€™s head was sleepy, but there was still an edge of affectionate sharpness to it. The voice of a mother, expecting to be heeded.

â€œGood.â€

The reality was she didnâ€™t. Not for a while. Not looking at the screen didnâ€™t stop her brain from spinning round and round, trying to find solutions to problems she was systems too far away to solve.

In the soft blanket of darkness, Leia thought she knew the truth.

The bad news was that it had taken him all night to get there and it hadnâ€™t been a refreshing ten hours, heâ€™d just been working. Heâ€™d caught her sleeve for half a second, but she didnâ€™t slow down when she felt the tug and Anakinâ€™s words died in his mouth.

He was really screwing this up.

The temptation to just stomp around the apartment and be angry was large, but his brain chose this moment to realize that Artoo hadnâ€™t moved away from the door the entire time theyâ€™d been here. Sure, heâ€™d rolled forward to help with Threepio. But heâ€™d kept in a tight rectangle, always covering at least part of the doorway, so that anyone who tried to come in would fall over him first.

Artoo had remembered that. Heâ€™d never lost sight of it. Not like the stupid, sleep deprived organic that was Anakin Skywalker.

Enough. He could do better. He would do better.

The room was way too small for him to practice lightsaber forms, especially with Artoo and a half assembled Threepio around. At least, not with the blade live. So he ran through his basics with just his hilt, letting the movements bring him focus and work off some of his energy.

He was still angry. He didnâ€™t even know why, but he was. And he was also tired. Which maybe had something to do with being stupidly angry. So when he was done practicing, and checking their floor for the sense of any threat lurking around, Anakin made himself fold up on the floor (couch would have been too distracting) and meditate.

Heâ€™d told Obi-Wan he wanted to, might as well take advantage.

He didnâ€™t end up doing it for very long.

Any time that he tried to find something to let go of or concentrate on, heâ€™d be drawn to his half-completed project in the corner. After maybe thirty minutes, he accepted that whatever was going on in his head, Threepio was too important and nothing else (besides protecting PadmÃ©) was going to matter until he got this done.

And he needed the time if he was going to finish by tomorrow. Especially if he was going to manage the upgrades.

He only interrupted his work for a few minutes to make PadmÃ© lunch and hover awkwardly near her door, trying to decide the best thing to do. The simple knock and flee option would have worked better if she wouldnâ€™t have been able to see him in the front room from her open door.

In the end, he accepted the awkwardness and waited for her to open up, holding out a bowl and a cup when she did and saying, â€œBrain food.â€

She actually smiled, just a little, and he hadnâ€™t even been trying to be funny. As she took them, she asked, â€œHowâ€™s it going?â€

â€œNotâ€¦not bad.â€ And then, because some part of his brain was still working separately from the rest of him, â€œDo you think, laterâ€”Would you have time? Artoo canâ€™t reach much above his waist, and my hands areâ€”I was smaller at nine. Could youâ€¦ help? Me?â€

â€œAre you sure?â€ she asked, and he felt like she was asking something else and he had just missed it.

â€œYeah?â€

â€œAlright. Let me finish a couple things and eat this and Iâ€™ll be right out.â€

â€œOkay,â€ he told the closing door.

Crescendo

Chancellor Sheev Palpatine was a seasoned politician who had seen the rise and fall of many parties and ambitions and frequently joked that if there was anything left that could surprise him, he didnâ€™t want to see it. The day to day of his life was bad enough.

Anakin had never completely understood why that was so funny, but heâ€™d always laughed when the Chancellor said it to him, because Anakin wasnâ€™t stupid and he wouldnâ€™t make the Chancellor look stupid by looking like an Outer Rim castoff when he was specially invited to the Chancellorâ€™s office. Next he used his eyes and ears, focusing them with the Force when he realized there were too many people and the room was too large to catch everything the old fashioned way. â€œWho are the people in the central pod?â€ Shmi was asking SabÃ© when Leiaâ€™s focus came back. â€œWhat are they doing?â€

â€œFear of reprisal is what keeps most people from interrupting in the middle of speeches,â€ Leia added when SabÃ© was finished. â€œTechnically during a scheduled debate, as opposed to informative assemblies or celebrations or other nonsense, anyone can interject at any point where they feel false information is being given. Shmi smiled, but it was only for a moment before she turned back to the debate. â€œThey are alternating?â€

â€œThe Chancellor and the Vice Chair are usually enough up to date on allegiances to keep that pattern going,â€ SabÃ© said between bites. â€œBad ones will moderate so that the party they align with goes last. â€œChancellor Palpatine is a good moderator then?â€ Shmi asked.

SabÃ© shook her head. â€œHeâ€™s fine. I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s him getting lost in his own friendships and forgetting where othersâ€™ alliances are, but this will get pretty muddled before it gets to the end.â€

â€œWhen will PadmÃ© speak?â€

â€œIf they can manage it, last,â€ Leia said. â€œIf not, close to the end.â€

â€œShe wants to stand out,â€ Shmi seemed impressed and worried.

â€œLeia,â€ Shmi scolded.

â€œSheâ€™s right,â€ VersÃ© stepped in, shaking her head. â€œHeâ€™s very good for a lot of things, but public speaking always makes him nervous. Which was why PadmÃ© was there in spite of the fact that they hadnâ€™t heard anything about her bounty hunter.

The proceedings dragged on. Three times pro-military members delayed volunteering to speak in the hopes of provoking PadmÃ© to go early. Those silences seemed to stretch on forever.

The last one, a battle for what would probably be the last speech before the Chancellorâ€™s closing remarks, created an empty space of three full minutes, provoking Mas Amedda to threaten to close to proceedings. The Sermerian delegation caved first. Possibly because Senator Paddie had made the mistake of meeting PadmÃ©â€™s eyes.

When the Chancellor turned the floor over to the Senator from Naboo, Leia had to bite her lips to stop herself from sniggering. His face may have looked calm to many, but she knew what those carefully flattened lips meant.

The Senate was boring. Anakin was grateful heâ€™d had to stay standing because otherwise he might have fallen asleep and humiliated PadmÃ©.

The first few speeches hadnâ€™t been so bad. Some of the arguing between speeches was pretty good. But after the third or fourth person, it was getting repetitive, a point for point attack that boiled down to, do you value what we do or what they do?

He wished Obi-Wan was here. Mind speaking was a little hard, but their bond was more than strong enough to share humor or irritation, and sometimes not being alone was the most important part.

Which was why he kept shifting (not because he had to fidget) when PadmÃ© would start to tense. He didnâ€™t have another way to remind her that he was here, but from her half glances at him and her slight relaxing, she did get it.

Finally, finally, it was PadmÃ©â€™s turn to speak. Having all the eyes in the room on their pod as it floated forward made Anakinâ€™s skin crawl. Now he was trying not to fidget. He looked to the Chancellor, hoping forâ€¦ something, but the Chancellorâ€™s attention was locked on Senator Amidala.

She waited almost a full minute once theyâ€™d stopped, until the low rumble of background noise actually quieted to almost nothing. Then she braced her hands against the sides of her podium.

â€œHonorable delegates,â€ her voice was low and clear, â€œI will not waste your time by repeating the arguments against the MCA which have been so clearly stated by my colleagues. That earned a murmur, but it quickly faded. â€œWhat I am here to say, to add to what has already been said, is this. You are not alone.â€ A breath, and her hands were turning white where they gripped the podium. â€œNo one of you, not a single one, is alone. Because we are a Republic.â€

Anakin recognized most of the pieces of what she said next. Theyâ€™d gone over her speech, very quickly, with her handmaidens. She outlined what a democracy was, why it was important, why the right to choose to participate in it was equally important. Why some people might feel inclined to leave, if a democracy failed to meet their needs.

â€œWe mourn the loss of systems and colleagues who are no longer with us,â€ PadmÃ© said, hand sweeping up and down to showcase empty pods. â€œWe miss them. We are afraid for them, and what their absence means. But we cannot be afraid of them. And we cannot act in this body based on that fear.â€

He felt her trembling in the Force, felt the weight and the depth of her emotions, screaming to find an escape through her words. Holding her up and dragging her back. How was anyone in this room still breathing, looking at her?

â€œI have been accused of being naive,â€ PadmÃ© said, and some of her anger leaked into her feelings, if not her voice. â€œI have been accused of being simplistic and pacifist and not knowing what the cost of those things means. We donâ€™t timidly say, â€˜Pick your battles.â€™ I stand here today with Representative Binks,â€ her hand flung back to point at Jar Jar, â€œbecause once I stood before this body and it failed to protect my people.

â€œAnd my answer to that,â€ PadmÃ© continued, â€œwas to reach out to those in my system and beg them to stand with us, when we had done them so much wrong. We ask you to vote down this act so that in its place we can offer others. Donâ€™t be afraid, her posture said, the echoes of her voice still quivering through the room. Donâ€™t be afraid, Iâ€™m with you.

Anakin would follow her anywhere, he thought, as in bursts the entire chamber broke into shouts and applause. He would follow her anywhere, do anything, anything she asked. Just so he could stay wrapped in this light that danced around her, bending the universe into something more beautiful.

The applause went on for some time, but the mood was interrupted when the broadcast decided to use the time to recap the explosion on the landing platform and all of the difficulties the Naboo delegation had been going through. And to express some surprise that PadmÃ© had come, given the imminent threat to her life.

Leia tuned it all out, holding Shmiâ€™s hand and waiting for the votes to come in. As the moderators reviewed the tallies the whole room held their breath. When the vote came back with the MCA defeated, Leia couldnâ€™t even be angry that PadmÃ© collapsed against Anakin in full view of the galaxy and started to cry.

â€œAn army was purchased,â€ he murmured. â€œAnd in the Councilâ€™s name. More we will learn from Obi-Wanâ€™s efforts.â€

Chapter End Notes

So, I started this story under the belief that it would be long, but it was one story. Maybe a couple hundred thousand words, but all of a nice cohesive piece with a couple overarching themes that would tie into each other, and a few major plot points with a bit of narrative string holding them together. Easy peasy.

I can still hear my beta laughing at me, 800 miles away.

After some consideration, consultation with said beta, some maniacal cackling and some head banging against a desk (I'll let you guess which off us was doing which), I've come to the conclusion that for the way my brain works thematically, this will now have to be cut into pieces. I'll spare myself the embarrassment of guessing how many or few of them. I have always been wrong, and will probably be wrong again if I try.

That being said, while Like Fire is now listed as completed, fear not, I am not leaving the story to end here. There is plenty more to be read. Just probably not this week. I'll need a smidge of time to get a handle on exactly where this next bit is going (especially because it decided to change major plot points just as my head was hitting my pillow last night, thanks brain).

Thank you all for your support and interest. As this project has grown I've had more and more anxieties about finishing it and whether the endeavor was worth it. Your comments and statistical presence make it easier to encourage myself to keep going. I really, really, really appreciate it. I hope you're pleased with the results.

(And yes, if you listen closely, you too may be able to hear my beta still laughing.)

Afterword
